28906046.review:
The game gripped me shortly after beginning. My heater was broken, it was freezing outside. But this wonderful adventure had hooked me. The world is one of the best-presented I've ever seen. The characters are very well presented to make you curious for more. I just wanted to spend more time exploring this world. It's also filled with humor that lightens up the somber setting, it's difficult to explain just how well the combination works.

The puzzles themselves vary in quality, with some doing a great job in feeling like you're just solving problems that would exist in the world rather than an arbitrary roadblock by the developers. Others... Not so much. One particular puzzle stands out as an example of this problem (slight spoiler warning, though I won't give the answer)

You need two different objects that can obstruct a vent. The first is easily gained by cutting off the tip of a robot's finger. However, the game doesn't allow you to cut off the tip of another finger for the second item. This is a frustrating limitation, and can easily lead to resenting the puzzle. The fact that important objects are often indistinguishable from the background only adds to the frustration.

HOWEVER, and I can't stress this enough, while this kind of uneven quality in puzzles should suck the fun out of an adventure game... It doesn't. The rest of the world is too entrancing. It single-handedly rekindled my love of adventure games. I bring up these drawbacks to help emphasize how truly great the rest of the experience is, that even these issues don't sour it.

TLDR; If you're considering buying this game, do so. Do it now. Play it. Enjoy it. Have fun.

28859284.review:
TL;DR: If you love noir and/or sci-fi, get this on sale and play with a walkthrough, because it's not a super-fun game, but it's an awesome experience!

A very classic-feeling adventure game with a perfect blend of science fiction and noir - and not the watered-down versions you might be used to, I mean think classics, the genre-defining stuff people still remember from 50+ years ago. As a fan of both, I was very satisfied. It's a smart story excellently told with top-notch writing and art. Kudos to the devs for having the game run in super-low resolution - no accidental ruining of the retro feel by hi-res glows or particle effects. You want retro? This is retro. The art direction is consistent right down to the screen resolution.

As a game... not so much. See, it's an adventure game, and that means exactly what you think it means. Personally, I bought it for half-off and after the first 40 minutes or so I opened up a guide - so much more enjoyable! The writing is witty, the world-building is amazing, the story unfolds with perfect timing... why be bogged down with "find the hidden active zone in the dozen screens you have access to" or "use X on Y in order to use X, Y, and Z together, no other combination works"? Those games are dumb. When you actually have all the items and clues the puzzles are usually not stupid, but you never really know if you do - the fundamental failing of adventure games. Don't put yourself through that just to get at the good stuff. Keep a walkthrough open and peek at it any time you're starting to get the slightest doubt on how to proceed.

I am not the kind of person who usually goes into games for storytelling, but I am a sucker for sci-fi and an even bigger sucker for noir, so this was totally worth it. If I'd known how good a time I would have I might have even paid full price! If any of what I wrote sounded interesting and you have the time to kill, it's definitely worth at least the price of a movie ticket.

28848321.review:
This game is absolutely fantastic. I don't think I can do it justice here, but I will try.

This game is a work of art. It's very fun and the puzzles are stimulating, but the real treasure is in the dialogue and the world. This game explores the nature of religion, justice, and creation in a post-human, post-apocalyptic world. It's so achingly beautiful. I also literally cried at the end. It's a rare story that can reduce me to tears, but this one did it.

Mechanically this game is great as well. The music and the voice acting are wonderful, and the graphics are perfect for the story. The game flows well, and I think it was a good length. The character arc of Horatio was fantastic and satisfying - any longer and I think the game would lose some of the power of its narration.

The details are what really make this game. Explore everything. Talk a lot to Crispin. Right-click on everything. Go through all dialogue options. This world is compelling, and beautiful, and utterly desolate. Horatio, the protagonist, is similarly compelling, beautiful, and desolate. If you're looking through the reviews because Primordia's on sale, please just buy it. You will 100% not regret it, I promise.

28846074.review: A highly polished, fully voiced retro adventure game with an engaging post apoctalyptic sci-fi story. Lasts about 6-8 hours depending on how long it takes you to figure out the puzzles. There is a small amount of replayability via optional achievements as well as a specific set of hidden objectives you must complete in order to get the best ending. Support the devs and buy it!

28840132.review:
If you enjoy dark dystopian sci-fi, beautiful artwork, and a storybook gameplay I highly recommend you try Primordia!

As a point-and-click storybook game, Primordia does not dissappoint. It's smart, well-illustrated, and presents a compelling story. The writers took care to build an internally consistent world complete with mythology and believable motives. It's a world I would not be dissappointed to return to in a follow-up title. 

There is an obvious retro-feel that permeates not only the art style, but also the story and game-mechanic. Primordia's writing reminds me of 1980s robot sci-fi including a few text-based games from that era. The art is clearly influenced by visual work from that period including Lynch's Dune. There are multiple endings, and I enjoyed that the best of them still presented a dark and morally clouded set of choices for the main character.

The only criticism I have of Primordia is the same criticism I have of similar point-and-click games; many of the inventory combinations and item uses are not intuitive and are occassionally inconsistent. Also, while the side-kick character was a wise choice for an in-game hint system, his personality occassionally feels out of place. FYI: There were also 2 achievements which I believe I met the criteria for but did not recieve. Probably not a bug, but other reviewers have had the same problem.

28789292.review:
Купил игру очень давно, но не играл из-за отсутствия перевода на русский язык, так как знания по английскому языку у меня довольно поверхностные (о чём я сейчас очень сильно жалею). Но решил всё-таки попробовать пройти игру без перевода. 
Во время прохождения я очень многое упустил, пропустил, недопонял, но это не помешало мне полюбить эту игру. 
Primordia - это очень серьезное произведение, в котором есть место как драматическим событиям, так и смешным моментам, которые вместе сочeтаются прямо как в настоящей жизни. А ведь по сути, в игре и создана жизнь, пусть и в рамках квеста. 

Что я бы выделил в этой игре?

* Каждый персонаж имеет свою харизму и проработанный характер. Голоса, как мне кажется, им подобрали идеально. Не припоминаю в игре неинтересных персонажей, у всех есть какая-нибудь изюминка. Диалоги с ними в игре я не пропускал, а пытался вникнуть, так как было действительно интересно узнавать что-то новое.

* Сюжет. Вроде бы простой, но в то же время сложный. Во время прохождения появляется всё больше деталей. Обращать на них внимание или нет зависит только от самого игрока. Честно говоря, у меня сейчас есть желание сесть за игру по старинке, со словариком, и сидеть вникать в сюжет.

* Квесты. Большая часть довольно простая, но попадаются такие, где приходится повозиться и серьезно подумать. Каюсь, в парочке моментов пришлось прибегнуть к прохождению в интернете. Всего таких моментов было три, два из них связаны с моим знанием английского, а в третьем я сам себе усложнил задачу, дурак, а решение было довольно очевидным.

* Внимание к деталям игрового мира. Очень запомнился граммофон(на самом деле в игре фонограф, но мне почему-то он запомнился как граммофон, edit). Я ведь совсем забыл, что такие музыкальные аппараты когда-то были, игра вот напомнила. Проходил мимо него и включал ту единственную песню и  просто слушал…
Игра просто наполнена ламповой атмосферой. Картины, пейзажи, роботы, в игре есть на что посмотреть.

* Криспин. Этого робота я выделю отдельно, он этого заслуживает. Идеальный компаньон. Его комментарии были всегда в тему, иногда после них меня пробивало на конкретное ха-ха (сидел и смеялся как дурак, даже сейчас вспоминаю и удержаться не могу).

* Визуальный стиль. Мне он сначала совсем не понравился, а сейчас даже не знаю было ли лучше, если бы он был другим. Немного поиграв, проникся уважением к художникам. В игре всё нарисовано с душой. Да, такой стиль понравится далеко не всем, но игре он вполне подходит.

* Я в играх почти не обращаю внимания на саундтрек. Поэтому мало что могу сказать о музыкальном сопровождении. Но меня в игре ничего не отвлекало, надоедливых мелодий не было, не было и желания включить свою музыку фоном.

* Единственное, что мне в игре не понравилось — это технические проблемы. Несколько раз игра вылетела, но спасибо автосохранениям. С инвентарем были какие-то неполадки: под конец игры у меня половина предметов в нём отображалась некорректно. Но меня это не сильно напрягало.

P.S.: Таких хороших игр очень не хватает. Огромное спасибо разработчикам за такую душевную игру. 

А я, пожалуй, куплю её и в GOG.

28781507.review: A classic style adventure game. Very interesting and original setting. Decent writing and puzzles. A bit short, but definitely worth the money I paid for it.

28779813.review:
Primordia is a retro-styled point and click adventure game set in a dystopian future in which Man has gone extinct. Only machines remain, struggling to survive in the junk-filled wastelands. The protagonist will have to face many challenges in order to retrieve his source of power, gradually learning about the hidden thruth of his world along the way.

The gameplay is very simple, as is every other adventure game: you'll have to explore, find and combine multiple items and use them at the right places to progress. What separates this game from the others is it's theme and its great humor. The last being delivered by a lovable sidekick who also serves the purpose of a hint bot. The puzzles are clever and challenging but not impossibly hard. 

The story is filled with rich and interesting lore, but is very linear (except at the very end, where you have multiple endings available). Each dialogue feels thought out and unique.

The graphics are very reminiscent to those of Fallout 1: pixelated and low-resolution with dark brownish tones, which is tolerable since they seemed to be aiming for the retro theme. The only exception is the handful of brief cutscenes presenting very detailled close-ups of the action, which help with the immersion. The soundtrack is atmospheric and blends well with the setting. The voice acting is truely amazing.

There's even some replayability value for those who wish try the commentary mode.

[b]So in short;[/b] for a 7 hour game with a good storyline and challenging puzzles paired with immersive soundtrack and great voice-acting, the pricetag is well worth the experience.

28768529.review: Primordia is a point 'n click developed by Wormwood Studios which provides a good storyline, well-written dialogues, old-school graphics, an atmosphere somewhere between Machinarium and Blade Runner and a cool soundtrack by Nathaniel Chambers. 28505136.review:
[NO SPOILER!!!!]

Primordia ist ein klassisches Point&Click Game im Retro Stil der frühen 90er Jahre. Die Handlung entwickelt sich durch das Lösen von Rätseln, kombinieren von nützlichen Gegenständen, sowie den Entscheidungen über das falsche oder richtige Handeln. 

Worum gehts?
Der mysteriöse Android Horatio und sein kleiner Gehilfe Crispin durchstreifen ein postapokalyptisches Szenario in einer Wüste. Woher sie kommen und welches Ziel sie verfolgen bleibt ungeklärt. Was ist mit dieser ehemals fortschrittlichen Welt passiert, von der nur Ruinen übrig geblieben sind? Und welche Entscheidung führen die Beiden Freude an Ihr eigentliches Ziel?

POSITIV: 
+ detaillierte Szenarios
+ guter Soundtrack
+ düstere Atmosphäre
+ super (!) Synchro
+ fein ausgefeilte Charaktere
+ Spiel läuft flüssig, gute Steuerung, jederzeit speicherbar

NEGATIV: 
- keine deutsche Vertonung, schade
- frustrierende Rätsel, ziemlich knifflig
- Das Volumen der Musik kann nur bedingt reguliert werden, Volumen ist manchmal schlecht abgemischt. 

FAZIT: 
Ein wirklich schönes Spiel mit viel Atmosphäre und einer interessanten Handlung. Die Dialoge haben mich oft zum lachen gebracht weil Horatio und Crispin ein wunderbares Team sind (was sich liebt das neckt sich). Als alter Hase darf ich das sagen: die 90er Atmosphäre wirkt NICHT aufgesetzt, ganz im Gegenteil. Ich habe mich dabei erwischt wie ich das Release Datums des Spiels überprüft habe, um sicher zu gehen. 
Das einzige was mich frustriert hat waren die knüppelharten Rätsel. Nachdem ich Stunden umher geirrt bin habe ich einen Blick in die Auslösung geworfen nur um fest zu stellen dass ich da wohl nie selbst drauf gekommen wäre... dies ist jedoch ein sehr persönlicher Kritikpunkt. 
Wer also auf dystopische gruselige Sci-Fi Geschichten mit schwarzen Humor steht sollte vielleicht ein paar ruhige Abende investieren um die Welt von Primordia zu erforschen. Viel Vergnügen!

Great world, awesome voice acting, humor and interesting characters.

As it stands - it is awesome game for people, who dont mind to look past few obvious flaws, but not the game "everyone" could possibly enjoy at this state.

Oh yea and it is somewhat short.

28322883.review: 7/10. Good game but not great. 28321273.review:
Digging through Wadjet Eye catalogue is a pleasure every time, so when I finally found the time to try Primordia out, I wasn't expecting any less than a great adventure. But wow, I wasn't expecting it to be [i]that[/i] great, either.

Obviously, most of the reviewers around here have already described the game much better than a non-native English speaker ever could, though it never hurts to praise a masterpiece. And as with any other masterpiece, it doesn't seem necessary to break it down to individual components and discuss whether the mechanics lack gunplay. The only thing that matters here is the feeling, what it's like to live through the story of Primordia.

You know when you're close to finishing a book so good you almost don't want to read the last few pages? It's as if a significant part of your life is about to be taken, and you try to savor every single word there's left. Oh boy, I still remember the devastation I felt as a kid when 'Pippi Longstocking' ended. [spoiler](don't judge me, I love that book)[/spoiler] A horrible yet extremely satisfying moment of experiencing something beautiful and important. And it's exactly what a quality adventure game should be – a book you will never forget.

Primordia bears this very feeling in its core logic. Its world, consisting of rust and despair, might not be of the attractive kind, but the minute you dive into it, you'll have enough reasons to stay. It is surprisingly smart, detailed, vivid and, even less expectedly, highly amusing thanks to the characters populating it. Despite the depressing tones, the amount of intelligent humour makes it one of the most likeable worlds in the recent adventure games history.

No wonder leaving it is incredibly hard. I found myself thinking, "This is not enough! Why would you end it so soon? I want more!" and loading random saves to listen to random dialogues once again. But while Primordia surely is a short experience, I doubt making it longer would've made any difference. You just can't have enough of worlds like this one. 

Primordia is indeed a hidden gem of the genre. Well, not really hidden anymore, but it definitely is something that deserves more attention. Every piece of attention you can afford, to be precise.

Thank you, Mark. I'm sorry it took me so long to play it. <3

28316048.review: Great atmosphere and writing..enjoyed it quite a bit actually!

28284042.review:
[h1] So what happens [i] after [/i] the robots take over the world? [/h1]

[i] Primordia [/i] is here to answer that question. This amazing point-and-click game takes place on a dystopian Earth at an unspecified point in history. The few humans that remain have fled underground, living in low-g bunkers and looking at a once-green Earth through pictures and little garden chambers. Over the years, we have faded into myth, and now the Earth is ruled by our creations, some of who worship our memory as a creed called "Humanism."

You are Horatio Nullbuilt, a wasteland-dwelling robot of undeterminate origin whose only companion is Crispin Horatiobuilt, a floating, armless robot with an endless supply of sarcastic remarks. Together, they lived a pretty uneventful life. They were trying to fix up a crashed airship, a relic of the long-forgotten War of the Four Cities, so they could at last fly away from the Dunes and go wherever they want. Unfortunately, their progress is halted when a mysterious robot named Scraper shows up and "plunders" their power core--an item they cannot survive without. When trying to find power in the Dunes fails, they have no choice but to travel to Metropol, the last city, where their power core has been taken. To make matters worse, an anceint robot named MetroMind has claimed your power core for the betterment of the city, since it is crumbling under her inept rule and she needs all the power she can get.

From there, it is up to you how the story ends. Choose carefully, your every move has consequences.

The voice-acting is masterfully done. Every character is unique and full of personality. The story and lore are very well-crafted as well. Unraveling the mystery of the world you're in never fails to be fascinating, and if you play through it just right, the ending is beautiful and cathartic.

Like my review? Check out my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/27019034-%EF%BC%B2%EF%BC%A5%EF%BC%AF%EF%BC%AE%EF%BC%A1%EF%BC%B2%EF%BC%A4%27s-Reviews/] Curator [/url] page!

This game is a work of art.  It has a profound atmosphere to it- something that just so perfectly sets the tone with the perfect blend of dystopian future, a sense of doom, and yet also quite wry humor.  The visuals, the dialogue, and the themes all marry together so well.


It would be so hard to fully explain why this game is so magnificent.  The visuals are impressive, the voice acting flawless, the gameplay intellectually challenging but requiring no particular finesse or agility, it is a game that anyone could play.  With multiple endings and some multiple paths, it has a little bit of replay value.  Even for one playthrough of about 5-6 hours though, the price of a movie ticket for this game is a steal.
TL;DR:
10/10, buy this game you ponce.

27872318.review: Primordia - это один из лучших представителей игр в жанре "роботы в пост-апокалипсисе". Серьезно, она настолько атмосферная и оригинальная,  что может встать в один ряд с такими мастодонтами жанра квест, как Black Mirror и Grim Fandango. Человечества больше не существует. Боты, которых они перед своей аннигиляцие насобирали в боьшом кол-ве, приняли эстафету властелинов этой многострадальной планеты. За одного из этих ботов (Горацио-Первособранный) нам и предстоит играть и познавать всю тщетность пост-апокалиптичного бытия. Сопровождать нас в этом невеселом занятии будет наш мини слуга и просто хороший друг (забыл как его зовут), который постоянно остроумит и создают атмосферу дружеского уюта, что позволяет нам привязаться к нему. Мир в игре довольно мрачен и достаточно при этом забавен, но без чернухи. По итогу можно сказать, что игра явно заслуживает вашего внимания, а если вы любите квесты, то тем более. Однозначный Маст Хэв.

27730162.review:
Where can i start to review this game?
On the surface it's an old shool point-and-click adventure, but the story, the voice acting, the art and the setting are simply amazing.

Set in a post-apocalyptic world where machines have became sentient and capable of build (and re-build) themselves.
In this world, humans are only a fading memory, kept in partially corrupted data gathered by some and spread in a form of a religion.
Most of the world is now covered by the desert, where most of the androids live in a single huge city.
This is the background where Horatio, the protagonist, starts its (his?) journey to find a stolen component of his ship, revealing part of his (and our) past in the process.

The amazing art (all hand-made) and the attention to details of the world makes me heavily recomend this game to any point-and-click adventures fan with a soft spot for the post-apocaliptic setting :)

26543939.review:
[b]Primordia might be the single best point & click game in existence. It is a classic point & click adventure game set a in post-apocalyptic world with stunning and handcrafted pixel art, outstanding narration and one of the most atmospheric soundtracks you will ever encounter.[/b]

[h1]Graphics:[/h1] Each place you visit during the game offers very well-drawn and thematic pixel art with a good animation quality. More importantly, everything offers a feel of authenticity, which keeps you immersed in this post-apocalyptic sci-fi world.

[h1]Sound, Music & Voice:[/h1] The soundeffects are very decent for a point & click game. What really outshines all else are the soundtrack and the narration. The soundtrack is the most immersive and fitting I've ever encountered in this genre. It has around 40 (!) different tracks, which is very rare to see for such a game. The narration of the two main characters is very well done and their lines vary between fitting, serene and often amusing. In fact, it was so well done that I had to listen to the hints despite having solved a puzzle, just to hear all they had to say!

[h1]Gameplay & Story:[/h1] You control two robot companions, stranded in a post-apocalyptic world, where man has perished and become a myth. Your task is to solve different puzzles in the typical point & click style. Your goal is to repair your broken down ship and leave this world. You will visit different locations within the gameworld to find objects and solve puzzles which consist in many cases of applying one or two items to a certain location. Many of the puzzles are challenging but fair. Only for a few I had to go 'pixel hunting' and click everything on the screen to find what I was looking for. Should you have trouble solving a puzzle, your trusty robot companion at your side will always have a few hints for you ready!
The world is incredibly well built and the story kept me glued to the screen until I reached one of the many endings after around 12 hours.

[h1]Funfactor:[/h1] I enjoyed this game more than any other point & click adventure game I have ever played. In my opinion it even outshines the well praised Machinarium. Minor gripes were some technical issue while trying to launch the game for the first time.

[h1]Verdict: [/h1][b]MUST BUY![/b] Amazing world, story, pixel art, narration and soundtrack. If you have not played this game yet, it is my personal favourite point & click of all times. A must to play!

26347046.review:
Won this in a contest and picked it out cause good reviews and I like adventure games.

It's a point and click adventure game with an older sprite style and more detailed Giger-esque backgrounds. Overall I would reccomend it.

Pros:
>Good story - robot society after humans are gone
>Variety of characters with personality
>Easy to get around - you can walk and you have a map that teleports you to key spots.
>Puzzle quality and variety - From building tools to opening doors to judging court cases I can't think of a point that really struck me as needing unintuitive logic to solve.
>Hint system - robot buddy that you can ask for puzzle suggestions, usually helpful
>Takes notes for you - game jots down important information for you, which can help for puzzles. Couple spots you might still need pen and paper to work something out, though.
>Hot keys for menu stuff
>Does a good job getting into your thought processes - a few puzzles with multiple solutions, some puzzles animated to let you try something even though it doesn't actually work.
>Flavor text - if you like subtle characterization and banter, you can look at most everything for description stuff.
>Multiple saves - Save whenever you want however much you like.

Cons:
>Can't easily get out of item use - have to go into inventory to get your regular cursor back (hot key makes it bearable)
>Some pixel hunting - at least one puzzle where you need to notice a small, muddy colored item in a dark, muddy colored area
>Hints aren't always helpful - sometimes it hints what you know you need to find, not how or where to find it. Other times it's so obtuse that it's really no help at all.
>One or two puzzles that use a game feature only once - ran into one that required using the describe feature, which I didn't know was there and which had never been necessary to get info about items or progress puzzles before then.
>Loading issue - due to the chosen game engine, can't load saves past your 20th most recent save. Have to delete saves to get the one you want in that 1-20 section.

25957066.review:
Some puzzles are fairly easy because you know you got everything you need and must make it work somehow.

Others are terrible - the flipped ship, the rag that takes long to discover, the overall logic of the puzzles. One time you try to search the junk and your character says there's nothing in there of interest, next time you find something in there. When I get told: "This is all crap", then I dont expect this to magically transform suddenly to the puzzle solution. Games usually separate between useless and useful. The useless is for decoration mostly. These NPCs are called "workers", so there's not much to gain from them, but one of them has a name, so the player knows he's useful to progress in the story. These items are used to progress, others are just junk, decoration and so on. Usually the main character makes clear quickly what they are. You know you can look at them but never use them. I hate when a game shits on this and abuses well etablished ways for orientation as some kind of puzzle.

Lots of the stuff in the inventory looks like the weird crap it is, how do I know how I am supposed to use it? So I just try everything with everything until something works, and if nothing does, I just try everything in my inventory on everything in the outside world, which sometimes is a problem because the developers thought it's fun to search for hot spots.

Usually adventure games have a button to reveal them, not here though. I don't like pixelhunting at all, and I think old games, especially adventures, were mostly way too cryptic and way too complicated. I don't even call it hard, for me it's simply bad game design when you are clueless of what to do next once again. I wouldn't use bad game design as example of how to make a game unnecessarily complicated.

Usually in games you can figure out by some logical thinking - where do I go from here? What can I try? What item could go with which item? What am I doing AT ALL and WHY? Why am I accessing a giant robot again? Why like this? Why do I have to access a bomb again that also is a religious shrine somehow AND a powercore? Why again do I have to attach graphite to a cat with granny's panty hose to blow up a mailbox?? 

It doesn't have to be this way. I've played games where every next step makes sense through the WHOLE GAME and not only a few parts. It's not that the puzzles in Primordia are super hard to solve, it's just an overload of stuff. Especially of numbers. I think using plenty of numbers/codes is the lame way to create difficulty. Add some annoying minigames, like power cord connection and machine assembling. Ugh. Hand me the walkthrough! 


Despite that, the game has great atmosphere, really good voice acting, I like the humor and sound design, and I'd still recommend it.

25915583.review:
When I saw this game, it has some interesting feels on it and when I found out it is like those old school point and click games, I ecided to get this one since I didn't play one of those for long time, most were some kids game or other, but this one has nice apocalyptic mood on it and I love it's visual style.

The controls are simple, just point and click, getting into inventory is simple as moving my mouse up to see it and if I ever feel lost what to do next, I just need to ask someone what they would do.

This game also feature the multiple endings, but I don't know yet how much there is since I did play for couple of hours.

If my review is pretty confusing, I don't blame you.
When I review MY reviews, I'm thinking myself: "What was I talking about"
So I put some pros, neutrals and cons with reasons on this game.

PROS
+ Art style
It has nice pixel art style like those old school point and click games and I like the designs of the characters and others

+ Voice acting
Like any other point and click games (or any games) they have voice acting and they sound pretty good or even well done in my opinion, especially Crispin being sarcastic and mostly paranoid about like giant cannibal robot.

+ Good sidekick
Like I said about Crispin, I like his charming punchlines and sarcastic nature.
He also is reliable on certain area where you need get something or get somewhere, he even give some ideas what to do next

+ Puzzles
Who doesn't like puzzles, not you?
Then why did you pick this game, if you don't like puzzles?
Anyway, this game mostly puzzle on certain parts where you have to either combine, poke with it, ask or anything else and this game is not like you can get stuck forever, you just need to think about what would you do or first gather info and then figure it out or ask Crispin what would he do on that, not like he straightforward tells you, but suggest something.

+Robots
It's about robots

NEUTRALS
= Story
This game has that simple story, I wont spoil anything else, but the beginning, you are Horatio who is trying to rebuild the crashed ship to fly with it, but then some big unknown floating robot comes to ship, shoots you and steal your power core, after that you woke up and decided to do something about it.
Welp, I'm not usually care about the story, but it is huge part of this game, but I don't usually follow it or even "know" does story make good sense, so that's why I put it as neutral because... I'm terrible to review the story part.

= glitchs and bugs
there are some minor bugs and glitch on this game, but it's not severe or annoying, it's just there and it wont stop you to continue to play this game, just some quick freezing that you almost don't notice all the time and other rare glitches.

CONS
- Games length
I do admit, it does make the game longer since you have to figure out the puzzles, but when you finish the game on first time, you just know almost all of it and you can just blow this game maybe almost under of hour, unless you think there is still something missing in it.

CONCLUSION
I really like this game, too bad it is short, but it did took me over 5 hour to pass it first time and it is pretty addicting since I did played nonstop from 22:00 PM to 4:30 AM.
It has only one cons in my opinion and that is not even a huge problem and I think this game pretty great since art style is beautiful and progression interesting on it.

In other words, this game is worth for your attention if you like point and click games.

Welp, that's all for now.

Doktor Greenman, logging out.

25912872.review:
I'm a little late on this one but I just felt the need to leave a review on it.

I grew up playing point&click adventure games, and I played pretty much all of the 90's classics, so unfortunatly nowadays it can be quite hard for me to find a game that keeps up with the expectations I have for this kind of games but I can tell you that Primordia is on par with the best games of this genre. 
It's a blast of joy and nostalgia to play a title like this that makes me feel like a kid again exploring a new awesome unknown world.

Primordia has a Beneath a Steel Sky vibe to it that instantly got me hooked, but even if you didn't play any of the older point&click titles Primordia would be a great place to start because it's so damn charming!

The story of the game is engaging and well-written, the soundtrack and voice-acting is great, the characters are memorable and make you feel attached to them.
The game puzzles are not too hard but they offer a good challenge, although this may vary from person to person depending on the experience you have with this genre.

The only downside I can think of is that the game is a bit short but the multiple endings and achievements give Primordia a good degree of replayabilty that other games lack.

This game is a MUST-PLAY, and I just want to thank Wormwood Studios and Wadjet Eye Games for this amazing experience.

25906652.review:
This game was surprisingly amazing. Not only does it look and work like a great 90's point and click game like Full Throttle, it actually FEELS like one. While playing it I constantly forgot that it wasn't a classic game from decades ago. The art, story, characters, dialogues and puzzles are all fantastic. The past years I haven't had much patience for these kinds of games (even though I used to love them) mostly because I can rarely get engaged enough with the story and characters to keep playing and paying attention to long conversations. In Primordia every single piece of dialogue is very interesting and mysterious, revealing more about the world and its history, or it's just plain witty and funny. The puzzles are great too, very intuitive most of the time. The hint system is pretty good too, not breaking immersion and sometimes just the right push in the right direction. I used hints a few times and rarely felt like I was cheating, so that's pretty great.

TL;DR - Primorida is an amazing game, but <SystemUser> is welcome to select their own terminology.

25880423.review: If you took a little from Grim Fandango, Fallout 2, and Planescape: Torment, melted them down till they were completely mixed together and poured that into a retro-style pixel-art adventure game, you would have something close to Primordia. I was really glad to discover this game, even though it took me years past its release. The setting is intriguing, the characters well defined, the music and voice acting impressive, and the visual art style really holds up in that retro way. If I had to find something to critique it would simply be that I wish there was more of Primordia to explore.

25878830.review:
​Primordia é um jogo de point-and-click no estilo bem das antigas mesmo, feito na saudosa engine Adventure Game Studio e é altamente reminiscente dos jogos clássicos da Lucas Arts. A temática do jogo é pós-apocalíptica, toda a humanidade foi exterminada da face da terra e tudo o que sobrou foram os robôs que os seres humanos construíram, e também os robôs que foram construídos por outros robôs. Os próprios robôs são a única força na terra que os mantém sobre operação, eles se auto reparam e até constroem outros robôs a partir de partes de coletadas dos escombros e lixo do mundo. Como o menos complexo e menos avançado não pode gerar o mais complexo e  mais avançado, isso gera uma cadeia de degeneração em que os robôs vão ficando mais decrépitos e desgastados com cada geração conforme eles próprios caminham, lentamente, para serem também finalmente apagados da existência junto de seus criadores humanos.

Você experiencia a estória através dos olhos de (Ou o termo correto seriam receptores oculares?) Horatio Nullbuilt, um robô eremita que habita uma aeronave destruída no meio do deserto. O objetivo de Horatio é restaurar sua nave, ele tem o sonho de voar, mas o núcleo de força da nave é roubado de Horatio por um robô coletador; Scrapper. Nisso Horatio é forçado a perseguir esse inimigo para tentar recuperar seu núcleo de força, vital para tanto o funcionamento da nave como para o abastecimento de energia do próprio Horatio, sem o núcleo Horatio pararia de funcionar.

O jogo tem um ambiente pesado e triste, a arte do jogo tem uma qualidade muito alta; os personagens e o plano de fundo dos ambientes são todos muito bem desenhados, o jogo tem toda uma estética bem original e muito bonita. Toda essa qualidade nas ilustrações do jogo reforçam a atmosfera sólida de tristeza e desolação que o jogo exala.

Essa qualidade estética do jogo sofre, todavia, não por erros do desenhista das sprites e background arts; mas sim por limites relacionados a engine do jogo. Como eu mencionei, Primordia foi feito na Adventure Game Studio e essa engine é muito antiga e tem limitações muito extremas para os padrões atuais, a mais gritante delas sendo a resolução de tela muito baixa. Durante as cutscenes em que o foco se aproxima mais do personagens é possível ver claramente como a qualidade da arte do jogo é muito maior do que a baixa resolução nativa nos permite enxergar.

Apesar da premissa deprimente de Primordia, o tom geral dele é muito menos "pra baixo" do que ele poderia ter sido. Há também muitos momentos cômicos entrelaçados na história graças aos diálogos entre o personagem principal, Horatio, e o seu fiel companheiro que ele próprio construiu; Crispin. Enquanto Horatio faz o papel do personagem mais sério, Crispin é o personagem mais engraçado que faz varios comentários engraçados sobre os eventos e outros personagens os quais os nossos heróis encontram durante sua aventura. Esse tom de comédia ajuda muito a aliviar o peso da premissa do jogo, tanto para o bem e para mal que isso implica.

Os personagens do jogo são todos eles muito interessantes e bem escritos. Crispin, por exemplo, recebe através do arco de sua história majoritariamente marcada por momentos engraçados um desenvolvimento surpreendentemente sério e heroico no final. A própria antagonista do jogo é um personagem bem equilibrado no sentido de que, apesar de suas ações parecerem malévolas a primeira vista, ela tem razões lógicas e razoáveis para agir da forma que age e faz vários argumentos até bem fundados.

Existem muitos outros personagens únicos e memoráveis no jogo também, mas o que pessoalmente mais me cativou foi um que participou muito pouco da história, o apropriadamente nomeado; Sad Robot. Ele é um robô de programação aparentemente corrompida, ou extremamente simplória, que espera solitário e paciente por algo que nunca vai acontecer e é impossível fazer ele perceber e entender isto. Achei ele algo metafórico da condição humana.

De fato os personagens que povoam o mundo do jogo brilham tanto que ofuscam o personagem principal. O Horatio, personagem principal, em si pode até não ser o personagem mais interessante da trama, mas enquanto protagonista; enquanto herói, aí sim ele pode ser também visto sobre angulos interessantes quando comparado com os heróis de outros vídeo games. Horatio é quase um anti-herói, ele não está afim de aventura, ele não quer salvar o mundo, ele não usa da força bruta e nunca parte pra briga, ele não tem interesse em matar nenhum vilão; ele é simplesmente alguém que quer sobreviver e restaurar a sua aeronave, para completar ambos esses objetivos ele precisa resgatar um item que lhe foi roubado.

A estória do jogo é definitivamente o ponto mais forte, ela é marcada por personagens carismáticos e únicos. A atmosfera do jogo é segurada bem firmemente pela alta qualidade da música e da arte visual e do voice acting, e o conjunto desses elementos é algo que fortalece ainda mais o efeito de uma estória que por si só já é interessante e bem escrita. Analisando ela do começo ao fim é possível ver como ela foi bem pensada e também bem realizada, os eventos são amarrados de maneira muito boa através da trama, coisas que os personagens dizem no começo da aventura se tornam muito mais significantes à luz dos eventos no final do jogo. Os monólogos que os personagens lançam nos vários finais possíveis são altamente reflexivos e bem escritos e refletem bem a perspetiva dos personagens através dos eventos que se passaram. Se trata obviamente de uma estória que foi escrita com muito amor e esmero.

Os únicos pontos verdadeiramente negativos que eu tenho contra o game estão contidos no seu gameplay: Até os melhores games point-and-click sempre tem esse ou aquele quebra-cabeça que não faz sentido absolutamente nenhum, geralmente resultado de o jogador ter que usar de uma solução que requer uma lógica totalmente absurda que só fez sentido na cabeça do designer. É nesse quebra-cabeça maldito em que você vai agarrar e não conseguir progredir mais na história sem consultar um 'walkthrough' na internet. Quando você tem que fazer isso, você inevitavelmente se sente menos investido no gameplay do jogo. O Primordia em si faz até um bom trabalho em impedir que o jogador tenha que consultar a internet para se desagarrar de um puzzle, faz isso usando um sistema de dicas atrelado ao seu parceiro Crispin. Todavia, houve um puzzle relacionado a um terminal em que eu simplesmente não vi lógica absolutamente nenhuma e a dica que o Crispin deu em relação a ele foi praticamente inútil, mesmo depois de ter olhado a solução na internet eu ainda fiquei sem ver como é que o designer do puzzle esperava que eu fosse adivinhar a solução.

Primordia definitivamente tem a minha recomendação, se trata de um clássico moderno dos point-and-click, mas o que mais brilha nele não é qualquer coisa inerente ao gênero point-and-click ou mesmo aos video games, o que brilha nele é o seu enredo; ele conta uma história que seria adorável em qualquer meio. É um jogo que "passa por baixo do radar", não recebe o reconhecimento e atenção que realmente merece, mas os poucos que conhecem ele sabem que se trata de uma obra-prima, um cult-classic (não é atoa que o mesmo está entre os 100 jogos mais bem avaliados da Steam). Primordia, apesar de não ser tão conhecido hoje, sem dúvida será vindicado pela história. Daqui a vinte anos muitos poucos se lembrarão dos jogos de grandes títulos que hoje muito vendem tais como Halo ou Gears of War, mas quem jogou Primordia, dele se lembrará.

25871501.review:
Wormwood Studios made their introduction onto Steam a memorable one with Primordia, a post-apocalyptic sci-fi point and click title. You will guide Horatio Nullbuilt through the futuristic, rusty dystopian wasteland known as Primordia. Horatio, and his floating comic-relief sidekick Crispin, need to get their stolen power core back; either that, or face death when their charges run dry and they shut down. They soon find out that getting their power core back is the least of their worries, as there's an entire city known as Metropol that's run by a corrupted master computer.

As you wander the lonely, desolate landscape of Primordia, you will come across many robots to interact with. Some of them are self-aware, some of them utter their pre-programmed responses, some will become friends, and some will be enemies. Man has ceased to exist for many years, though the exact timeframe is undetermined, but long enough for them to have vanished into legend. Horatio is a believer in Humanism, a religion that sees man as god; he even carries his copy of the Gospel of Man with him. The story is absolutely stunning, and the same can be said for the dialogue; I will forego delving any further into either so that you may truly enjoy the experience for yourself.

This is another point and click title that is obscure in its puzzle solving. There are many times that you will need an item which is hidden in a place that you'd never think to look. For people like me that completely suck with even the simple point and clicks, a guide will absolutely be necessary. However, for more advanced enthusiasts of the genre, you're in for a real challenge and treat. Every puzzle is a "think outside the box" type, and very few are expected or familiar. Even a large portion of the achievements are enigmatic. With a guide, you're looking at about 5-6 hours of playtime, without one you'll easily approach 10 hours.

The artwork of Primordia is done in a monochromatic rusty theme, for the most part consisting of dark browns and dirty oranges. There are subtle glimpses of neon reds and blues, and some places that are steel grey, but they're few and far between. The art does a fantastic job in bringing out the feeling that everything is coated in thick layers of rust, dirt, and sand, and that humans have been dead for centuries. Likewise, the pockmarks on Horatio and many other characters and places conveys the likelihood of near-constant acid rain. The melancholic, dismal, void-of-life atmosphere of the title is both exceedingly strong and somehow calming. The soundtrack is comprised of ambient, semi-industrial tracks that compliment the art wonderfully.

If you've been holding off on grabbing Primordia, stop waiting and just go for it. You simply cannot rob yourself of a detailed, highly immersive experience such as this one. Truly one of the greatest point and click adventure games of the modern era, Primordia is the complete package; visuals, audio, enjoyable characters, story, dialogue, and challenging gameplay. Even though it's a steal at $10.99 CAD, you can also find it on sale for $2.19 CAD at times, either one is a huge bargain.

25488368.review:
This game is inspired.  If you like realistic sci-fi stories then buy this.  Primordia is thought-provoking and engrossing from start to finish.  So few games can build up hype and then exceed your expectations, but for me Primordia did.  This game starts with great art and characters, then weaves a deep world full of inspired lore, and closes with some encounters that left me marveling at the game's writing.  Without spoiling anything, I was not expecting the dialogue in the antagonist encounter to be that effective and it completely caught me off-guard.

My only complaint is that there were one or two places where click-able objects weren't clear enough.  The actual puzzles all make sense and they range from simple crafting to serious lateral thinking.  Also I suppose the game would have benefitted from a few additional animations for some of the weightier plot moments, but that's forgiveable.

Can't recommend this game enough.

25262646.review:
If story is more important for you in a game than mechanics or visuals than you will enjoy Primordia as it is a decently written story.

> Great game lore / interesting setting
> Great plot and semi twist if you don't see it coming, I enjoyed the little seeds throughout the game like the ship being named "UNIIC" [SPOiLER] (VGER anyone?).
If the writer reads this not that I minded the ending but I think the twist would have had even more punch if Horus had followed through with his mission instead of Metromind carrying it out, big bad being the big bad is not as fun of a twist as the good guy was the bad guy. Would have made the final choice more interesting and a more interesting realization for the player "I'm a humanist trying to save humanity but I killed them?", my two cents as a wannabe writer, was still good though
[/Spoiler]
> Main character deals with interesting themes, and can choose different paths, "Progress needs transformation needs art needs freedom" reminded me of 'what can change the nature of a man' from Planescape: Torment... was interesting to think about it, as were the logical arguments of the robots
> Sidekick character is more funny and likeable than most comedic relief companion characters, reminded me a lot of Morte from Planescape:Torment while still being unique and memorable as his own character [Spoiler] I felt a great deal of loss after he died, almost found myself getting angry like the main character and strongly felt his absense in the scenes following his death, great immersion!
[/spoiler]

Mild Cons:
> Puzzles were okay, not overly hard or easy. I enjoyed the logic puzzles more so than go search a map for random item (I could see others minding those quests less), the wingman quest though had me chuckle
> Game is short, 9 hrs for me with frequent pauses leaving the game running while I took breaks
> Graphics are reto pixels but not bad if you zoom out, took my eyes a bit to adjust in the beginning

For me money well spent, memorable story.

25251418.review:
"Until we realize that things might not be we cannot realize that things are" a great poet once said.

I have to admit that I didn't fully enjoy Primordia on my recently finished first playthrough (there will be more) - it started excellent so the further into the story I got, the more I was waiting for it to disappoint me. But it didn't. 

It's somewhat ironic, that game so "retro" - from it's visual form, through mechanics, to themes - feels so fresh. After playing so many contemporary adventure and semi-adventure games it's nice to see that there are people who don't see stories just as shiny boxes filled with emotions. Instead of killing some characters who got a lot of screen time to make viewer shed a tear and considering job well done, Primordia focuses on building an atmosphere, allowing emotions to occur naturally, and, what is recently rare in storytelling, tells a story. Rather than having a bunch of characters hoping from place to place pushed by expendable plot, the game has a topic which it wills to explore.

I might say, that Primordia is philosophical, that it's meditating upon metaphysical themes, but we may not quite understand each other, since the meaning of word "philosophical" has devalued. The game isn't trying to make some "social commentary" or present a political concept, but it asks fundamental questions, questions that, one may say, are ancient. But, as a (great) poet once said, only weighty ideals live long enough to be called ancient.

Every element of Primoridia harmonizes with each other. Unique and rich world isn't original only for originality's sake - a wasteland world where robot's seek their raison d'être, a city ideologically based on vague and hollow Progress, a court where the judge has two advisers - justice and mercy, the Gospel of Man which was given to robots by their creators... Primordia becomes more like a biblical parable than a typical belletristic story.

The meaning of life, the wonder of existence, presence of evil in the world, relationship between creation and creator, between robots and man, between man and God - Primordia not only mentions these themes, but also discusses them. It reminds us why people used to tell each other stories. It was because they had something to say.

25194710.review:
This was an interesting game. Don't be fooled by the endings you think you see. Somehow, I managed to mess up the game so badly that I only got sad endings. These are the endings that no one talks about. The endings where the main character's friends are all dead, and he goes back to his ship, and reprograms himself to forget about what happened at the city. The ending when he has nothing left to live for.
Yet, I have seen other playthroughs where he manages to save his friends, and the ending is full of hope. It all depends on you. Will you save your friends? Will you join the AI who ruined your life? It is all your choice.
and in the end, what does it mean to be human?

25159872.review:
[h1]Dystopia wśród Point 'n Click[/h1]

"Klikane" przygodówki kojarzyły mi się zazwyczaj z kolorową oprawą i wesołą historyjką. Wyjątkowość Primordii wynika z bycia przeciwieństwem takich gier. Na ekranie dominują odcienie brązu i szarości, a historia oraz soundtracki przygnębiają zamiast uprzyjemniać nam pobyt w świecie gry. Czy warto zainwetsować 40 złotych w tytuł, który ma predyspozycje do wywołania u odbiorcy depresji?


[h1]"Man built us to build"[/h1]

Wormwood Studios wykreowało bardzo interesującą wizję przyszłości, o ile inne tytuły wykorzystują postapokaliptyczne światy do zaprezentowania ludzi walczących o przetrwanie w niekorzystnych warunkach, tutaj na świecie ludzie już dawno wymarli. Pozostały jedynie roboty, którym nie przeszkadza zatrute powietrze, brak żywych organizmów (no, może poza "nieśmiertelnymi" karaluchami) czy kwaśne, radioaktywne deszcze. Roboty te tworzą swego rodzaju społeczeństwo, budują nowe roboty, wykonują funkcje takie jak
sprzedawanie dóbr, pozyskiwanie energii lub wydawanie osądów. Niektóre z nich nawet wierzą w Ludzi, nazywając ich swoimi bogami lub perfekcyjnymi maszynami, które rozpoczęły Primordium budując pierwszego robota na swoje podobieństwo. Inne natomiast, uważają Ludzi za mit wymyślony specjalnie po to, aby uzasadnić to, że Postęp miał kiedyś swój początek. Jednak nasza przygoda nie zaczyna się w centrum tego wszystkiego, a na odludziu (odrobociu?), na pustyni gdzie nasz protagonista próbuje poskładać swój statek do kupy.


[h1]Horatio Nullbuilt, version 5[/h1]

Początek naszej podróży ma miejsce na wraku statku UNIIC, którego to właśnie sterowany przez nas bohater próbuje naprawić. Bohaterem tym jest Horatio, zakapturzony robot wyglądający jak pustelnik. W naszych zmaganiach pomagam nam Crispin, mały inteligentny robocik, skonstruowany przez Horatio. Nie posiada kończyn, ale potrafi lewitować, dzięki czemu pomaga nam, gdy trzeba zajrzeć do trudnodostępnego miejsca. Potrafi także szyderczo dogadywać bohaterowi, co dodaje walorów humorystycznych dialogom pomiędzy nimi dwoma. W grze zagadki są dość wymagające, jednak Crispin podpowiada nam od czasu do czasu, gdy mamy jakiś duży problem z odnalezieniem odpowiedzi. Kontakt z rozumnymi formami nie ogranicza się jedynie do Horatio i jego małego kompana, na naszej drodze spotykamy różne inne roboty, każde z wyjątkowymi, zapadającymi w pamięć osobowościami. To wszystko sprawia, że łatwo jest się wczuć w klimat i bogactwo świata Primordii.


[h1]Warto![/h1]

A rzeczywiście jest się w co wczuwać, tajemniczo mroczna, wywołująca trwogę muzyka, tła, które są piękne na swój obrzydliwy i przytłaczający sposób, zagadki, których rozwiązanie daje poczucie satysfakcji oraz historia, która pokazuje nam inną perspektywę, o której nigdy byśmy nie pomyśleli. Gra posiada kilka zakończeń, każde z nich daje powód do rozmyślań i refleksji. Jeżeli umiecie dobrze język angielski, lubicie klimaty sci-fi, nie przeszkadza wam nieprzyjemna atmosfera i lubicie zadawać sobie filozoficzne pytania - to jest tytuł w sam raz dla was.


[h1]"Yea, though memory be fleeting, faith endureth."[/h1]

25141321.review:
After a total 11 hours of playing, I've finished Primordia. As a point-and-click the gameplay is mainly based on puzzles and some basic crafting, but its steampunk atmosphere, its hughely charismatic characters and its deep and thought-provoking messages are the strongest part in the game.

In general, Primordia creates a powerful discourse about justice, law, charity, industry and energy, community and knowledge, energy and history. Most importantly, about logic and free will. As a player, you are brought to wander in an environment that is partially an echo of men's life, partially an odd representation of robotic life, where to the decay of humanity is counterposed the need for energy of the last city on earth. Every knowledge is lost in the dust, and Metropol, the city where the two protagonists will find themselves in, is a ghost city whose only side still provided with energy is a long road. 

I will be haunted by its finale for a while, also because of its powerful credit OST. It leaves its scars, but worth, worth playing.

I love the writing, atmosphere, characters, and soundtrack of Primordia. It's a sort of post-apocalyptic dystopian future in which "Man" went extinct in the distant past and robots are all that is left on planet Earth. I liked that a lot of the story went unspoken and has to be pieced together as you play the game, and I find it funny that I have come up with my depiction of the "unspoken" backstory in my own mind. I also thought the voice actor for Horatio was excellent.

That being said, the movement is a bit clunky (even considering that it is a 2.5D retro game) and I wish there were more areas to explore. Also, the game being pixellated did not add much to the experience. I often wonder what the game would look like with hand-drawn sprites instead of pixel sprites (probably much cooler).

Overall, I would recommend Primordia if you have the patience for a point-and-click RPG.

The world and characters are expertly crafted and for once it seems the game doesn't treat you like an idiot. What I mean by that is holding your hand throughout the game and telling you what to do. You figure it out, however long that takes and I have to say that it makes the game much more rewarding. Many points allow you different ways of continuing on that have different impacts. 24665736.review:
Primordia is a cyberpunk game about faith. Much like in the movie Tron, the main character is a robot with a mission he forgot. A mission given by his own creator, Man.

Primordia is a point-and-click adventure game by Wormwood Studios. The main character is a robot with amnesia, but made for a very significant purpose. It is still his choice to fulfill this purpose. He can be a faithful warrior that defeats the evil progressive mind and unites the robots, or he can run away from it. In the game, the robots live under a totalitarian secularist regime, where the belief that the machines were created by a mysterious being called Man is forbidden. His faith in Man keeps the protagonist alive. It is a very interesting twist for the cyberpunk genre.

The graphics are beautiful, as well as the soundtrack. The voice acting is complete and very well done. The voice of Crispin is the best. The dialogues are funny and the developers opted for a more dynamic gameplay, allowing the player to engage in the story without huge dialogues.

One of the advantages is a map that saves the player a good time that would be wasted wandering around. Another advantage is the "automatic notes", which saves you the trouble of writing down important information. There are several ways to solve the puzzles, and the developers sought to avoid puzzles that are incoherent with the setting. There is a great internal system for tips, preventing players from getting stuck.

If you like games like Beneath a Steel Sky, or games that allow you to immerse in an engaging and deep atmosphere with unique and intriguing stories, you should give a chance to Primordia.

Positive points
* Amazing setting.
* Good writing and voice-acting.

Negative points
* The engine is limited.

Likewise, every piece of information gathered through dialogue and observation has a purpose. This game isn't just "put this on that and see if it works" and it never hands you the answers unless you ask (Crispin acts as an in-game hint giver), and even then, solutions are never simply GIVEN. Ok I just finished this and first: this game was horribly crashing until I recently updated it, though unfortunately, I was already at the end of the game.

The story is kind of...sad. Beautiful. The puzzles interesting and fun. I liked Technobabylon more though. Those fucking crashes ruined it for me to an extent...

The end was just...hm. I miss the feeling of a final closure to the beautiful story. I revolted against MetroMind to the very end but the story ending was like....like the authors wished to finish the game early and stopped caring about the script. 

I sensed considerable laziness from the developers in the game, here and there, mainly in the story development. Not in the puzzles though, some of them were sure tough to solve - the kiosk was the worst hurdle and figuring out some codes literally hurt my head. 

Also, the puzzle where you need to answer two robots in answering three questions is broken...in the second question only though. You are asked which of selected statements MUST be true but all of the statements DO NOT NEED TO BE true so I had to find the answer online.

Also, I'm not a good puzzle solver.

All in all...this game DEFINITELY needs more story into it. And the story parts of "Humans destroyed themselves"? Cmon...that's lame. Human destroyed themselves / robots destroyed humans / wars between robots and humans....it's just not original. I mean: the Gospel of man, that is so beautifully written, I swear I read it many times. That is poetic. That was ART!! So was the philosophical laments of the MEMORIUS in the Kiosk. And Crispin! The Dunes! The Goliath!! All beautiful and very original, at least to me. 

Honestly, reading the gospel of man at the start of the game hyped me incredibly. I expected that the game was going to be preseting very hard, unsettling, maybe existential questions in its story. Conflict of religious beliefs among postapocalyptic robots? With philosophical insights and two-sided arguments I can relate to? 
I dig that. 
After reading the gospel of man at the start of the game, I realized that not only the author means the story, he is actually capable of meaning it! But...the story does not really go fully in this direction and remains a "beautiful adventure game" with a great story plot. At the start, I thought "this is going to be a masterpiece" but it was not. To be a masterpiece, it needs even more human soul given to it.

Simplemente precioso, 9.5/10.

Primordia es un juego que consigue mezclar aventura, puzzles, distopia, e incluso humor, de una forma que jamás había visto. El juego en sí mismo contiene cierta carga de tristeza pues prácticamente todo está destruido/decrépito, pero, incluso siendo un juego basado en pixel-art, consigue maravillarte con todos los niveles. Todo tiene un contexto y está bien construido, la historia está magistralmente desarrollada y no tiene agujeros, además de contar con varios finales. Además, este juego pondrá a prueba tu ética en ciertas partes.

La música, aunque no es lo que más destaca, ciertamente encaja a la perfección y más de una vez querrás quedarte en una zona para escucharla.

Lo único que puede tirar a alguien hacia atrás es la jugabilidad, en ocasiones puede resultar algo frustrante pues el personaje no se mueve muy rápido, y el sistema para usar objetos es un tanto rudimentario.

Otro apartado notable es la dificultad, a la cual le pongo muy alta. No en el sentido de que puedas morir, pues es imposible, si no que los rompecabezas que se nos presentan suelen ser verdaderos rompecabezas, y puedes pasarte mucho tiempo intentando resolver algo. Es más, da igual el orden en el que consigas objetos: no te olvides de uno solo, porque habrá cosas que las usarás todo el juego.

Aquí acaba mi análisis. Aunque es una historia completamente lineal en la que no tienes casi nada de libertad para desarrollar la historia de diferentes formas, es ciertamente una grandísima experiencia que recomendaría a cualquiera que disfrute de una buena historia.

24453131.review:
I held of on buying this game for a very long time due to how minimal it seemed, but after playing it I wished I hadn't done so.  This game is as close to flawless as an adventure game can ever be.  It has the best writing and the best soundtrack of any video game I've played and has a surprisingly deep setting and lore to it, which is impressive considering the small size of the game world.  With just a few locations, it creates a realistic world that had me immersed for hours.

The story and atmosphere of the game did a remarkable job of drawing me in and building tension, but where I believe the game stands out the most is in its setting.  The game takes place in a future in which life has long been extinct and Man has become a mythical deity worshipped by the remaining robots that now wander the lifeless desert that covers the earth, or even dismissed altogether as nothing more than legend.  Glass and light have become precious resources and what little remains of human invention is constantly scrapped to build new robots.  This is the kind of creativity that is lacking in most adventure games, and the subtlety with which it was presented was refreshing.

It was surprising to see a post-apocalyptic setting in which humans take only a background role and the nature of the world before is long forgotten.  Rather than barrage the player with the history of the world, Primordia puts the story and gameplay first while allowing players to discover the lore on their own, avoiding many (though not quite all) of the tropes that plague post-apocalyptic, dystopian, and robotic science fiction settings.

The game takes itself seriously and the comic relief exists for the amusement of the characters rather than that of the player, which is a skillful way of keeping the story believable, though Crispin's lines did make me cringe in more than a few points.  The primary cause of the chaotic dystopia is the degradation and corruption of the robots' programming, which becomes increasingly apparent as more of them are encountered.  All of the robots from the days of the humans are dead, insane, or rebuilt to the point of having no memories of the previous era, and the world inhabited by the rusting automotons that remain of civilization is chaotic, unpredictable, and bleak.  The dramatic irony of many characters' situations as well as the limited color palette contribute a depressing and hopeless tone that makes this an especially memorable experience.

Primordia is an essential contribution to the adventure genre of computer games, and one that I will gladly recommend to anyone who has an interest in interactive stories.  If you are considering getting Primordia, then please do yourself a favor and don't make the mistake I made of waiting for several years before buying it.

24420313.review:
Great art, engaging story. However, the game has a critical flaw that permeates the entire experience: discovering how to progress is less an exercise in logic and more an exercise in clicking and walking the world. Many of the components of each puzzle are only tangentially related, oftentimes only in the most esoteric ways. Progression is further  hindered by the game's lack of robust programming. Sometimes you will try something that should work, only to find out that you were supposed to perform that action through slightly different mechanisms. 

The game also does not handle choices well. Now, there aren't many story-altering choices to make in this game, but the creators should have given the player more indications of what the effects of their actions would be, as well as more indication that certain paths could have been taken. I felt cheated out of the ending I would have chosen because of the problem I mentioned above. I clicked on something, nothing happened, and I went on my way, not realizing that I could have performed the intended action. This changed the ultimate ending.

Still very much recommended, but don't be ashamed to open up a guidebook if you get stuck.

Edit: Also, the save system was bad. They could have easily done it better.

23812190.review:
[h1] Независимость есть свобода: союзничество - рабство! [/h1]
Primordia — это приключенческая point-and-click игра, разработанная Wormwood Studios и изданная Wadjet Eye Games. С момента выхода игра уже была переведена фанатскими сообществами с английского на многие другие языки, среди которых: русский, французский, португальский и польский.
И так я провел достаточно часов в этой игре,чтобы написать обзор об этой игре.
Такие игры в жанре Point and click,обычно заводят в заблуждение как это было в то время когда мы покупали ещё диски.
Эта же игра завела меня в заблуждение и в раздумие,кто бы мог подумать что 16-ти значный код будет настолько сложно сложить?...
Робооты созданы людьми,казалось бы это лишь искуственный интеллект который не может мыслить и запрограммирован для выполнения как либо функции или функций,а ведь в этой игре совсем наоборот,в одно время эта игра схожа даже с нашем миром! Ведь если рассмотреть версии то прогресс человека в технологиях вырос до такой степени,что после того даже когда все живые организмы практически умерли на нашей планете,роботы же которые были запрограммированы с целью мыслить начали выживать,строить себе убежища,искать энергию,создавать себе подобных,хранить историю о человеке,что много десятков\сотен\тысяч лет назад был высший разум - человек,а просто говоря роботы начали развиваться,мы верили в бога - они верят в нас как в богов
В определенные моменты важно вспомнить о том что человека в этой игре - нету,так как существуют в игре сцены пожалуй в которых можно подумать что главный герой Горацио - человек (Horatio)
А теперь перейдем к плюсам и минусам
+На корабле Unniic можно найти монограф на котором довольно таки приятная музыка
+Сохранения,давно не видел что можно сохраняться  практически на любом моменте :)
+Диалоги
+Сюжет
+Атмосфера
+Сюжет
+Головоломки и это ещё мягко сказано...Ах да если кому в конце нужен будет 16-ти значный код держите (Я незнаю зачем я сюда это кинул,но видимо я хотел показать как у меня болела голова от головоломок )

Часть Шпиля - 02 -675 -4024

+Концовки очень обрадовало то что в конце можно выбрать практически любую концовку главное осмотреться и понять,что к чему начиная с самого глупого что может быть и заканчивая героем\геройским поступком\разумным поступком
Минусы -
- Малая популярность,очень хотелось бы чтобы в Steam эту игру заметило больше людей так как игра сделана на шедевр,98% хороших отзывов вам не кажется что игр с 95-99% хорошими отзывами очень мало? Единственное что я могу сказать так это то что эта игра заслуживает продолжения,мне очень понравился сюжет и лично я буду ждать 2-ю часть этой превосходной игры,либо просто смирюсь)
- Русификатор 
Из-за него множество проблем во многих сценах,большего всего запомнилось то что считыватель память не мог соединить с базой данный или тот же чип который так же надо было вставить в базу данных,приходиться сохраняться,закрывать игру,включать winsetup.exe в папке Primordia,переключать на Game default,заходить в игру,загружать сохраненую игру,выполнить действие,просмотреть сцену на английском,сохраниться,выйти из игры,открыть папку,включить winsetup.exe,поставить Russian translation,закрыть и играть...
Ну а вообще игра превосходная порадовал особенно юмор в ней)

23742337.review:
Almost since the decline of professional adventure games, fans have been making their own games.  These have varied wildly in quality, but in more recent years indie studios such as Wadjet Eye Games have managed to churn out charming retro games with regularity.  They generally strike the right balance in difficulty, the hand-painted art is often beautiful, and the stories are often interesting.  These games are not for everyone, of course, as games of this sort may seem "dated" or slow to modern gamers

To me, Primordia exemplifies the best aspects of most retro adventure games, with wonderful graphics (again, in a low res way that some appreciate more than others) and classic point and click exploration.  Primordia, however, distances itself from its peers through superior story, characters, and story structure.  The basic premise is an interesting one, and game designer and writer Mark Yohalem develops that premise expertly and meticulously.  The world unfolds naturally as you join Horatio and Crispin on their adventure.  The themes are more complex and nuanced than what you will see in most games.  The puzzles feel true to the world rather than thrown in just because you have to have them.

This is, in my opinion, the best game published by Wadjet Eye, and one of the best adventure games in recent memory.  If you're interested in going out on a limb and try an adventure game, consider trying this one.  If you're already a fan of retro games or thoughtful sci-fi, this is a no-brainer.

It's like Beneath a Steel Sky, but with androids. It follows all the same beats. The hero and his tin can of a sidekick being attacked in the desert. A journey to the big city where things seem a bit off. And...well anything more than that would be spoilers.

23312584.review:
I bought this game for $2 or something when it was on sale a long time ago, and finally got around to playing it. 

First of all: I don't typically enjoy point-and-click games. I haven't played very many of them, and I usually get frustrated with the puzzles and either look up a guide (which kind of defeats the point) or quit. 

I LOVED Primordia. Maybe it scratched the right itch at the right time, but I enjoyed every second of this game. The puzzles are challenging, but not frustrating (the only times that I had to look something up were just because I didn't realize I could scroll down on my data pack, for example, or that I could interact with an object in a certain way. For everything else, Crispin's hints were more than enough). It's gorgeous and thought-provoking. The voice acting was excellent and really brought all of the characters to life. The world is endlessly interesting. Looking at the achievements after my first playthrough, it also seems that there is a great deal to discover that I missed my first time around, which is good, because in my desire to experience more of this world I will probably play through it at least one more time. 

A lot of reviews have commented on it feeling a bit short, and I'm tempted to agree. The second half of the game in particular feels a bit rushed, but it seems to have more to do with there being lots of questions to answer, and they all get answered in a shotgun blast at once that seems to detract from the feeling of discovery that permiates the rest of the game. However, if the only bad thing I have to say about a game is "I wanted more..." is it really a bad thing after all?

Primordia is very literary. It's a game about the preservation of individuality within an increasingly communist society. It's about one's "design," and whether or not it's possible to act against it. It's about friendship, religion, creation, preservation, degeneration, and hope.

Do yourself a favor and play this game.

23062525.review:
The war is lost, mankind is lost, everything is lost.
Alles was bleibt bist du, Horatio, ein Roboter der mit seinem Begleiter Crispin in der radioaktiven (Ich nehme mal an es gab da A-Waffen) Wüste lebt. Dummerweise stellt sich heraus, dass wir zwei nicht alleine sind und etwas haben das ein schwerbewaffneter Räuber will; Unsere Energiequellle.
Ohne diese sind wir jedoch dem Untergang geweiht. Also machen wir uns auf die Energiequelle wiederzubeschaffen. 
Was nun folgt sind 10 - 12 Stunden Adventuregaming mit gut durchdachten Rätseln, einer wunderbaren Geschichte und herrlichen Konversationen.
Über die Geschichte will ich nichts sagen, aber zum Spiel. Die Stimmung ist trotz des distopischen Settings nicht deprimierend, dies ist besonders Crispin geschuldet der mit seinen losen Mundwerk viel Heiterkeit verbreitet. Die Rätsel sind logisch und lassen sich mit ein wenig Hirnschmalz gut lösen. Steckt man dennoch mal fest steht einem Crispin mit Rat beiseite, wenn man ihn den fragt. Mit jedem Rätsel erschließt sich ein weiterer Teil der Geschichte und am Ende steht der große Showdown. Hier punktet Primordia mit einer Reihe alternativer Enden, für die zum Teil dann noch einmal einige Kleingkeiten zu kombinieren sind. 
Für mich war das Spiel ein absoluter Glückskauf und empfehle es jedem weiter und kann nur hoffen ihr habt mit dem Spiel so viel Freude wie ich.

Nur einen Nachteil hat das Spiel, es ist so b'soding kurz ;)

PS: Auch sehr nett sind die Eastereggs. Zum Beispiel finden sich im Spiel Anspielungen auf Fallout 1 & 2. Auch denke ich habe ich den Einfluss von Stephen King und seiner Sage vom dunklen Turm (sehr gute Reihe) deutlich im Spiel wiedergefunden :)

23052430.review: For a few hours this game took me someplace else. Thank you.

23041400.review:
I judge puzzle adventure games by a single rule:

Every puzzle in the game must be solvable within the game's own universe without requiring more than a grasp of English. No trips to Google to check bible passages or pop culture references.

And that's it. That's why Primordia's difficulty is well-earned and satisfying to figure out on your own. That's all I need to know about a point-n-click, and that's what you should need as well (but okay fine, the writing is also absolutely hilarious and full of personality).

23021789.review: Wonderful little game with a wonderful little sidekick. Real good atmosphere and cool artstyle.

22965603.review:
Un point'n'click avec une direction artistique proche des production Lucasarts à l'ancienne, j'ai voulu tenter le coup.

Au final c'est un produit correct, mais sans plus. Il manque une musique vraiment accrocheuse, celle proposée fait le boulot pour l'ambiance mais impossible de s'en souvenir.

L'histoire traite d'un futur lointain dans lequel la terre devenue vaste dépotoir, n'est plus foulée que par des robots d'origine diverses, pour qui l'être humain n'est qu'une espèce éteinte.

L'aventure est assez laborieuse et peu passionante, j'en ai peur. Le nombre de lieu visité est trop léger. L'empathie générée par les personnages ne suffit pas à s'intéresser à cet unviers qui pourtant sur le papier me tentait.

Le seul point positif de l'histoire est la multiplicité de fins. Mais après en avoir vu une, je n'ai aps spécialement eu envie de refaire l'histoire avec des choix différents.
En anglais seulement.

Conclusion : un point and click assez pauvre et décevant. Uniquement si vous êtes désespéré d'en faire de nouveaux.

22925826.review:
Интересная адвенчура, то ли странная, то ли «особенная». 

Многим (в том числе мне) очень понравилась демка: создана потрясающая атмосфера... которая в итоге оказывается лишь началом игры, а основное действие переносит нас в обитель грязно-коричневых оттенков и существенно более простых (за малым исключением) персонажей. Игра продолжается не так как вы ожидаете, и оканчивается совсем не там, где вы ожидаете, и уж точно не так, как вы ожидаете. Хорошо когда игры умеют удивлять, но будет ли удивление приятным — предсказать не берусь.

Разнообразие концовок выдает метания автора: с одной стороны он стремится завершить имеющуюся на руках историю, с другой - оставить мир открытым для продолжений. Его право, но к сожалению данное решение оставляет игроков с б0льшим количеством вопросов к сюжету, чем они хотели бы унести с собой.

Если вам нравятся хорошие истории, в особенности про роботов и пост-пост-апокалипсис, и вы не боитесь пиксель-хантинга среди грязно-коричневых урбанистических пейзажей — смело берите.
