22456856.review:
Das Leben kann unfair sein. Primordia wäre vor einigen Jahrzehnten wie eine Bombe eingeschlagen ... da bin ich mir sicher. Ich fantasiere und male mir aus, was passiert wäre, wenn Lucas Arts oder Sierra diesen Titel in den 80ern vom Stapel gelassen hätten. Ist es übertrieben, wenn ich behaupte, man würde Primordia dann heutzutage in einem Atemzug mit Monkey Island, Space / King's Quest, Indiana Jones und The Day Of The Tentacle nennen? Nicht unbedingt. Wir haben es hier mit einem unfassbar hochpolierten Point and Click Adventure zu tun; ein prachtvolles Gesamtkunstwerk mit dichtem, einzigartigen Setting, tollen Grafiken, einem einmaligen Soundtrack und zwei Haupprotagonisten, die regelrecht KULT schreien: Horatio Nullbuilt und sein treuer Schweberoboter Crispin dürften in jedem Retrogamer-Herz ihren Platz finden.

Das düstere Szenario und die beklemmende Atmosphäre ... die philosophischen Fragen, die das Spiel stellt ... Primordia füllt damit eine weitere Lücke im Adventure-Bereich und dürfte ohne Weiteres mit an der Spitze der Sci-Fi-Games dieses Genres stehen. Wer Lust auf einen "Blast from the (reconstructed) past" hat und geilen Retroscheiß mag, muss hier einfach die pizzaverklebten Nerdfinger ausfahren. Bedauerlich, dass solche Titel heutzutage nicht mehr Mainstream-tauglich sind und es kaum ein Schwein interessiert. Damals ... ja, damals ... wäre Primordia der Respekt gezollt worden, den es verdient. Ich frage mich, wo all die alten Hasen bloß hin sind, die damals Monkey Island und Co. abgefeiert haben!? Sind sie wirklich schon ausgestorben? 

Ja, das Leben kann unfair sein.

Mein Gott, ich höre mich an wie Marvin. 

PS: Einziges Manko ist für mich das Fehlen einer deutschen Fassung. Ich verstehe Englisch gut ... doch nicht perfekt. Dadurch werden die Rätsel nicht gerade leichter und ich musste oft in eine Komplettlösung schauen (Schande über mein Haupt!). Ich wusste, dass deswegen Probleme auf mich warten; den Titel musste ich als Adventure-Liebhaber trotzdem kaufen. Und das Gleiche sollten Ähnlichgesinnte ebenso tun! (hier bei Bedarf idiotischen Hashtag einfügen) SUPPORT PRIMORDIA - es ist der unbekannte Königssohn, der sich im Wald von Wurzeln und Würmern ernährt (daher heißen die Entwickler auch Wormwood) ... und der Pöbel vom Dorf hat keinen Schimmer, mit wem sie es zu tun haben. Sie ignorieren den Waldmensch, dabei fließt adeliges Blut in seinen Adern!

Ja, das Leben ist unfair.

22429965.review:
Had some problems with getting the mouse to function (at all) on my windows 10 rig but the Dev's are really nice and encouraging and was able to find a solution.  For anyone interested in order to get the game to run I simply had to alter the properties on Primordia.exe - under the compatibility tab tick the boxes 'reduced colour mode' (16bit), 'run in 640x480' and 'run as administrator'.  After doing that the game runs fine.

So the game itself

An old school style point and click adventure with some very interesting charcters, settings and concepts.  The dialogue is quite well written even if the jokes do on occasion fall a bit flat. Very much enjoyed my time exploring this little world and trying to figure out the puzzles.

Its only downfall in my opinion is that it seemed rather short - given the setting and the plot setup I was expecting more content but what is here is still very good.

8/10 - best of the genre I have played in a long time

22368616.review:
Primordia is a superb game. In the far future, Man is no more and is worshiped as an ancient god that was the perfect machine that built the first robots (in the era called primodium). These manbuilt robots built more robots and they are now the only sentience that populates the post-apocalyptic world. The robots believe that Man will return once more to start a second primordium. Meanwhile, they go about "maintaining" the world and preach the gospel of man. Horatio Nullbuilt and his levitating companion Crispin Horatiobuilt are two such robots that live out in the dunes, far away from the robot city of Metropol. When a giant robot with lasers "takes" their power core, they are forced on an adventure that takes them to Metropol and uncovers everything from Horatio's past to the fate of the last humans.

The music sets the tone perfectly for this world. What struck me most was the intricacy with which this world was constructed: every little trinket of knowledge about this universe fits so seamlessly with every other tidbit. So, the writers did a fantastic job and obviously put a lot of thought into their work. The visuals, music and puzzles served to elevate that writing. If you love atmosphere and storytelling or if you loved the blackwell series or if you just enjoy wadjeteye games, this is a title that must be experienced.

22362005.review:
I won't go into too much detail because I played this game years ago, but I recently saw it in my library and thought it deserved a review. There are few negative things to say so I'll start there.

[h1]CONS[/h1]
Starting with the only downsides I can think of, it was bothersome finding the right settings so the game would scale perfectly and look sharp on an HD display, but it worked fine once that was taken care of. 
Gameplay is somewhat akin to classic point and click with character displacement handled like any old 2D RPG, but it sometimes isn't clear which items are to be interacted with, or even whether it is possible. This was sometimes annoying but can be considered inherent to the game genre.
It's too short. Don't get me wrong, the length of the game is appropriate but the mood and story are so enticing by the end you'll definitely be left wanting more.

[h1]PROS[/h1]
The art. I'll come out with a bit of an unpopular opinion by saying gameplay is not a good reason to buy this game. Its geatest asset is without a question the art. Not only is the style 100% distinctive from anything I've seen before, the devs actually pulled it off perfectly. While it resembles moody postapocalyptic or cyberpunk art commonly seen in high-res online, the low pixel count makes it particularly impressive. Combining intricate convoluted shapes with pixel-art is just something I didn't think was possible until playing Primordia. The dark and brown color tones used and occasional neon accents really set the atmosphere as a surrealist cyberpunk universe. I can't stress enough there is nothing else like this.
On top of the visual aspects, the soundtrack is just great. Maybe I wouldn't listen to the ambient sounds on their own but they really do a great job of accenting both the story and environment.
Last comes the story. Oh boy. Not only was I surprised at every turn by a creative plot, but the character development is the cherry on the cake. Whoever wrote the story really knows how to blend humor, mystery, and tragedy in a story that never left me bored (except when I got stuck desperately looking for some object to interact with).

I won't oversimplify by rating this game with a number, but I'll say this:
Since I was about eight years old not a single day has gone by without me reading a novel. I have watched thousands of movies, played literally hudreds of games, and amidst all the classics, the worldwide hits, the big budget productions, all the various forms of entertainment, this comes out easily as one of the favorite stories of my lifetime. If you can sit through a few tedious puzzles and don't mind spending half an hour looking for items in a pile of trash, then I recommend this game wholeheartedly. Hell, even if you hate the gameplay it's affordable enough that you can buy it just to appreciate the art and ambience.

22226233.review:
This may just be the best freaking adventure game I have ever played in my life!
The game manages perfectly to keep you interested, but not overwhelming you.
And if you're stuck, you can always get help that REALLY HELPS from your Pal Crispin.
I HATE it when I need a strategy guide, only to get passed some roadblock of a puzzle,
like in most other adventures.
Not so here.
Multiple ways to solve puzzles.
Multiple outcomes to situations.
Multiple ENDINGS ! - I love it.

And the attention to detail is really striking, - not ONCE did I encounter a single line of dialogue that didn't fit, although that's something developers quite ALWAYS glitch up in a minor way when
allowing their game to follow multiple paths.

On top of that, FOR ONCE an adventure game orients itself in reality, in the sense that you can use the same item in different but similar situations - most other games just find one excuse after the other, why "Crowbar XY" can IN NO WAY open Door #2, when just minutes ago it was  perfectly capable of opening Door #1.
In Primordia things tend to be a little more logical, and I enjoyed every minute of it.

I played it straight through today, then immediately run through it a second time, just to collect the achievements and see all the things I could have missed.

21762626.review:
Primordia's robot driven post-apocalyptic setting is a great twist on your standard post-war stories. Even though the characters in the game are robots they retain many human properties that makes them quite relatable. To add to this, their human traits are merged with some very interesting quirks based on what purposes they were coded for. This makes almost every character you meet really interesting and memorable, and also drives a lot humor in the game. In particular, the bond between the playable character Horatio and his creation and best friend Crispin is consistently entertaining thoughtout the whole game. It's not just the setting that's great though, the writing and story in general is fantastic, and the voice acting is amazing.

The gameplay draws really well from the setting too. Scavenging for spare parts and pieceing machines together might feel pretty familiar to anyone who has played an adventure game before, but because of the setting and design of the game all of this feels really organic and fluid. It helps that there are core items in the game aren't simply used once and then thrown away, but instead you are gathering an array of tools (Your friend Crispin being one of them!) that you will keep reusing throughout the whole game. There is still the odd puzzle that had solutions I wouldn't have thought of and got me turning to a guide, but I would put this down to my own impatience rather than design faults of the game. I never really took the time to think things out completely as I was too compelled to move forward with the story!

Long story short, I would strongly recommend this game. The only negative thing I can think of is that I had a couple of very minor technical issues that were resolved easily. If you have any interest in point-and-click adventures or story-driven games in general I wouldn't hesitate to pick this one up.

21737660.review:

21514896.review:
My god. You want to talk about fun and story-driven gameplay? This thing comes close to a masterpiece. 9/10. Details below.

Set in an extreme post-apocolyptia, our hero attempts to recover a power source he desperatly needs, stolen from him by a hulking robot. As his simple quest progresses, he finds himself drawn into the day-to-day conflicts of many men and women bots, deepening the story and lore of the world naturally. On the way you, the player, solve simple yet satisying point-and-click puzzles with elegent conectivity and solutions. The vast majority of the puzzles feel very natural, not forcibly integrated with the environment. The few esoteric ones can be figured out by paying careful attention to the dialogue of NPC bots. As you travel from your humble abode across vast wastes, to a sprawling, decrepit city, you meet incredibly interesting characters. The amount of work that went into the art design is astounding, and reflects well on the amount of work that went into the writing. The story is driven by dialogue rather than the environment, though all the scenes are breathtaking. I will say Crispin's playful banter leaves something to be desired and feels off-key, coming as it is in such a bleak game. But the story and gameplay merge so seemlessly you can forgive it. An incredible game with replay value and amazing choice endings. Highly reccomended.

Over all I recommend it. Wish there was Primordia 2.

21258391.review:
TL;DR 10 баллов из 10 возможных, один из лучших квестов, что мне доводилось проходить. 
А теперь поподробнее:
Сюжет рассказывает вам о нелегких буднях робота Horatio Nullbuilt - отшельника, живущего с роботом-помощником в сбитом когда-то давным-давно воздушном судне, потихоньку его реконструируя, лелея мечту о том, что когда-нибудь "UNNIIC" полетит. Разнообразие в серые будни Горация привносит внезапный визит робота, который ворует энергитическое ядро корабля, откуда и стартует нелегкий и неблизкий путь робота по дороге к возвращению украденного имущества. История мира, в котором происходит действие игры, описана богато и с вниманием к мельчайшим деталям, и подается игроку как через диалоги, так и через терминал, с, кажется, бездонной базой данных.
Графическая составляющая игры радует, хотя количество пикселей на экране может отпугнуть привередливого игрока. Я  же считаю, что выбранный графический стиль, вкупе с отличным исполнением и вниманием к деталям, прекрасно справляется с поставленной задачей создания постапокалиптического пейзажа на протяжении всей игры. Радуют глаз как задники, так и "передний план" экранов.
Волшебный саундтрек за авторством Nathaniel Chambers прекрасно дополняет графическую составляющую, радуя уши приятными, слегка депрессивными мелодиями, как и подобает нарративу произведения. К сожалению, в Steam саундтрек не продается, однако его легко найти в Google Play, продаются все 43 композиции всего за 129 рублей. И да, я его купил :)
Геймплейно игра представляет собой классический квест - собираем предметы, решаем поставленные задачи, беседуем с персонажами, узнаем о мире и о том что в нем творится, продвигаясь далее по сюжету. Нелинейность присутствует, но не тотальная. Отдельно хочу упомянуть головоломки - они, во-первых, имеют несколько решений, а во-вторых - все эти решения вполне подчиняются законам логики. Ни разу за время прохождения мне не пришлось лезть в гайды или просто бездумно тыкать всем на всё на экране, пытаясь наугад узнать решение головоломки, будучи абсолютно дезориентированным недостатком информации и/или мотивации, чего я не могу сказать о многих других представителях жанра (передаю привет всем трем частям Deponia, второму акту Broken Age и всему Grim Fandango), хотя есть один достаточно запутанный момент, но стоит лишь собраться с мыслями и постепенно выполнять поставленные задачи одну за другой, а не метаться между ними, как всё становится на свои места.
В общем, не могу не рекомендовать к покупке данную игру всем любителям жанра, да и даже тем, кто с жанром не знаком. Она определенно заслуживает вашего внимания и стоит потраченных на ее покупку денег.

21164762.review:
I liked this game. I really did, which is a rare occasion for me in this genre.

I'm the kind of person who usually buys huge batches of cheap new indies and revamps of old adventure games, starts point-and-clickers excited but leaves them even before half-way, bored of the theme, disillusioned by the lack of immersion, redundant puzzles and all. Somehow it all gets diluted into a non-engaging mess. But this was not the case with Primordia; I played it through twice, once genuinely without any help, and then second time with a walkthrough / achievement guide to see what I had missed. 

I loved the dystopian atmosphere. The writing was excellent, as well as the characters. The graphics were surprisingly fitting - somehow the artists filled just the right amount of atmospheric detail in "cinematics", and the gameplay was fluent enough. Puzzles did involve every once in a while some actual thinking and not just random inventory combo-womboing, and once I even took pen and paper to solve a key puzzle. I must commend that the narration for Horatio, Crispin, as well some other key characters (without spoilers) were excellently done, which played a huge part on why the game was so immersive for me.

On the down-side, some of the puzzles were kinda redundant pixel searching, as one might expect. Luckily the hint system was just on the correct level for a guy like me, who doesn't like hunting for pixels for eternities, and might dismiss an "obvious" clue every here and then. I never felt stuck, and I always had a sense of progression in my first playthrough. Without spoiling too much, there isn't that much of difference in the endings or how your choices end up as consequences, but second playthrough (with a walkthrough) did reveal more of the lore and modest alternatives that I had missed. I must also admit that dystopia/sci-fi as a genre is probably my favorite (1984, Brave New World, Neuromancer, you name it), so I am biased to liking this game.

Overall, I can highly recommend this excellent adventure-novel to anybody that can overcome the barrier of point-and-click, and instead enjoy a ride of well fitting retro graphics, excellent narrative, good writing, and a neatly packaged ~4-6h adventure in a single playthrough - all for a very modest price. I'll fly one day, and Crispin will be laughing at me.

20944890.review:
First things first: I have only played one ending to this game, I am led to believe there are many.

Despite the above I feel I am qualified to give a review of a large portion of the content, since the core backstory is static.

This game is wonderful. It happens to be my favorite game in the world, but that is a subjective assessment and I intend for this to be an objective review so I will explain WHY my opinon has formed the way it has.

First: the world is unique.  The spectacularly different setting in which the protagonist finds himself is interesting and deeply realized. I found that as I played this game I wanted to learn more and more about the backstory, the reason things were the way they were. It is likely that not everyone will have this response but I found that the somehow quite human cyberpunk characters drew me in. The robotic population of this game have dreams, hopes, and problems which make them relatable, but also special. They are obviously not human, but the similarities between them and humanity are evident in many portions of the game. That, however, is not to say there are no differences. Indeed some of the differences are what drove me to be more industrious in my exploration of the world.

Second: the voice acting is stellar. While the voice acting is not particularly flashy, it has an underplayed value in making the protagonist and his little helper come to life. Throughout it gives simple but essential relatability with the main character, putting the player in his shoes so to speak. The voices are diverse and unique and this additionally draws the player into the world, which now not only has depth, but also seems broad.

Third: the art is dead center with the rest of the game's feel. Though robotic, many tubes and unique shapes cascade through the art design, giving the machines an organic feel (this is not the only game I've seen do this but this game does it well). Most of the tones are dead-feeling beiges and browns but there are many glowing lights throughout the game that give the overall impression of a world with a soul beneath all the lifeless metal. Again this fits perfectly with the world's history and vibe.

Fourth: the audio is wonderfully immersive. The sound is electronic with a common use of ethnic sounding pad synths. Deep, slow rhythms give the game a dark and somber feel which meshes perfectly with the mechanized art and characters. There is at least one old record you can listen to, which deepens the games portrayal of the world's past.

Fifth: the gameplay is solid. The puzzles are not hard, but they have an obvious digital slant that only increases immersion and interest. Each one is unique, although each of thier formats is fairly standard for point and click games. If this game had to have a weakness it would be the puzzles, if you don't play this game for the story and immersion, I think you're not playing to the game's amazing strengths. If you don't like stories/worlds that you can lose yourself in and just want hard puzzles, don't play this. However, if you've ever been interested in a cyberpunk world, or a fantasy story, or even basic philosophy/worldviews, let this game tell you a story. It does it well.

Sixth: no spoilers in this review but I will say the ending I found was amazing.

20914220.review:
I thought Primordia was a very good game, and I would recommend it both in terms of mechanics and story. I am a big fan of the Blackwell games, and this game has many of the same strengths.

Pros:
+ Excellent story. There's legitimately a lot to think about in this game, including political, religious, and social commentary. The game is set in a world where humans are extinct and only robots are left. We see how the society they create is a very clever mirror of our own, with plenty of parody of our own flaws along the way.
+ The point and click puzzles are solid. They are somewhat difficult, but solvable without having to consult a walkthrough because the solutions make sense once you get them. To me, this is one of the most important things about gameplay in a point and click. You have to use your brain to solve the puzzles.
+ If you do start struggling, you can get hints by talking to people (especially your sidekick Crispin), which again means you don't need to consult the internet to get a nudge in the right direction. Normally, he will give you a clue about which area you should be searching, or which object you should be fiddling with.
+ The art and aesthetics in the game are good. The characters are interesting-looking, and the world is very neat.
+ The game is paced well. It does a nice job of moving you from place to place, advancing the story and revealing the mysteries by steps.

Cons:
- Hard to think of any. I suppose the UI can be a bit clunky until you get used to it, especially how you access your inventory.

20778475.review:
A mysterious past is slowly unveiled in a post-apocalyptic art-noveau cyberpunk world.

If you like robots, themes of AI, and/or adventure games - especially classic ones - this game is for you.  

The game follows the pretty standard adventure mechanic - click on things to make things happen - sometimes click on things with things from your inventory, or mix things in your inventory together until they become clickable on other things.  Take notes.  (Most of which actually happens for you with the in-game "data-pad".)  Solve puzzles with said notes.  

The game runs at 640x400 resolution - which can be off-putting to some, but really lends to the retro-adventure feel of the game, and I've come to love it.  (On my 1080p tv, it won't actually fill up the whole screen, but it doesn't really bother me.)  That said - I highly recommend going into the options menu and chosing the "DX" display mode as opposed to D3D if it works for you - the sprites mesh with the backgrounds much better this way in my opinion.  DOS nostalgia!

What really shines in Primordia is the story - and the art.  They come together to create a fascinating atmosphere that makes me want to revisit the game again and again - and the developer commentary is great on a second or third playthrough.  The excellent voice acting and seven or so potential endings don't hurt, either.  (The narrator from Bastion plays the main character - and the sidekick that follows you through the game is entertaining at every turn.)  The music and sound mesh well with the art to create an engrossing atmosphere - despite the retro low-res graphics.  

There aren't many puzzles in the "puzzle game" sense - but there is plenty of puzzling to be done in the game in terms of figuring out how things fit together, what things mean, and what the significance of certain items or pieces of information may be.  The story is mostly linear, but there are a few opportunities to take different approaches to solve situations - especially near the end.  Observation and careful contemplation are rewarded.

The setting is in the distant future in a post-human world - no organic life is to be found anywhere - even the bugs and little things swimming in the sewers are machines - but make no mistake, they have lives and thoughts of their own, and are no less interesting than any human character.  And for the robot fan, there are references to other robots from both popular and obscure culture everywhere - along with a videogame reference or two.  MST3K, Short Circuit, Metropolis, and Fallout - just to name a few.

I would highly recommend this game to any fan of classic graphic adventures, narrative-driven games, or robots.

20529085.review:
Primordia is not what it first appears. 
It's description is: "What happened to the Humans", but that isn't what the game is about. 
I thought this would be an Adeptus Mechanicus themed Adventure game with a Sam and Max buddyish element, but was actually wrong.
Instead, this is a game about logic, law, and a divide between liberty and community. 

The main characters are both charming and the other characters all have little quirks that ensures there is no "that guy" of the game. The puzzles are good without ever being too challenging and the story is tightly knit, with only about 10-11 locations and about 15 characters in the entire game. It's concise without any red herrings. Actually, because the game is so tightly knit, some important secrets are left out in plain sight, which makes it interesting to replay. 

What I also like about the puzzles in this game are that there's dialouge if the game understands what you were trying to do with a puzzle, but you were using the wrong piece and there's multiple ways to solve several of the puzzles. In fact, the biggest and longest puzzle of the game can literally be bypassed from the moment you enter the second act. 

My only complaint with the game would be the antagonist. The antagonist has a trait that they can "never lie" but then you manage to catch them in lies several times and when confronted with this, the antagonist says "no player, you must be mistaken because I am not". In a game where the entire second act is about logic, it just seems silly. Additionally, my other problem with the antagonist is that at one point the antagonist just says "I know you have a lot of questions about the world and history of this game world, so let me answer all of them for you". 

However, that small gripe aside, this game had me engaged and immersed the whole time, trying to figure out its secrets and lore (until the minute that it got bored and laid out its cards on the table).

20350961.review:
Point-and-click adventure games were one of the first things I ever played: When I got my first computer around 1994-’95 I played Discworld with my dad. We had a walkthrough since neither of us could understand English. Since then I have gone mostly to other genres but the adventuring spark were left in me somewhere. That’s why I have bought a great many point-and-click games but every time I play one the same thing happens: I click around for a while and get bored. They just don’t get a grip on me. That was until Primordia.

The player takes role of Horatio and his sidekick Crispin, who live in a post-apocalyptic wasteland. What seems like a peaceful existence is interrupted when a robot crashes through their wall and steals a power core that is keeping the two alive. The game is a quest to find and get back the power core. The mood is melancholic and sad but is lighten up by Crispin’s surprisingly funny dialog. Every other character was also fascinating and had some personality to them.

This was the first ever adventure game that I completed without looking at a walkthrough. Most of the puzzles are logical in a sense that if you have an item that might fit it most likely does. Every solution made sense. The puzzles are quite varied: There are use-item-on-item puzzles but also drawing, memorization, code breaking and so on. I was surprised at how many different kind of obstacles the creators had thought out. It took 7 hours to complete the game, though length varies greatly depending on how fast you solve the puzzles. There appears to be different endings and outcomes since I only got half of the achievements on single playthrough.

The graphics in this are amazing. Everything is a post-apocalyptic bleak wasteland but the world that was destroyed has this art deco kind of style (think Bioshock) that is really nice. The game actually runs at the tiniest of resolutions but is stretched to full screen. Not a lot of pixels to work with but what has been achieved is wonderful. I’d love to see full resolution images of the art since it’s so great. This is also why the game probably runs on pretty much any potato as long as there is electricity. For some strange reason in one room, after certain thing happens, my fps dropped to single digits but it was solved after I got out of the room. You cannot die and there is no rush so it doesn’t matter. Even better than the visuals is the sound and music. I think the voice acting is great but, together with the art, it’s the music that shines the most. 

If you have any interest in point-and-click Primordia is a must play, no doubt about that. For someone new to the genre it’s also a good place to start since it’s not as far-out weird with its puzzles as some games in the genre. I can only give a big recommend for this wonderful game!

One of the best point & click games I've had the pleasure of playing. Despite the 'outdated' graphical appearance, the art was top-notch, as was the overall feel and atmosphere. But what really seperates fantastic point & click games from the mediocre ones, is the writing and the quality of the dialogue and plot in Primordia is absolutely stunning. Characters were also very likeable, in part due to the great voice acting.
 
Planescape: Torment is a major inspiration here; the initial hook of the story, Crispin/Morte, emphasis on the past, it's all here. Much like Torment, Primordia is filled with sad moments, funny moments, philosophical themes and one hell of a cathartic ending (at least the one I got).
Puzzles were decent and quite logical, although at times the game had too many red herrings going on, which made some puzzles a bit difficult for me. Still, only in one puzzle I had to go to a walkthrough and check it out. 

All in all, a very solid old school adventure game with insanely good story, one that I am unlikely to ever forget.

19873099.review:
[h1]"Primordia" (Adventure/Point & Click) (*Spoiler-free*)[/h1]

[b]HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.[/b]

Beautiful (if grim) setting and atmosphere. Excellent dialogs.

The puzzles are quite intuitive (after thinking for a bit! =), at least some of them have multiple solutions (I finished the game without solving every puzzle), and the game has a very robust hint system which is nicely integrated into the narrative.

I enjoyed the retro/pixelated visual style, but since mileage varies greatly do check screenshots and videos and see for yourself.

Maybe a tad short, as adventure games tend to be (about 5-8 hours in this case) but you can save the game at any point (and you have as many save slots as you want), which encourages exploring alternative solutions & dialog choices.

***

[h1]In detail (*Spoiler-free*)[/h1]

Personally, I play adventure games mostly for the story, setting, and characters, with a bit of puzzle-solving to spice the mix. As noted above, in this genre I don't care much for AAA high-end graphics as long as what's on the screen is clear.

"Primordia" delivers on all counts:

> The setting is amazing: robots in a post-apocalyptic, nearly Mad-Maxian world (minus the cars), with an orwellian Big Brother on top. Although, to make it better, the mood is nostalgic and bittersweet rather than oppressive.

> The plot is itself quite good.

> I found most characters to be very well crafted. The protagonist's companion deserves a mention of his own: not only he fulfills his Sassy Sidekick role and provides the humor this otherwise grim tale needs, he's also part of a very comprehensive hint system (and seamlessly integrated into the narrative)

> The puzzles themselves are quite intuitive, and the few that may be too obscure are enlightened by the hint system. Several puzzles have multiple solutions, too (I finished the game without solving every puzzle), and at least a few of them affect the endings of the story.

"Primordia" (as other adventure games) may feel a bit too short when comparing the playtime/cost ratio with other genres, but IMHO it's the price of well crafted plot & characters... and, perhaps more important, of setting and themes you keep thinking about even after finishing the game.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

==New Review
I've written a new review on completing the game. First I still think the warning applies: it should be made clearer that it runs 640x400.** That's not a full screen size image in the video**. However I found it best to turn on x4 anti-aliasing, this is the best option.

This is a great story, nice main character and side kick, good voice acting, setting is interesting. I only got stuck a couple of times, and you know when you do in these games it's because you've missed something obvious or not so obvious on the screen. I'm not a fan of searching the screen for a clue and there is'nt  too much of that, but if you get stuck chances are it's that. The memorious puzzle was in fact a bit oblique to me, like I'd forgotten something in a trunk.

I'd also say this is the type of game where even though the in game data collection works fine you will need a pen and paper for a couple of the code and logic puzzles but that's it. Mostly because getting it wrong the first time locks you out of achieving some of the achievements, though this does give you incentive to play again.  

It has multiple endings so there's some replayability to it at the end. 
I'd compare the setting to Machinarium, but story style wise and feel more Beneth a steel sky. I happen to think those are two top games.

To dev: I dont think a sequel would be possible *right now* but maybe a prequel  would fit really well here. Do a Star Wars and make a trilogy and jump around the timeline.
Having read the Fallen pdf it did give me much more of a sense of story, I can see how things would be missing with out it. I'd put a link on the store page for download if it's not already there. Add the setting to right click change settings to the library entry.

I give it 8.5 / 10

The puzzles provide a good challenge and the story is well written. I really enjoyed playing through this, unlike other point and click adventure games. The themes are also pretty dark, but very satisfying and aided in keeping me playing. I tend to put these kind of games down because I get bored or suck. I hated mine sweeper as a kid and randomly clicking around the screen got tiresome. Primordia even has some cheeky and cleaver dialogue incase you need to run around clicking everything. Didn't help with the frustration, but the occasional joke helped keep me from just giving up. Plus CYBERPUNK! PLUS POST APOCALYPTIC WASTELANDS!

SPOILERS!!!!--------

There are multiple endings. I assure you, saving right before the big confontation helps you experience them all! Each is pretty cool, but even some optional items can have an impact on the ending. Mainly items belonging to your companions. Also certain events may occur that have an impact on your endings. Save different files often as kind of a bookmark so you can go back and attempt for different outcomes. I had about 17 so I could see everything with three files for all the endings (confrontation save)  

For example, there's a situation where you can corner a rogue AI. Save before you attempt! Trapping him gives you an item that aids in the true ending, but killing him changes the ending of that chapter. So if you want to experience both chapter endings, you'll need 2 saves, but after that, the two paths merge and continues normally. 

ALSO! SPOILERS!

Have Crispin talk to the lanterns. He needs the practice!

18574771.review:
In Primordia, you play the role of a robotic nomad named Horatio struggling to find his way through a post-apocalyptic wasteland. Through your searches, you managed to find a power source capable of helping you re-build a derelict spacecraft. All seems well until an unknown assailant ambushes you and steals the power source, forcing you to chase after it or face a slow death in the desert wastes. Thankfully you have your witty and sarcastic sidekick, Crispin, to help you make your way through the various obstacles you will inevitably face.

Being a point-and-click adventure game, most of the gameplay will revolve around you combining items with other items or using them on various places to solve puzzles and progress the plot. You also get a special button for using Crispin on things, either to help you out or just to hear more of his banter. At any point in the game you can also click on him for idle chatter where he will reveal clues about what you should do next. The game also offers a data pouch to help save critical information (so you don’t need to write much down) as well as a map for fast travel.

Most of the puzzles in Primordia are pretty straightforward and Horatio will give you obvious clues whenever you get close to solving one. The only part I found to be particularly tricky was a text-parser based puzzle that required you to stumble through various typos, secret phrases, and acronyms using your keyboard to input queries. But even that was pretty simple once you figured out the trick behind it. 

One thing I really liked about this game was the overall cozy atmosphere observed through the calming visuals and music. It kind of reminds me of old 70s/80s era sci-fi animated movies in scenes where the character would be walking through some trippy landscape to a synth-heavy soundtrack. Most of the voices are pretty well done too (for such a small studio). 

As a whole, Primordia is entertaining without being overly hard on the player and is worth looking into for anyone who is a fan of classic adventure games and sci-fi.

18337296.review:
Primordia is a classic point and click adventure game, with gameplay reminiscent of Zork, King's Quest, or Monkey Island. You will gather, combine, and use items found throughout the world to solve problems, and you will be asked to solve the occasional riddle.

You take on the role of Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot who lives in the wasteland, salvaging parts to repair a derelict flying ship. The game begins when a strange robot cuts his way into the side of your ship, shoots you, and steals your vital power core. Without a power source to recharge your body you will surely die, so you and your companion (a floating, armless sidekick named Crispin Horatiobuilt) set out to recover your core, or at least to find a suitable replacement.

The game is divided into two major parts: first, you wander the wasteland searching for a power core, then eventually you leave the wasteland for a second location. Once you transition to the second area, you will no longer be able to access the wasteland portion of the game. Along the way, you will meet many strange robots, unravel mysteries about your world and your own past, and uncover a sinister plot.

Storytelling is Primordia's greatest strength. Once the narrative picks up (beginning about halfway through the wasteland section), the story really engages the player. The cast of characters (most of which are found in the game's second area) are surprisingly well realized. Each has a distinct personality and a clear motivation. Your relationships with each of them feel genuine, and even your enemies feel well rounded.

The game's setting and art style combine with the well realized characters to create a compelling sense of place. Despite the low resolution environments and sprites, Primordia's world feels bigger than the screen it plays out on. Stellar voice acting and a droning ambient soundtrack put the finishing touches on a beautifully desolate world.

For all its strengths, though, Primordia's downfall is the gameplay. In the 80s and early 90s, point and click adventures were among the best represented genres in PC gaming. Since the rise of 3D graphics and the emergence of new styles of adventure game, they have retreated to the niche and indie markets. My memories of those old adventure games are pleasant, and it takes a game like Primordia to clear the fogged lenses of time. Simply put, even the best made adventure games tend to have puzzles whose solution only seemed apparent to the designer. And Primordia is far from the best made adventure game.

The first issue is that puzzles in Primordia often have nonsensical solutions, or worse, do not permit you to use the most obvious solution. One puzzle early on asked me to plug a pair of ventilation ducts. The first I plugged easily with a piece of scrap cut from a nearby structure, but despite there being three more identical pieces of scrap to cut from, the game would not permit me to do so, and instead demanded I locate an unrelated item that did not seem to fit (according to the visual representations in the game). And these logical disconnects are such frequent occurrances, you will soon find yourself simply trying to use every item in your inventory on each puzzle in the hope that a solution will present itself.

The second issue is the way the game arbitrarily cuts you off from certain areas, objectives, and even major plot threads. It is even possible to lock yourself out of "winning" the game (you can still complete the game and achieve one of the "bad" endings) through a blindly made choice in the first 30 minutes of play.

Lastly (and this is a small complaint), the inclusion of achievements seems to undermine the freedom built into the game's choices. When there are three ways to resolve a puzzle, but one awards an achievement, there is a real sense that there is a "right way" to play, stifling any sense of freedom the system might have otherwise provided.

These serious and frankly unforgivable design flaws sour what might have been an excellent game. Die hard point and click adventure fans will probably push right through, but if you are an average modern gamer with fond memories of classic adventure games, prepare to be reminded of all the bad mechanics that made those games such a frustrating experience.

17803138.review:
Maybe it's a bit of a bold statement but I think Primordia is a memorable game, so much so that I'm writing this review to recommend it.

I'm a story guy and this game delivers it in spades both at a macro level (the main story arch) and micro level (the single scenes). It does suffer a bit from the puzzle adventure syndrome, that is, it's not always clear how to solve a problem with the stuff you have, even when you have everything that's needed. I know this is to be expected in a way but it still bothers me.
The old nerd in me suspected some of the details revealed in the final scenes right from the start but the game was compelling enough to just draw me in the atmospheric setting and make me concentrate on what was happening at a certain point. Hard to say the same about most games I've tried.
The music may be a bit repetitive in the long run but it really adds to the mood, it fits perfectly. So much so that I actually noticed, appreciated and left it on: in other games I usually have it on low volume or off entirely.
The graphics are retro, but in a good way. A shiny AAA engine would only marginally enhance the game. Some may even think that this old school style is actually better/more suited to this kind of game, can't say they are completely wrong.
Again, highly recommended, best game I've played in a long while.

17781635.review:

Somethings i found annoying were:

- I couldn't always tell when story paths were diverging, though this more subtle style of nuance might be a aesthetic feature.
- Some puzzles required an excessively broad associative horizon, which didn't always match real world thinking (according to me).

17671196.review:
This game was a pleasant surprise, to be certain. I could tell just from looking at the trailer and screenshots of this game that it looked interesting, and that "Overwhelmingly Positive" next to the user reviews made it seem like a no-brainer. So, finally I picked up this game and boy, I am not disappointed.

Let's get the bad out of the way first.

This game runs in a very small resolution, at least for most modern monitors. The highest resolution possible is 1280x800, which looks best in a window. It was also a bit annoying that the only way I could find to change these settings was by a launcher in the actual folder containing the game files. I only found that much by perusing the game forum when I was disappointed with the resolution.

There isn't much replayability. I can definitely see myself trying this game again to do a few things different, but overall it is a story-driven and therefore linear experience. It has several endings, but most of those endings are decided at your own whim by how you play out the final scenes.

Now, the good.

The obvious first thing you'll notice about this game is that artwork. I found it to be very cool to look at and definitely gives you that feeling of despair - a world wasting away around you as you desperately try to rebuild what you can. You also have atmospheric music that adds to these scenes but mostly stays in the background. It adds a lot, but doesn't overtake it. Instead, it's all just working together to give you an experience.

The voice acting is likewise excellent. The main character and his sidekick both do most of the talking, so it's great to see them so well performed. It's easy to pick up on their personalities and they're both likeable.

I'm always a bit bad at puzzles in games, but I thought the ones here were challenging but always possible. Nothing ever felt frustrating or beyond my abilities to figure out. I did get "stuck" in a few places where I had no idea what to do, but it usually came down to me not thinking about the situation well enough or remembering details that I simply overlooked. It's worth saying, almost everything matters in this game. There are few things that are superfluous.

Overall it took me about six hours to complete this game. I would have liked for it to be longer, but I could say that for any good game.

If you're interested in this game at all, check it out.

+++ Puzzles that make realistic sense, well-integrated into the story, and with multiple ways to solve them.
+++ Solid script, greatly blending comedy and drama.
+++ Rich and palpable world, friendly to immersion.

Primordia is a game that almost plays itself.  The sort of puzzle-adventure where you become engrossed into the world, and lose track of time. 17193027.review:
Primordia is my first "proper" Point and Click and as such I did have some trouble with some of the puzzles, but I am someone who is completly new to it with only The Walking Dead as a prior Point and Click.

Primordia is heavily story rich. There's so much in the world that I wish I could have explored more so that I might have more knowlege about it, but since it's not importaint to the plot it's touched on at most. [spoiler] There is an information kiosk that you can look at however. It'll give you information on any topic you can find. [/spoiler]

You follow Horatio and Crispin, two robots living out in the dunes, until their power core was stolen by a bigger robot. They embark on a mission to get it back. I don't want to go too deep into story but the ending was one I was very satisfied with. I'm so used to games having a truely happy ending but the endings in Primordia were none of that. [spoiler] The endings were that of weariness, telling the player that in this world there is no such thing as a happy ending.  The world has died and there doesn't seem to be a way to get a kind of renewable resource, and if there is it's just not known. [/spoiler]

Primordia was an amazing game, it wasn't too long nor too short. It was just right.

17186939.review:
Я могу порекомендовать эту игру любому, кто готов терпеть ужасную техническую сторону: движок игры слишком старый. Я понимаю, скорее всего это было обусловлено тем, что создатели хотели передать «олдскульную» атмосферу, но это можно было сделать и при помощи «выстаривания» современного движка, нам же приходится довольствоваться динозавром, который был создан ещё во времена DOS. Кроме того у многих людей с мышками Logitech имеются проблемы с курсором. Свою я решил удалением софта для мыши, впрочем. 

Если абзац выше вас не остановил и вы всё равно хотите поиграть, то я скажу, что это один из лучших квестов, что я имел честь проходить. Возможно потому что я обожаю постапокалиптику и антиутопии, но тем не менее: визуальный стиль, музыка, атмосфера, персонажи, диалоги – они великолепны. Конечно, тут есть свои жанровые клише, но куда же без них? 

Если разбирать подробнее визуальный стиль, можно сказать, что здесь он выдержан в духе квестов из девяностых с характерной «старой» 2D-графикой. Я считаю, что это помогает игре выглядеть самобытно и подходит для происходящего гораздо лучше, нежели современный 3D. Убранства же, через которые предстоит пройти свой путь Горацио и Криспину, выполнены в антиутопичном мрачном стиле с примесью постапокалиптической разрухи и запустения. 

Музыка хорошо вписывается в происходящее и дополняет атмосферу игры. Самих треков не так много и они явно не шедевральны, но своё дело делают. 

Персонажи имеют яркие черты характера, все они прочно запоминаются. Личности каждой ключевой «машины» раскрыты, диалоги продуманы и интересны.

Огромным плюсом для любого квеста я считаю удачные шутки (согласитесь, когда вас пытаются рассмешить плоским юмором, охота играть отбивается), а здесь их полно, несмотря на всю серьёзность происходящего, и они чудесно вписываются в окружение. 

Если поразмыслить, можно отдельно отметить философию игры, делающую отсылку к вере человека в бога, по сути такую же, как веру местных роботов в Человека. Такой многослойный сюжет, дающий пищу для мыслей, заслуживает внимания, как по мне. 

Кроме того в игре есть множество концовок, на которые будут влиять принятые в ходе игры решения. Такая концепция мне не очень нравится, особенно в квестах, ведь их скучно перепроходить, но здесь я получил все с большим удовольствием. 

В итоге я оказался очень доволен покупкой и готов посоветовать Primordia любому, кто играет в игры ради идеи и сюжета, а не ради графона и прочих технических наворотов.

17116931.review:
A hidden gem on the Steam store, Primordia is a game that is about robots in a world where their creators have long since been gone. You are a robot named Horatio Nullbuilt with his best friend Crispin Harotiobuilt, and you two are living in a wasteland. This game is great at charather development and world building.
Man is a god among robots and some say Man never existed. Some robots are barely surviving in the dying world they find themselves in. Others live together in Metro city, a strange place that seems like the last civil place on earth. When Horatio and Crispin's power core (the thing that keeps them alive and running) is stolen, they must embark on a journey using only stuff they can salvage in classic point and click style to find whats rightfully theirs. The gameplay is simple, but like most point and clicks it's about the world and the story is tells. And it tells a good story. Without wanting to spoil anything, trust me and get this.

17068757.review: Damn good post-apocalyptic robot noir.  Reminded me of Alphaville and other bleak black-and-white post-war counter-modernist films.  I can't comment on the voice acting, because I play adventure games with voices turned off whenever possible (and so should you), but competent writing.  Varied locations and characters.  Multiple satisfying endings, and even the "happiest" is pleasantly bleak.  One of the best of the modern small-team adventure games (definitely better than Gemini Rue, which also was going for sci-fi noir).

17058373.review:
I've always been a fan of the adventure games Myst and Riven. My favorite part about these games, as a kid, was that they whisked you away to a completely different, and foreign place. Though many adventure games seek to do this, few fall short, and end up feeling like "just another point and click" derived of any rich narrative. Primordia is not one of those games that falls short at all.

I should admit before I go any further that I've only played the opening sequence of this game thus far, and am extremely excited to get back to it after this review, but this particular summary will be noting the aesthetic, and initial response of Primordia.

I absolutely love post-apocalypse. It's not an uncommon scenario, thankfully, so there's lots of material to dig through on the subject. Unfortunately, there's quite a lot of BAD post-apocalypse games out there, and so with some hesitation, I bought this game, and sat down with some skepticism. For ten bucks, I was hoping it was going to deliver, and the reviews spoke for themselves.

Primordia does something a lot of post-apocalyptic stories don't, and removes humans altogether from the character roster. You begin the game as Horatio Nullbuilt (the surname meaning some dude presumeably named 'Null' built him, which is a common theme throughout the game), the 5th version to be precise, and are accompanied by Crispin Horatiobuilt, your custom companion and comic relief. The world around you is an age-old Earth, looking very barren and very post-war. A strange robot cuts down your door one day and steals your power core, without which you can not charge your own batteries (nor Crispin's). Since that simply won't do, you venture out into the world in order to find the strange robot and reclaim your power core. 

Easier said than done. What follows are scenes common to Adventure/Point+Click games: You meet hosts of interesting robots, travel to new and exciting places, and spend a good deal of time trying to combine every single item in your inventory to see if it does something cool. Excellent (okay... MOSTLY excellent) voice acting, a (so far) riveting and comedic script, beautiful artwork, and intriguing characters make this one of my favorite Adventure games to date, and I've barely even started it.

Should you get it? I mean, it's a point and click. You know what you're getting. The deciding factor, in most cases, is the story and artwork, and both deliver wholeheartedly. Even this early, the story is already showing to be incredibly promising, with twists and turns, and dark comedy as only robots can deliver. The script, as mentioned, is really quite good, and I don't find myself simply reading through the subtitles and clicking through in order to progress, but rather relishing the lines and the delivery. The art, while simple and "retro" in style, does not detract at all from the story, but actually enhances it with far-off vistas, incredible robot designs, and teeming robot cities, both very alive, and strangely dead. 

Fans of point and clicks, this is another excellent addition to your collection, reminding me of titles like Deponia, Riven, and (of course) Monkey Island. Fans of sci-fi, post apocalyptic fiction will also love this game. All in all, I think it's one of those rare games on Steam where I feel like I absolutely got what I paid for, and then some.

And I haven't even finished it.

16967261.review:
When I first saw this game, I was looking for something similar to machinarium (another point-and-click adventure game) and what I was met with while playing Primordia was not at all disappointing. There are some very unique things that set this game apart from other point-and-click adventure games.
     One element that is so different about Primordia is the surprisingly large amount of dialogue that is incorporated into it, unlike most other games of the genre.
     Another characteristic that adds to the game is Crispin, the protagonist's "sidekick" if you would call him that. He adds a sense of humour to the game (although sometimes rather corny) and can offer hints to the player that are valuable, but not always completely revealing of the next course of action that must be taken. Crispin is an often uplifting character in this post-apocalytic setting.
     Another trait that won me over is the atmosphere in the game. It seems realistic in the post-apocalyptic setting, and it is one of my favorite things about this game. The backrounds always seem beautifully made.
     The puzzles in this game are very engaging and are not always clear-cut which may seem like a bad thing, but I personally enjoy the extra challenge. Not every puzzle is as simple as clicking on one thing and then another. They often include various items and/or certain actions to be taken. This is a huge difference between Primordia and other point-and-click adventure games.
     The only complaint I really have about this game is that it seems to include a few creationist concepts that I personally do not agree with. It is brought up through the concept of humanism in the game which is symbolic of today's major religions that believe that a god created humans.
     Another piece of this game that I am not fully content with is the way the protagonist moves. It can sometimes seem somewhat clumsy, but I won't be critical about it seeing as how that is how it is with most other point-and-click adventure games.
     Overall, I would give this game an 8.5/10. It is definitely a worthwhile play for those who like games such as machinarium or other big point-and-click adventure games because of the unique elements it includes.
     One last thing I would like to address is that it sometimes has multiple choices that can be made, leading to different outcomes. They do not alwyas have a huge effect on the story, but it adds a sense of independence in the game.
I highly recommend that you all look into playing this game :)

16737886.review:
97% d'avis positifs sur Steam, des critiques dithyrambiques, en plus j'adore les jeux Wadjet Eye Games, notamment la série des Blackwell que je considère comme passionnante et originale à beaucoup de niveaux. Et pour couronner le tout, les univers post-apocalyptiques sont plutôt ma tasse de thé. Pour moi, il était évident que j'allais passer un bon moment avec Primordia !

Il y a beaucoup d'éléments pour faire un bon jeu dans Primordia !
Hélas, malgré tous mes bons à-prioris et ma volonté de m'amuser, je n'ai jamais réussi.

Histoire en résumé:
L'humanité a disparu complètement depuis des lustres et ses seuls héritiers peuplant la Terre sont les robots, qui ont reconstruit une société bien à eux, héritant toutes les tares de leurs créateurs. L'Homme n'est aujourd'hui plus qu'une légende, certains robots y croient, et d'autres non. Horatio, le héros, vit en ermite dans le désert et se fait voler la pièce maîtresse de son vaisseau par un robot menaçant. Aidé par son petit assistant Crispin, il se lance à la poursuite du voleur, ce qui l'entraînera dans diverses péripéties...

Premières constatations : les graphismes sont délicieusement mornes et déprimants, et la musique est du plus bel effet.
Les doublages sont pas mal, même si l'intonation des personnages (robots) est constamment monocorde, et que leur voix est souvent distordue, ce qui se révèle un peu fatiguant à la longue. On retrouve l'ami Abe Goldfarb, qui doublait Joey dans les Blackwell, et qui se cantonne ici encore au rôle de l'assistant du héros, Crispin. Mais ça fait toujours plaisir de le retrouver !

Plus on avance, plus on se rend compte que l'histoire et l'ambiance sont très sérieuses. Les quelques traits d'humour sont surtout des références de geek (jeux vidéo comme half life, fallout, etc) et des blagues d'informaticien, bref, tout ce que je déteste. Dommage !
Le rythme est lent et je me suis demandé de nombreuses fois quand l'intrigue allait finir par décoller, ou quand les choses allaient vraiment bouger. Ca vient peut-être aussi de l'ambiance pesante ou simplement de l'univers assez figé et monotone. C'est sûrement voulu, mais du coup, à aucun moment je ne me suis amusé sur ce jeu. Je ne me suis jamais senti non plus emporté par l'intrigue, qui passe rapidement de retrouver la pièce du vaisseau à sauver une ville entière. Un rebondissement un peu trop classique dans le genre.
Difficile de se sentir impliqué lorsque cette ville est peuplée de seulement quelques robots. En effet, avec le recul, vous n'intéragirez pas avec beaucoup de personnages : ceux avec lesquels le héros peut vraiment dialoguer de façon élaborée (hormis son compagnon) ne sont pas nombreux.
Les dialogues montrent à quel point les robots du coin sont complètement tordus / buggés, ce qui peut être amusant. Vers la fin, le héros affirme qu'il en considère certains comme ses amis alors qu'au bout du compte, ils se sont croisés dans la journée et n'ont eu que des échanges assez limités (hormis avec Crispin, encore une fois). C'est assez bizarrement amené. Mis à part Horatio, les personnages ont un background assez peu développé, ce qui ne permet pas de s'y attacher vraiment. Leur (non) charisme n'aide pas beaucoup non plus, mis à part Crispin, qui fait de son mieux pour caser des blagues et des remarques cyniques quand il peut.

Reste alors les énigmes. 
Certaines sont plutôt originales (le branchement des câbles par exemple), certaines sont juste usantes. Avec le recul, encore une fois, je me rends compte que j'ai passé une bonne partie de mon temps à trouver des codes et à jongler avec pour ouvrir des portes / réparer des trucs. Le reste du temps, je l'ai passé à trouver des objets pour les donner à un gus X ou Y qui m'en refile un autre en échange, et ainsi de suite. La forme est parfois variée mais le fond ne l'est pas du tout. Le peu qu'il reste se compose d'énigmes de réparation et de dialogues de type questions-réponses - vrai/faux selon ce que vous avez retenu du dialogue.

L'outil qui récupère les données part d'une bonne intention puisqu'il vous permet de stocker les infos et de les garder sous la main à tout moment pour résoudre les énigmes, comme une sorte de calepin. Le problème, c'est qu'il stocke à la fois des informations cruciales et des trucs complètement inutiles ou dont vous ne vous servirez plus jamais (il n'efface pas automatiquement les infos qui correspondent à des énigmes résolues depuis belle lurette), ce qui vous oblige à faire défiler tout un tas de pages sans intérêt avant de retrouver celle qui vous intéresse. A quoi ça sert ?

Point appréciable cela dit : aucune erreur / mauvais choix n'est considéré comme un échec dans le jeu. Vous pouvez tout à fait foirer une scène, le jeu considèrera toujours qu'il s'agit de votre manière à vous de faire avancer l'histoire. Ca vous laisse donc de nombreuses possibilités de débloquer des situations. Autre point positif qui en découle directement : de nombreuses fins sont disponibles !

Au bout du compte, le jeu est plutôt court (entre 4 et 6h), sauf si vous comptez le recommencer pour tester toutes les solutions et les fins. L'histoire est assez téléphonée, et plutôt basique sur le sujet Science-fiction / robots.

En résumé :
Si vous aimez beaucoup les point and click, les ambiances post-apocalyptiques, la science fiction, les références geek, les robots, et surtout, si vous êtes un grand nostalgique, vous apprécierez sans doute ce jeu, en plus le prix est plutôt correct.
Seulement voilà, ces critères sont généraux, et cette critique reflète uniquement mon avis personnel. Oui, il est possible d'être déçu par ce jeu, il s'agit plus d'une mise en garde. Si les points négatifs que j'ai mentionnés sont importants pour vous, donc si vous avez plus ou moins les mêmes exigences que moi, réfléchissez bien.

J'espère que ceux qui se laisseront tenter l'apprécieront, car j'adore ce studio et j'ai beaucoup de respect pour le travail qu'ils accomplissent habituellement.

16668195.review:
Primordia doesn’t have the best start. During the first 20 minutes I was pushing myself to continue based only on the positive reputation of the title. I’m glad I stuck with it, because when it gets going it’s an admirable game. The world and the story has as much rigorous thought and attention put to it as you could ever demand of a title. 

My only problem with the game (apart from the slow start) is the puzzles. I don’t mind slow paced games, or solving puzzles. But there’s something with the point-and-click form that makes me lose patience faster than 3d puzzle games like Portal or Antichamber. There’s always walkthroughs to help out players like me, but I don’t like going that route. There’s puzzles in Primordia where I have no idea how I would have ever solved them, like in my entire life, without looking up the solution. I want to see what happens next in the story, that’s my primary interest in these titles. But the designers thought otherwise, and because they thought this was a good idea, I’m not going to think ill of anyone who likes the puzzles. It’s just not for me. And I guess it’s “not really a problem” because faqs exist. But I wish there was something else that could be done with this type of game. Of all the point-and-click games I’ve played there’s only a couple where I haven’t hit a wall because of pixel hunting. Those moments always make me wonder what the point is.

Despite that rambling second paragraph I would absolutely recommend Primordia to anyone who likes the look of it. It’s superb sci-fi, of the kind that’s not just rare in games, but rare anywhere. It treats its characters and the world with intelligence and respect. What made the first 20 minutes a bit dull was that I couldn't tell how ambitious it was going to be with the setting. I mean I've seen a ton of stories start out like this with lonely scavengers in the desert. But when it started dropping hints about what the game would really be about it made me increasingly excited. It takes a serious stab at exploring what life as a machine in a world run by machines would be like. What their religions and laws could be. Echoes of their human ancestors, now adapted for their style of thinking. And it does this without any attempt at dumbing it down for a wide audience. A gutsy thing to do, and it works.

This is a very interesting and strange game.

The graphic style is “different” kind of haunting and wistful, unique and beautiful.
Play is somewhat frustrating because you have to find items then combine them while in your inventory for use on items in the environment.
Some of the combinations that need to be used are just not intuitive or easily figured out.
Also if you combine two items by putting one on the other it may not combine until you put the other thing on the one thing. 
(In example, maybe you put water on dirt it doesn’t make mud but if you put dirt on water it DOES make mud)

Personally I have enjoyed the walkthrough so far, I say walkthrough because to make any real progress in the game I just keep the gamezibo.com walkthrough open on my tablet.

So, I can’t really say that I am playing the game, perhaps you are more clever than I am, but, I need a step by step guide.

Graphic style and clever banter are the strong points of the game.

16387627.review:
A refreshing original adventure game with strangely charming retro-graphics despite the desolate environments devoid of living things. You play as a robot in a post-apocalyptic world, where robots of varying degrees of sentience, function and design remain after humanity become extinct. Exploring and learning more about the world is compelling, the puzzles are well enough designed, you have a companion that is both useful and funny and the game is just long enough that it doesn't overstay its welcome. 
A small gem of an adventure game. Much recommended - don't let the seemingly crude and perhaps initially offputting graphics deter you.

16334799.review:
I am a huge fan of Point and Click games, from the DOTT and Monkey Island games. I am a huge fan of Wadjet Eye games and I usually buy all of their creations. So like all of the games I played through I'm going to review it in PROs and CONs. Or you can of course read the Verdict at the end.

[b]PROs:[/b]
[list]
[*] Beautiful pixel art graphics
[*] Incredibly immersive 
[*] Awesome storyline
[*] Really good and unique Jokes especially if you're a computer geek
[*] You have a floating companion
[*] A lot of content to explore and scenes to unlock
[*] Multiple choices to solve puzzles
[*] Multiple endings (you should play all of them)
[*] Really really awesome ambient and music
[/list]

b]CONs:[/b]
[list]
[*] Too short
[*] Should be longer 
[*] Really too short
[*] Some parts of the game should be more explorable
[*] WE NEED MORE BACKSTORY


[/list]

[b]Verdict[/b]

It's an incredibly beautiful game, with beautiful music and funny jokes. I really hope for a sequel or anything happening in the future. It has multiple choices of how to solve a puzzle, which is somewhat revolutionizing, since in the early games there was only one way to finish the game. Now I really want to replay some of the scenes because of different interactions. The one and only CON that I could think of is, that it's simply too short. I finished it in less than 20 hrs and after it I felt sad that it already ended. It had a lot of fun and interesting characters. Another awesome job you did there Wadjet Eye!

16212227.review:
Ok so let me start off by saying even at full price this game is worth buying.It's goregous in a rusty-noir (that's mine) kind of way that, I honestly didn't think was possible with this type of rendering. This game has made me an instand wadjet eye fanboy.

I experienced absolutely no bugs in my playthrough,
 I thoroughly enjoyed the voice acting, and the writing is excellent. 
I was able to play this game with my 3 year old in the room (you don't generally find such a dark story free of offensive language or innapropriate visual content so it's a huge plus for me.)
Easily the best point and click game I have ever played (I've been gaming for 27 years now I like to think of myself as a connoisseur).
If you like the point and click genre you NEED to play this.
If you don't, but like a good story then I'd say you wont be dissapointed.
You can read more about the story and setting in other reviews so I wont go into it. I'd just say that it was enthralling start to finish and the puzzles aren't brainwracking but you need to use your head throughout the game.

16043998.review:
A downbeat trod through a world where robots scramble to survive amongst the ruins of decaying, forgotten human world. Primordia has all the charm, class and witt of old point-and-click games and none of their problems and is a delightful story in a game that doesn't hold your hand. All in all, a short point-and-click adventure game with puzzle elements and some philosophical nods.

[h1]Highlights[/h1]

* Some very cool little puzzles add a little bit of depth and side objective. One puzzle, for example, has you exploring an encyclopaedia style database of information via an information kiosk to try and unlock information pertaining to the current objective, and is a nice side-step distraction
* Incredibly good game design, nothing is over or under designed and it takes all the good elements of old point-and-click games and none of the problems
* Fantastic sound assets, voice acting and soundtrack

[h1]Mistakes[/h1]

Finding mistakes and problems with this game is difficult, though there are some minor and non specific design mistakes.

* It can be finicky trying to find solutions to progress at times which can impact the pace of the story
* The graphics are arguably too low-res or dark. For me, that adds to the appeal

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]

Primordia is listed at £6.99/9,99€/$9.99 which is fair for it's 6 hour+ story. There's also a [url=http://www.wormwoodstudios.com/p/primordia.html]short demo available for free[/url].

GOG offers a copy of the soundtrack, a MAC version and some other small extras at a cheaper price and may be a better choice for some.

* There are a number of interesting cutscenes and small story elements to discover, [url=http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=152701150]most of which are married with Achievements[/url]
* Everyone who enjoys Primordia should take a few minutes to check out Wormwood Studios' other IP which includes 3 games; Like a Raisin in the Sun, Salt and Beacon, and a number of short stories, all of which are [url=http://www.wormwoodstudios.com/p/small-games.html]available for free from Wormwood Studios, hosted on The Escapist[/url].
* [spoiler][url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T7HPWpjCesQ]Primordia has several possible endings[/url][/spoiler]

http://store.steampowered.com/app/227000

16034764.review:
[b]General Overview[/b]: Primordia, a point and click adventure, takes place in the unique timeline of post-apocalyptia where humans are no longer present. The only thing left is their own invention: machine. Machine that prospered and slowly became just like human, with their own ideas and vices. Even if they're limited by their programming, they could still interact with others like normal folk. Taking the reigns of Horatio Nullbuilt and Crispin, what starts as a simple retrieval turns into a full blown adventure, albeit a somewhat short trip.

[b]Gameplay[/b]: The game itself follows the point and click style of gameplay, so its hard to screw that part up. That said, it does a good enough job being difficult and leaving you wondering "what the hell do I do now?" Thankfully, Crispin has a built in hint-o-tron to give you tips on what you could do or should do if you're ever stumped. The puzzles themselves are, in my opinion, pretty darn easy. The only difficult ones would be where you meet your unfriendly thief again or when you need access to a certain place with a long string of code. Other than that, it's pretty straight forward. Then again, I play puzzles for kicks so take that with a grain of salt. 

There [i]are[/i] some puzzles with different methods of completion, usually a good and bad way. Sometimes the bad way is the only obvious way, where the good way will require a save here and there to help you out should you pull an oopsie. By the way, you'll probably be doing this often. Puzzles do have "soft-fail" states, which can be pretty infuriating, so save often! The actual game itself is, unfortunately, pretty damn short. You could probably finish the entire game within 5 hours or so (after knowing everything and everyone and all the choices). There is [i]A TON[/i] of going back and forth. No joke, you'll probably find yourself going back and forth between robots, trying everything, for a good 10 minutes until something works. It can get annoying fast. There are also a few references sprinkled here and there to earn a few chuckles. Some more obvious than others.

[b]Art[/b]: Holy hell, this art style. While a mess of browns, it works so damn well together. Not to mention Horatio and Crispin always seem to stand out from the environment whenever possible, so that's also a plus. Unfortunately, the overwhelming abundance of browns makes finding some robots or items kinda difficult. Had to pull the hover method to find a few things sometimes. I understand its supposed to be post-apocalyptia, but sometimes you have to look away and rub your eyes.

[b]Music[/b]: It's amazing. Done.

[b]Acting[/b]: The VA in this game are beautiful and, at the same time, somewhat phoned in. Sometimes you can tell the lines are being read from the script. Other times you feel it from the heart. It is, overall, a very good experience to feel the voices actually try when they do. Funnily enough, it was the side characters that, in my opinion, had the best acting compared to our main characters.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone that loves a good point and click adventure with a fanfuckingtastic sound track.
