15705259.review: Usually I do not have the patience to play retro (i.e. pixelated) point-and-click adventures anymore, nevermind finish them. This one kept me going though and I played it all in one sitting. What kept me going? The setting and the story were original (at least they were to me) and engaging. The gameplay and puzzles were simple enough to not get tedious without being pure pushovers. Most importantly, though, the characters were interesting and absolutely beautifully voiced -- far superior to a recent so-called "AAA game" that I played where I grew to hate the characters. Not in Primordia: every character was great and the voice actors and sound design was perfect: Horatio, Crispin, Clarity, Ever-Faithful, Gimbal,  Goliath, Oswald, Primer, 187th, Memento Moribuilt -- so many awesome voices and dialogues that I enjoyed immensely.

15698469.review:
Многие вариации на тему апокалипсиса рисуют смачные картины, наполненные безысходностью и страданиями. Но стоит сделать последний логичный шаг и окончательно вычеркнуть человечество из сюжета, как на душе сразу становится легче. Как когда любимая команда наконец проигрывает заведомо безнадежный матч. Пожалуй, ничто не приносит большего облегчения, чем полный и окончательный провал.

Примордия – это интригующая и замечательно одухотворенная свалка. Мир хлама и мусора, в котором заправляют обаятельные роботы, с любовным гротеском отражающие наш мир в кривом зеркале трагикомедии. 

Главный герой, - Горацио Нульбилт, пятая версия, - впитал лучшее, что нуар завещал жанрам-потомкам. Циничную романтику, холодную пылкость и  безрассудное упрямство.  Инженер-механик, Горацио так же большой почитатель Гуманизма – религии, восхваляющей Совершенную Машину, то есть Человека, написавшего код мироздания, а своим “детям” даровавшего Память и Логику. 

Как и многие квесты, игра затягивает постепенно. После неспешного начала, камерного и уютного, как MS-DOS, история раскрывается во всей перепрелой красно-коричневой красе. Сложно представить место действия столь же депрессивное и оживленное одновременно. Эксцентричные роботы демонстрируют ярчайшую палитру комплексов и предубеждений. Подпрограммы вины, ингибиторы риска. Странные пристрастия и антипатии, скрытые в глубинах базовой логики. 
Машины в равной степени мучаются ограничениями кодовой базы и неопределенностями свободной воли. Разрываются между желаниями и директивами. 

К примеру, судебный клерк-гиноид, - Кларити Арбитрбилт, вторая версия, - демонстрирует всю устрашающую красоту Закона, достигшего полной беспристрастности. Она делит всё и всех на черное и белое, нули и единицы. Её Справедливость слепа, бездумна и беспощадна, а оттого неэффективна, уязвима и одинока.
Еще более ярким примером становится антагонист, живописующий доброжелательную тиранию наглядно, как инструкция по эксплуатации. В его понимании цензура – не более, чем удаление поврежденных данных. Конституция – открытый для редактирования файл. Неэффективное управление – баги при апгрейде системы. Он сам становится функцией, а Правда - её значением. И всё это делается исключительно с молчаливого согласия рядовых роботов, которым не хватило бы инициативы даже на запуск пакетного файла.  

Впрочем, сердитая сатира изрядно разбавлена легковесным юмором. По законам жанра, ирония покрывает игру толстым слоем, как ржавчина после дождя, а неизбежный комикующий напарник, - Криспин Горациобилт, первая версия, - отводит на стеб и околесицу 97% процессорного времени. 

Фокус сюжета всегда сосредоточен на Горацио, его становлении и путешествии от полярного восприятия реальности к парадоксальному. Горацио – отшельник. По месту жительства и по символической атрибутике – плащу и коллекции фонарей. Но главное, по характеру. Он ощущает себя целостной личностью, достигшей предела развития. Он закостенел в своих убеждениях и закрылся от мира поношенным капюшоном. Но его путь еще далеко не закончен. Ему предстоит познать своё истинное имя, заложенное при конструкции, переосмыслить прошлое, признать вину, и через всё это определить будущее место в жизни. Конечно, он будет сопротивляться. А игроку придется поломать голову над нелинейным сюжетом, в котором лучшую концовку открыть сложнее, чем найти бит в терабайте. Но за это мы квесты и любим.  

Примордия - это недостижимая утопия, опасная демагогия и оправдание злодейства. Но это так же и рай, потерянный и искомый. Ослепительный идеал, стремление к которому само по себе победа. Это вера во что-то большее. Не во Всестроителя, а в то, что все мы – шестерни одной большой машины, которая доросла до нынешней версии нашими общими усилиями. Наконец, это вера в самого себя. 
Когда ты начинаешь понимать, что от неумолимого натиска энтропии тебя отделяет лишь сила воли, сопроцессор иронии и вечно убывающий заряд батареи, подобная вера не позволит поддаться соблазну дезактивации. 
Возможно, только форматирование может избавить наш мир от всех накопившихся багов и глюков. Но пока в нас остается заряд, мы должны латать и править его так, как умеем.

Как сказал Горацио: “Nothing is irreparable”.

15415226.review:
Wow, another great entry into this new golden age of adventure games. Primordia does so many things right, stuff that should be common in every game of this genre, like multiple solutions to puzzles, branching paths and multiple endings.

Both the story and atmosphere are great, and Crispin, the sidekick, serves not only as a great jokester, but also as a nice hint system that ensures that we are not left wandering aimlessly, like in many old adventure games. 

The game is quite short, but it’s better for it, as it doesn’t suffer from overreach, and it achieves the goal of telling a good story and exploring interesting themes.

There’s not many downsides to this game, but one particular puzzle, near the end of the game (involving a kiosk), annoyed me, and didn’t played by the same rules as the rest of the game. I also thought that the voice of Horatio never felt appropriate for a robot (it’s the same actor as the main character of Gemini Rue, but in that case it fit great) , but it’s just a minor quibble. The rest of the cast and characters are great.

15372713.review: Very depressing and bitter sweet but very hauntingly beautiful. Highly recommended for sci-fi story fans in particular robot-AI story lovers.

15342112.review:
A fun point & click adventure developed by Wormwood Studios. This is their only commercial release to date but they did do two games for Indie Speed Run 2013 called Like a Raisin in the Sun and Salt. It takes place in a post-apocalyptic world where all the humans are gone and you play a robot named Horatio Nullbuilt.  You have a broken down ship that you live in and another robot breaks in shoots you and steals your power core. Now you are on a mission to get it back.

Gameplay:
	It plays just like a typical point & click adventure game. Finding objects to use and figure out puzzles to progress further in the game. Puzzles were a little challenging for me but were fun to figure out. They require some logic and can have multiple ways to figure them out. Choices you make in the game can change things later in the game. If you’ve played other adventure games then you’ll have no trouble playing this.

Story:
	It kept me interested and curious to dig deeper. It all starts out over a power core but there’s a deeper secret you can uncover if you make the right choices in the game. Great supporting cast which brought some comedy to the game. I really enjoyed the banter from Crispin your little sidekick throughout the game. There’s also seven different endings to the story if you care to see them all.

Visuals & Sound:
	It has retro style graphics with some great looking hand drawn rooms. They did a great job of showing you a dark and grim world. An easy to use interface, and great voice acting. You can also change it to text only if you are one who just wants to read it all.

Overall:
	Primordia was a fun and enjoyable game. The story was a little slow in the beginning but picks up a little ways in. I laughed at times and even felt a little sad at times. It’s well worth playing if you enjoy point & click adventure games or a good story and it won’t take you to long to beat.

15315355.review: Fantastic story and puzzles. I am a huge fan of all of WadjetEye's adventure games and this one does not disappoint.

15302428.review:
Truly a master piece point click adventure game which has learned and adapted from all it's former predecessors. If you're interested in an old styled point click adventure which preserves the "vintage" feel of the genre, while making mile stone improvements to its execution -- then this is for you. 

Everything in this game made sense, I only used the walkthrough a small amount of times. The side kick is actually useful, he even hints you if you get stuck. The characters felt real and alive, things were not too 'grindy' and the story was very captivating... I can't say enough good things. If you're thinking about buying this game then don't think twice, buy it.

You take the role of  Horatio Nullbuild, a robot who lives in a vast wasteland. Together with his robot companion Crispin
Horatio tries to rebuild the  Uniic,  an ancient ship left behind by Man.
The Journey of Horatio and Crispin begins as a Droid named Scraper swipes the powercore of the Uniic.

Primordia is a Point&Click adventure with a retro graphical style and  an epic soundtrack.
It features clever and headcracking riddles along with a slow starting but awesome Story with tons of very loveable  and nice synched charackters to meet on your journey.

15023079.review:
I have tried to get into point and click adventure games in the past but have tired of them quickly. As soon as I get stuck the temptation to check for the solution on the web gets greater and when I finally do the magic is gone, I may as well just use the walkthrough. With Primordia there were some hard points but with the help of my sidekick Crispin I managed to get through and complete the game.

I found the world incredibly absorbing. The artwork was excellent and the dialogue thoroughly amusing. The story pulls you in and at the end I was a little sad that it was over.

If you like adventure games then this will be a hit. If you haven't tried adventure games but were looking to then I think this might be one to start with as most of the puzzles are pretty intuitive. The things you need to interact with are generally easy to find on the screen and the dialogue and hints help a lot.

Это один из самых восхитительных квестов, в которые я когда-ибо играла. Пиксели, но зато какие. Проработка локаций поражает, дайте игре минут 15 - и вы перестанете испытывать дискомфорт от разрешения экрана, я гарантирую это.

14978853.review:
I'll start this review by saying that this is the best point-and-click game I've ever played in my entire life.
What makes this game so special is how the story develops and the awesome caracther design.

SPOILER ALERT:
The story begins with Horatio and Crispin on top of the UNNIC, a half broken airship that has seen better days.
Horatio is fixing the telescope on that resides on top of said ship, when suddenly he hears a strange noise comming from down bellow.
Appon entering the room, he is now faced with the fact that there is a giant robot that has claws and shoots lasers ( you will probably get the joke if you have played the game ) that invaded his ship by cutting a hole in it.
The giant robot demands that Horatio "forfeits" and that he hands over his power core, Horatio does not give in to the robots demands and the following shoots Horatio in the chest region with a lazer beam.
From then on, Horatio and his side kick crispin set off to find out who this robot was and where he went, so that they can get their power core back.

Now let me tell you something, at this point I was already hooked on the story and I was like "okay let's continue playing for a bit more". That "bit" more turned into hours and hours of continuously playing this game. This game just throws at you the mix of a great story line + good caracther development + Not too hard to figure out but still good puzzles and great comedy. It doesn't have the same funny tone all the time however

When Horatio and Crispin fail to find a power source in the wastelands they are forced to head to Metropol, the self proclamed city of glass and light. "Free power for one and all" is what they advertise and they do have power for everyone, but it does come with a price. When Horatio and Crispin step out of the red line train, Horatio finds a robot who collects 1 megacycle from him. At the time, Horatio has no idea of what a megacycle is, but he does find out eventually that the megacycles are brain power, we could also call it processing power. Anyways, the story goes along and Horatio finds out that his power core is stored on the big tower where Metromind is. He then goes on to try and get it back and that's when things take a darker turn. BUUUUUT I don't want to spoil the ending for anyone who might have read the spoil alert and then thinks to theirselfs "you know what, Imma read it anyways".

The story is great, the caracthers are great, the puzzles are excellent and there are multiple endings which means you can replay the game and let me tell you, you will want to replay the game because it is so damn good!

I would rate it an honest 9.5/10 , I would even dare to give it a 10/10 .

Amazing game and for 10 euros, it is a bargain of a lifetime

14932730.review:
11/10!!!
Eins der besten Spiele, die ich jemals gespielt habe! Wunderschön gestaltete Level, Charakteure, wunderbare Englishe Vertonung. Ein Spiel mit einem eigenen einzigartigem Charme. Es erzählt eine unglaublich fesselnde spannende Story, die sich einem mehr und mehr erschleißt, bis das große Ganze vor einem "steht". Diese verpixxelte Grafik ist absolut passend, und das Spiel liefert Momente, in denen man einfach nur da sitzt und denkt: WOW (Fahrt nach Metropolis etc.), sowohl graphisch als auch von der Story her. Der Humor ist wunderbar und man könnte den ganzen Tag Crispin zuhören wie er um Arme bettelt, oder Horatios Zynismus. Die Puzzles sind unglaublich gut durchdacht, wiederholen sich nie, sind fordernd, schwer aber mit Notizen (JA man muss sich Dinge aufschreiben :D ), Sinn und Verstand sind alle lösbar. Selbst ein paar Anspielungen auf Half-Life oder Fallout sind zu finden. Ein absolut geniales Spieleerlebnis. Mit seinen 7 unterschiedlichen Enden (zumindest glaube ich, dass es so viele sind) und verschiedenen kleinen Puzzle-Wendungen bietet es Abwechslung. Auch die musikalische Untermalung ist absolut gelungen.  ABSOLUTE KAUFEMPFEHLUNG!

14932534.review:
Primordia caught my eye due to its design, which I adore, in addition to the sci-fi, mechanical protagonist / world.
The story and interactive aspects were also fresh and fun. You will find yourself searching for pixels, but you will also find yourself searching for clues within the dialogue.
For the duration of the game, they kept the motif of "a mechanical world" to its fullest: with religion, culture, social echelons and political power born out of machine-esque beaurocracy.

Since I am a cheap bastard, I do not think Primordia is worth 10$, I played it twice-thrice, and I found it to be a pretty short experience -- especially the ending, which felt like it came too soon. The middle section of the game is also burdened with swapping items for other items endlessly, which felt like a chore.

Overall, I got it when it was on discount, and I encourage you to do the same.

14910647.review: Primordia is one of the best classic point-and-click adventures in recent memory. Its difficulty is only equaled by its conceptual beauty. Darkly macabre in design and heavily themed in religious and philospohical question, Primordia is worth the time. The voice acting is top-notch all around along a exceedingly mysterious universe. While the abrupt ending is somewhat disappointing, it game never seems to lose a step and the dialogue is exceedingly cyncial and hilarious. The soundtrack is appropriate for horror-thriller films and reminds of the minimalistic The Thing (1982) soundtrack that fits the scene perfectly. Can't recommend it enough.

Other than that, this game is awesome click adventure and I highly recommend it to anyone that likes doom and gloom retro art and click adventure games.

Aventura gráfica entretenida con partes más asequibles y otras bastante complicadas. Esto es así por el nivel de inglés del juego. 

Tuve que echar mano de una guía para darme cuenta de algunos detalles que habia pasado por alto en las conversaciones, ya que en mi caso, con un nivel medio de inglés, te enteras de la historia pero pasas por alto parte de la información. Por ejemplo si se ponen a hablar con lenguaje técnico o nombrando rápidamente personajes y situaciones puedes pasar por alto algún detalle que te guie en la solución de los problemas. A parte hay caminos que cambian los finales, acciones que se pueden resolver de varias maneras y otras sirven para desbloquear logros. Estos son imposibles de conseguir en solo una partida o, si lo prefieres, puedes ir guardando bastantes veces para intentar conseguirlos desde diversos puntos.

No es la mejor aventura que he jugado ni la más fácil por el idioma. Aun así he de decir que no está mal y el ambiente post apocalíptico junto con la trama cyberpunk con toques éticos, morales y religiosos la hacen recomendable.

14613819.review:
This game became a favorite of mine very quickly.

For some reason I absolutely love any story that mixes machines with religion.  Perhaps I have that bias as a Christian who loves science fiction and philosophy (mind/body problem anyone?).  For those who are adverse to religion, I wouldn't say it's a huge part of the game (some of the robots have their own faith, not practicing a real one), but it is certainly obvious.  If you've ever watched Ergo Proxy, it kind of has a similar feel in that regard.

The characters are great, the story is great, the voice acting is amazing... I have nothing but good to say about this game.  Expect a Horatio cosplay from me soon! ; )

14503078.review:
A beautifully realized indie adventure game with alternative paths and multiple endings, Primordia is one of the best point-and-click gems you've never heard of. Set in a far-future dystopian setting, robots struggle to make sense of a world where humans, their creators, no longer exist. As Horatio, a robot seeking to repair what has broken or fallen into disuse, you will explore the landscape of the desolate world and explore one of the few remaining cities with his faithful and sarcastic sidekick Crispin. 

The voice-work is excellent, as are the music and visuals. Now with the 2.0 release, I'm looking forward to playing it again and taking a different path.

14486966.review:
Despite a few minor shortcomings, Primordia is a true gem, a deceptively simple cyber-punk thriller that gradually blossoms into a dystopian epic adventure with rich lore that dares to pose profound philosophical questions. In merely 8-9 hours, the player follows Horatio and Crispin in an unforgettable journey of thought and emotion, which combines the unfolding of a gripping tale with clever puzzles and addictive old-school adventure game gameplay.

Full Review: http://adventureadvocate.gr/gamereviews/item/primordia

I staggered at the beginning a bit and had to use the tutorial, but it was all worth it. I've also enjoyed the developer's commentary which is included. Games like this deserve more recognition. Definitely worth the price.

14305700.review:
个人强烈推荐……优点是70 OFF之后性价比非常高，短小精悍、剧情美术神赞、解谜不乏亮点；不过很可惜的是本作没有汉化，而且本身故事略显晦涩、也有部分解谜脑洞略大，对这种文字AVG无爱的玩家还是要谨慎入手。


发行商 Wadjet Eye Games 向来是90年代复古AVG专业户，一直以来都有着“系统比配音好，配音比解谜音乐好，解谜音乐比剧情画面好”的评价。不过本作虽然也是90年代复古风，但实际上和 WEG 家的游戏完全是两个风格，大概就是《异形》vs《CSI》。事实上本作也确实不是他家的作品：2010年的时候本作的主笔和主美两个人想做一个免费的小游戏，结果做了一段时间之后遇上了当时发展良好，于是想过一把发行商瘾的 Dave。虽然我不觉得WEG是一个优秀的游戏制作商，但毫无疑问的是个优秀的发行商；他们不仅在系统和解谜上给予了巨大的帮助，而且还拉来了在独立界可谓是豪华的配音阵容。结果最后成品花了两年多的时间才搞出来，而价格么……哎呀70 OFF之后也就不到20RMB嘛。

从游戏本身来看，本作不仅有着WEG家一贯的短小精悍、系统优秀的特点，同时编剧和美术也弥补了他家游戏剧情平庸、画面缺乏特色的不足（当然，不喜欢90年代像素风的另说）。

[list]
    [*] 剧情：9/10.本作流程大约是6-8h，如果有攻略会更快。整体来说有点像作者的政治寓言，表故事很简单：主角Horatio是个穿的像穷人版阿萨辛的宅机器人，和他的好基友+小催 Crispin 住在自家的小飞船里，过着看书发呆顺便做着飞行梦的悠闲生活。有一天一个大机器人突然闯进Horatio的小窝，抢走了他家的能源，于是两只机器人只好开始了找能源之旅。不过在简单乃至略显俗套的表故事后面是个非常复杂的Metropol 衰落史，如果有兴趣的各位可以查看这篇指南的相关部分（无耻的给自己打个广告=w=）：
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=385618294
如果只是上面这些内容的话，对我而言其实到不了9分，额外的加分项在于以下几点。一是主题虽多但并不说教，游戏中每个支线都暗含一个主题，但都是点到为止，说教的成分并不明显（不过编剧是个貌似学法的说教狂魔，评论的中二度真是爆表了233）。二是双方观点的平衡，作为一个包含很多主题的游戏，能够保证双方观点平衡是很罕见的。一般的游戏总是会有意无意的偏向其中一方（不举例，求不黑），但本作在这点上做的非常好，也因此最后尽管是多结局也没有“强行XX”的感觉。三是自由度，对于点点点而言能一下跳过25%主线的设定真是太刺激了……最后有7个结局的设定也相当刺激……每个结局都能找到心理动因也是可以……话说本作就是个披着机器人皮的人类世界嘛！

    [*] 画面8 /10,含0.5个人偏好分。本作的美术风格有点异形+星战+新艺术的感觉，用90年代像素风表现反而非常带感。缺点是色调太统一，整个游戏从头灰暗到尾，虽然是要阴郁的气氛但未免太阴郁了= = 尽管设定里能调整画质，但只是像素和更像素的区别，希望有个高清版or超级像素版。

    [*]系统和解谜：7.5/10.系统还不错，能到8（毕竟WEG出品），无论是快速旅行、笔记，还是 Crispin （话说这个飞来飞去的……Joey？）都很实用，没有特别废的地方。由于作者是个Bioware粉（也是The Longest Journey系列黑粉），本作居然还有队内对话这种神奇的设定，一段时间不操作角色会自己聊起来……Σ( ° △ °|||)︴ 不过解谜相对之下神坑……虽然大部分谜题不难，但个把谜题（比如搜关键词那个）脑洞开的突破天际；而且对话只能看一次+提示系统不给力，一些地方只能用穷举法刷刷刷也是拉仇恨的地方。（攻略请戳上面那篇指南=w=）

    [*]音乐/配音：8/10.音乐一般般，不过个人很喜欢主题曲，适合夜深人静的时候听。配音值得多说几句，整体来说非常不错，Horatio的声优是《Bastion》里的旁白老头，Crispin 的声优是Joey，而女主Clarity的声优是《Gone Home》里的妹子。不过一个小小的问题是几位的声线实在是太有存在感，Joey哥还又是飞来飞去的吐槽役……有时候会出戏（而且要是开评论模式的话……更出戏了好么！而且为什么旁白老头的声优是个黑人小哥！）。

    [*]其它：本作和WEG家其它作品一样，也是有喜闻乐见的评论彩蛋，有兴趣的可以听一下；官网上也有一些美术设定和相关背景资料（前传小说一类的）。
[/list]

总的来说个人认为本作是WEG家最好的作品，虽然不适合新手，但是剧情控们应该尝试一下。就性价比而言，本作也是70 OFF过，有卡有成就，相比之下还是很值的。

13940959.review:
[h1]TL:DR? See Conclusion[/h1]

[h1]INTRODUCTION:[/h1]
Primordia is a point-and-click adventure game developed by Wormwood Studios and made available on Steam through the Greenlight system.  It features a fully voice-acted cast with a retro graphical art style that pays homage to the classical age of gaming.

[h1]PLOT (No Spoilers):[/h1]
The story of Primordia takes place in a post-apocalyptic future where machines have taken over the world after the human race fought itself into extinction.  You follow the adventures of a self-aware android named Horatio Nullbuilt and his companion Crispin Horatiobuilt both residing inside a crashed ship called 'The UNNIIC'.  When a mysterious and powerful robot steals their power source, both Horatio and Crispin embark on a quest to seek out a new power source which eventually leads them to the mechanical city of Metropol.

[h1]PROS:[/h1]
+ Good Retro Art Style
+ Great character writing and developments
+ Good story with an interesting back-story
+ Atmospheric environment and world design
+ Consequence-based choices that can affect the final outcome of the story
+ Fully voice-acted characters
+ Healthy game time of at least 6-8 hours depending on how quickly the player solves the puzzles
+ Steam cloud support

[h1]CONS:[/h1]
- No 'HD' or Widescreen Support, in which the game opts instead for a pitiful 320x200 resolution which, frankly speaking, makes my eyes hurt.
- The game has a fetish for the color brown
- Puzzles are sometimes irritatingly difficult
- Does not expand much on the back-story which, in my opinion, is far more interesting than the main story
- The game's humor is a hit and miss

[h1]CONCLUSION:[/h1]
[b]GREAT POINT-AND-CLICK EXPERIENCE.[/b]  I Green-lit this game when it showed up in my Queue because I was very interested in its concept, setting, and back-story, and once it was released I purchased it and found a fun and absorbing point-and-click game with homage to the classical style of the genre. 

[h1]WORTH IT?[/h1]
Overall, Primordia is a great point-and-click adventure game that provides at least 6-8 hours’ worth of game time. In addition, for only $10 (or your regional equivalent), it is definitely worth a look especially if you're a fan of the genre.

13888561.review:
Let me just start this review by giving you the following context: I very rarely play point-and-clicks. The most notable ones (namely, those by LucasArts) were before my time, so my only games in this genre I’ve played are the new Sam and Max games and this one.

This genre greatly focuses on its writing and story, and I feel Primorida does well in that regard. What starts as a simple story of tracking a robot who stole your stuff turns into a one with many hints about the world and why it’s in the state it is, and Horatio’s role in it. Each character, from the straight-laced and practical main character Horatio, to his perpetually floating, snarky sidekick Crispin, and everyone else you interact with is written with enough skill to give them unique personalities without falling into two-dimensional archetypes. While many NPCs fall into some stereotypes of their characters (ex: a soldier robot speaks how you’d expect him to, likewise with a robot with a monocle), they get moments where they flesh out their character and have some very clever lines.

The overall plot kept me guessing all the way to the end, but stayed mostly clear about what was going on the whole way through. The story is straightforward in that regard, although the littering of hints of the details behind the game world really helped the story shine when it revealed big plot elements.

However, I NEED to talk about the gameplay. It’s your typical adventure game fare of solving puzzles by figuring out how items interact with each other, listening to context clues, etc. The game doesn’t go too crazy with the solutions.

That being said, I will be honest and say I had to use a walkthrough for this game. This is most likely due to my inexperience with the genre, but many times I felt clueless on what to do. Furthermore, when I looked up the solution, I felt like the game gave me little to no inclination that what I was supposed to do may be the answer.

PUZZLE SPOILERS

One of the most “how was I supposed to do that” moments was when I needed to figure out how to remove rust from gears so I could open a door. I hadn’t met anyone who was a cleaning robot or the like, and I had no items on me that implied they could clean. It turns out that in one segment, there are underwater “submersible” robots who, when I dunked the gears underwater where they were, cleaned the gears. When I clicked on them normally, the main character said NOTHING about their potential cleaning ability.

Another annoying one was a moment of “I didn’t know I could do that”. I had to inspect a door in order to solve a puzzle, but left-clicking it gave me a quote that didn’t help me. However, right-clicking it gave me a different one relevant to the puzzle. I know that could right-click on items to hear a description of them in my inventory, but I didn’t know why I couldn’t just left-click this door to hear the contextually-important quote for this puzzle.

END PUZZLE SPOILERS

So overall, I’d say that you should not feel ashamed if you need a walkthrough for certain puzzles in this game. The second half of this game has quite a few rather obtuse ones, which is a shame since they can halt the progression of what is otherwise a really cool story.

My other problem is a technical one: this game has no resolution options! It can only either run in fullscreen (which I think is 1024x768!!!) or windowed which has a default size that is most suitable for ants. Thankfully you can turn the “scaling” up, which means increasing the size of the internal resolution (window size in windowed mode increases with this), but the lack of proper resolution options just strikes me as lazy to me.

Lastly, and this is sort of a nitpick, but this isn’t Logan Cunningham’s best work. He does a decent job not sounding bored in his lines and emoting properly when necessary, but either due to sound engineering, low quality audio files, or otherwise not as much strength in his voice work, he isn’t as memorable as he was in Bastion. I felt the sidekick Crispin out-did him in passionately delivering his lines. It doesn’t detract from the game at all really, I’m more just feeling like he could have done better.

SUMMARY:

I strongly suggest you guys pick up Primorida. It’s got an interesting plot inside a unique atmosphere of a post-human world, and the writing does those both justice. The puzzles can be result in premature baldness due to hair-pulling difficulty, but they didn’t stop me from enjoying the game.

13631705.review:
What is the value of life, and do we value it differently if it is being carried out by automatons? What separates an automaton from a human being? How did the world get to the point where no human beings are present, and the myth of man is a religion whose reality may well be akin to our stories of Greek and Egyptian gods of old?

What is a creation myth really about?

This is a puzzle adventure game that asks a lot of questions. It doesn't really answer most of them, instead weaving a fairly straightforward story that gives up a lot of philosophy to chew on the side.

For the most part, the goals seem pretty straightforward, though at times the puzzles fall into the trap of trying to guess exactly what 'clever' gimmick the developers were trying to obfuscate this time to make you feel clever for figuring it out.

13604072.review:
This is a game that was on my wishlist for a while. My primary interest was the visual style, which reminded me somewhat of Machinarium, a lovely adventure puzzler I played a few years back. Primordia is more a traditional adventure game however and I wasn't prepared for how fully it sucked me in once I began playing.

It all begins with a robot named Horatio ... Horatio Nullbuilt v. 5 to be precise. Horatio has a problem, the power core to his fixer-upper airship the UNNIIC has just been stolen by a badass bruiser bot and without it, he and his floating companion Crispin will die a slow death out in the dunes, unable to recharge their batteries or get anywhere that they can do so in time. Thus begins this rather unassuming, but ultimately rather epic point-and-click adventure game.

My few problems with Primordia are the same I have with most retro-style adventure games, those being the combination of low res graphics and archaic systems making it difficult to know what is clickable and what is not. Playing "hunt the pixel" along with environments filled with "flavor" clickables, meant I missed a few crucial objects here and there, leading to a bit of frustration. Other than that however, the puzzles of Primordia are mostly logical, with only a few moments of "how was I supposed to know that?" or where a lack of full understanding of all that Horatio and Crispin together could do kept me confused.

The story and world building in Primordia more than make up for any shortcomings however. Set in a world populated only by robots, where "Man" is nothing more than a myth for all but a few devoted "Humanists", Primordia frames the typical post-apocalyptic dystopia in a fresh light. While at times predictable, the interactions between characters makes even a conclusion you've already jumped to a joy to behold. The dialog in Primordia oozes with personality, especially between the stoic Horatio and the sardonic Crispin. While oft-times broadly drawn, getting to know the denizens of the world of Primordia is half the fun, especially learning the quirks of their robotic society. There is plenty of lore to uncover as well throughout the game, fleshing out the periphery of the world and ultimately contributing to the main story in interesting ways.

By the time all is said and done, you'll have explored a rich world in Primordia, made choices that actually matter, and experienced one of several endings, some of which are locked by key decisions earlier in the game. On sale or not, I cannot recommend Primordia enough to adventure game fans.

13572409.review:
Game Critics Suck!


If you came to steam reviews then good for you, you aren't a tool who watches a bunch of bumbling idiots talk "prolifically" about a game they've played in a single sitting and never came back to.

The first thing I want to address is the negative reviews this game got from bigger critic sites saying this game is too hard. Critics have said that some of the puzzles to this game are too difficult and require a walkthrough,,, no, they don't, they require a pencil, a scrap of paper, and an attention span longer than someone who would give a Call of Duty game an 8.5 out of 10 on their website.
I managed this game without a walkthrough, granted one numerical puzzle was tough but not impossible, the general idea is that you're a fucking robot so of course you're going to end up doing some goddam computing. As soon as you start writing all of the relevant information to the puzzle on paper you begin to see the rules and elements of the puzzle exposed and ready for solving. YOU DO NOT NEED A WALKTHROUGH let the game grant you the satisfaction of completing it yourself.
This pen and paper style comes into play multiple times throughout and really rewards the player for paying attention to the environment around them.

This is an absolutely beautiful game that mostly airs around these cozy melancholic hub-worlds and takes the occasional incursion into the deep dank dark unknown. The music is pretty much entirely ambient and supports the melancholic tone.

The characters are great. The idea is that they are all post apocal

Like a lot of graphic adventures pont n' clicks, this game has a fair few areas to explore, compared to your average 3rd person game its pretty small but they go the quality over quantity route by packing screens with little details that give you a real sense of life and alludes to the mysterious history of the robotic age. Other screens are left very bare and unpopulated, building up lonesome and (Heres that word again) melancholic atmosphere and tone.

The gameplay is pretty simple point & click graphic adventure, combining things and making good use of your flying partner with some lateral thinking, solving various types of puzzles and uncovering mysteries about your past.

Overall this game has:

-the usual gameplay you could expect from this type of game minus some of the bigger cliche sins such as fail states that you didn't know where fail states until 2 hours later.

13378992.review:
Although Primordia is a game small in scope in several ways, it manages to insinuate a world so much bigger and personalitites so much deeper than it can actually describe. 
Our main character Horatio is pragmatic and taciturn, in contrast to his cheerful companion, the little floating robot Crispin; But these are only the main characters; throughout the game you meet numerous different robots with distinct personalities and little by little you learn more about the city of Metropol, and how it became what it is. 

The game mechanics are your old-school adventure game point-and-click, as well as the retro-style graphics. 
If you find the pixely look of the game distasteful, rest assured, it has all the pixels it needs to convey the worn-down world you explore. The puzzles vary in difficulty, but if you find yourself stuck, you can ask Crispin for hints. Throughout most of the game I found the difficulty quite suitable. 
Also, certain dialogue outcomes will affect the game- there are multiple endings to this story!

What makes Primordia worth playing, and what makes it stand out from other games that are also worth playing, is its extraordinary world-building and story-telling. Through simple means it manages to be engaging and touching and pokes at my curiosity for story- one that I choose the ending for. 
A playthrough is about 6 hours.

When the setup is run it's somewhat confusing and I always felt as if the graphics weren't set up right. 13222796.review:
Primorida is one of those games that's really emotionally devastating and depressing and you do feel bad for the characters and the world, but there's also that part of you that didn't really attach yourself to the characters and you're almost kinda glad to have it over and done with.

As a point-and-click adventure game (and as a story) its all really well put together. The graphics and music create an eerie setting. Upon entering the city of Metropol, I immediately felt a disease with everything around me. Every step taken is a direct threat to the big bad, for the mere fact you aren't obeying her every word from the get-go. The knowledge that the bad guy is watching your every move and is intelligent enough to start planning hundreds of steps ahead makes me shiver.

The puzzles are what you'd expect in a robot apocolypse: very technological, a strict sense of rules behind each one. All give off an extra feeling that speaks to me as "yep. Puzzles caused by robots alright."

By the end though, I didn't feel particularly emotionally affected. Which was weird because I did feel for the characters. I gasped at plot twists, I shivered at the Big Bad, and my heart felt like it was stepped on when spoiler stuff happened. But I suppose it was just brief moments of emotions rather than a lasting impact. Maybe apocolypse stuff isn't my thing. Maybe it was that the darkness of the plot sort of negated any victory. I won but it didn't feel like a win. Maybe that was the point.

Whatever, I'm rambling. TL:DR: its a good game. Really. If you play point-and-clicks or apocolypse games are your thing, check it out.

13171746.review:
The first thing you will probably notice about Primordia is that it is a beautiful game. The graphics are pixellated, but not in the sense often used by amateur indie designers as an obvious cost-cutting measure. This is pixel art at its finest: lovingly crafted details in every background and most characters show that the game's artist took their work extremely seriously. That effort paid off in spades.

The second thing you will probably notice about Primordia is that almost everything about it is bleak. This is not the post-apocalyptic world of Fallout, where things have gone to hell but black comedy keeps things from getting too dark. There is humor in the game, but it works in spite of the world being broken, not because of it. Humanity is extinct, its robotic creations and their creations in turn forming what qualifies for society in Primordia's shattered world. Energy is life, and power is running out.


The third thing you will notice is that often the game works in a far more logical way than others in its genre might lead you to expect. Early on you see a lantern on a high shelf your character cannot reach. The solution? Ask your hovering robot sidekick to push it down. There are a lot of moments like that in Primordia, where logic prevails over the typical adventure game "must be as drunk as the original designer to comprehend" school of puzzles. 


That said, there are still moments where you may not figure out on your own. I had to look things up at least a couple times in my playthrough to advance. Not everyone will, and I would discourage players from reading up except as a last resort. The puzzles make up a huge chunk of the game. If they are not your thing, I would say the game is still worth playing with a guide for the atmosphere alone.

12700322.review:
Klasse. Ein überragendes Spiel, verpackt als klassisches Adventure. Was als einfache Suche mit Sidekick (ein kleiner, ulkiger, fliegender Roboter) nach einem gestohlenen Gegenstand beginnt, entpuppt sich schnell als globales und metaphysisches Dilemma, das die eine oder andere philosophische Frage aufwirft und das viele unterschiedliche Enden des Spiels zu lässt. Und von Enden passiert nur eins auf Knopf-Druck. Alle anderen erfodern noch etwas Erforschung und Hirnschmalz. Ein Ende erfordert auch eine unterschiedliche Vorgehensweise bei früheren Rätseln. Bei einigen Rätseln gibt es auch mehrere Lösungen. Das Inventar bleibt während des gesamten Spiels überschaubar, wilde Kombinationen und unlogische Puzzles gibt es nicht. Der Sidekick des ernsten und fokusierten Protagonisten ist witzig und unterhaltsam und lockert damit die durchweg ernste Atmosphäre etwas auf (vergleichbar mit der Laterne aus Zork: Der Großinquisitor oder Arthur aus The Journeyman Project 3: Legacy of Time). Hin und wieder gibt es Easter Eggs und Anspielungen auf andere Spiele (so tauscht ein Händler einen Wasserchip gegen ein G.E.C.K.) Das Spiel ist kurz (habe etwa 9 Stunden gebraucht und bin kein Adventure-Pro), behält dadurch aber seinen Faden und seine Spannung und verliert sich nicht endlosen Nebenplots, die vom eigentlichen Plot ablenken.

Wer also von klassischen click & point Adventures begeistert ist, kann hier bedenkenlos zuschlagen. Wichtig ist nur, dass man sich nicht von der Grafik abschrecken lässt, die zwar grob und gering aufgelöst, aber trotzdem unglaublich stimmungsvoll ist. Adventure-Neulinge sind mit dem Spiel auch gut beraten, da die Rätsel nicht zu überfordernd sind, es auf Wunsch auch die eine oder andere ingame-Hilfe gibt und das Spiel sich nicht zäh in die Länge zieht.

"Line up the toy soldiers, two hundred abreast. The bravest of brave, the best of the best. Wind up the toy soldiers to march on their way. The city is fallen, no reason to stay. Two hundred abreast, my sisters and brothers. Now only three left, forget all the others." 

Primordia is a point and click adventure game that more than rivals titles like "I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream, Machinarium, Botanicula, etc." It takes place in a post human world, where advanced AI have claimed what is left of the wasteland that is the planet. 

The voice acting in this game is top notch, incorporating even the talents of Logan Cunningham. The characterization of the entire cast though, hinges on the environment they are thrust in. And how each sentience has chosen to deal with their circumstances. 

The game itself is quite serious in tone and changes in severity depending on which ending you achieve. Though there are many breaks from this dark nature when Horatio and Crispin interact with one another, often ending in clever word play or sarcastic optimism. It's something I hope they continue with a sequel or a run off featuring different characters. This is the type of game that would make a wonderful animation on the silver screen.

12334122.review:
A fantastic point-and-click adventure brimming with atmosphere and clever puzzle design, with barely any flaws to speak of.
So let's get those out of the way first. The biggest flaw is that the game occasionally has pixel-hunting puzzles, which are never good. Bad developers. Only time in the game I looked at guides was when I was missing something from pixel hunting (random LCD screen, bah, random floating junk, what even?)
The palette's also a bit dull overall; I get the point of having so much brown but it gets a little tiring to look at after a while, though the game's gorgeous looking otherwise.
That aside, only the postitives left. The two protagonist characters each have quite a bit of personality to them and play off each other well for plenty of amusing moments, though the game still keeps a fairly serious and dark tone throughout. The other various characters are all quite unique and memorable and serve the overall plot in interesting ways, usually having their own mini-arcs. The backstory and worldbuilding is also very rich, not outright saying a lot but leaving the pieces scattered for the player to put together. 
The puzzles are also generally good. Plenty of the standard item-trading things but there's no moon logic present there. And there's straight up logic puzzles on occasion, too, which are probably the most fun. There's no need to memorize strings of numbers or information, either; the game auto-saves all relevant data in the main character's datapouch, as well as providing a map for quick travel. It's got a lot of old-school adventure game design with a more modern feel to it, making it both well-crafted and elegant in execution.
There's a lot to like here and little to dislike, I heavily recommend it to, well, pretty much anyone really, but especially point-and-click enthusiasts, because this is certainly top-tier in that regard.

12295147.review:

12191160.review:
I would really like to recommend this game but I simply can't.  Despite the unique story, amazing voice acting, and fun universe it all took a back seat to the puzzle aspect of the game.

I'm no stranger to adventure games.  I've always been a fan of these types of games but Primordia simply doesn't do it for me.  I found the puzzles to be frustrating and counter intuitive.

Part way through the game I ran into a game breaking bug that caused it to be impossible to continue without a guide.  After an hour of rubbing things on other things and clicking on every pixel I did the unthinkable and went to a guide only to find out I've run into a somewhat common glitch.  On this Steam forum I see a post from one of the writers/designers for the game say "Sigh. If we ever do another patch, I'll make sure it gets fixed."  This is my ulitmate woe with the indy developer.  I pay for the game and I would hope that known bugs would be fixed.  I don't like to hear "IF we ever do another patch."  A bug in an adventure game isn't like most other games.  You don't always know there is a problem.  You just keep trying to solve the puzzle till you give up or turn to a guide.  For me that ruined half the experience.  Now every time I get stuck I wonder if I'm wasting my time because of another bug or did I forget to pick up a cup of coffee three screens back.

TLDR:  If you want the game then get it for the story and the art and not the puzzles.

12178106.review: I really loved Primordia it took me back to the days when Sierra, Revolution and Lucas Arts created some truly unique games and Primordia stands perfectly in their company. The voice acting is very good and there is a lot of humorous references to pop, computing and gaming culture. Primordia gives the player many choices for a game in this genre with various ways to solve puzzles and multiple endings that have very different outcomes. A few puzzles might be considered difficult, but most will keep you entertained without causing frustration. It took me about 8 hours to finish before going back to try different solutions to see the all the endings. I think Primordia is well worth the asking price and I found it more enjoyable than some newer click adventures 2-3 times more expensive. If you enjoyed games like Beneath A Steel Sky, The Dig or Ring World you won't be disappointed in Primordia.

12059002.review:
This game has an excellent story and a unique and interesting setting filled with charmingly colorful characters.  It is thoughtful and meaningful, and addresses some serious theological and philosophical points, while remaining mysterious and exciting (most of the time).  However, I found the gameplay to be very lacking, in a number of ways.  I'm now going to complain about all the things I need to complain about, but do please recall that I actually enjoyed this game :)

The puzzles in this game were difficult, and not in a good way.  While many of them had "cool" solutions - which would be awesome in a movie, for example - they were often not cleanly solvable, in the sense that they were the only plausible solution and made everything "make sense" when you figured it out.  For me, a lot of the reason I want to play a puzzle game is for that awesome feeling of everything coming together when I figure it out.  This is not the sort of game that does that for me.  Here's a few of the problems that I saw:

1. Trying to create a clever solution rather than a good puzzle.  The solutions to puzzles are often the sort of zany solutions that are fun to watch heroes think of in movies, but not reasonable to force the player to think of.  In other words, they don't feel like THE solution, just A solution (and yet in the confines of the game, they are THE solution).
2. Tooooo many items.  Unlike a lot of games, in Primordia you almost never get an item taken out of your inventory when you are done using it.  By the end of the game, I have so much stuff in my inventory that the task of getting through a locked door has dozens of reasonable-sounding solutions - crowbar, plasma torch, signal transmitter to pick the lock, etc, etc - but only one of them is right (and it's probably none of the standard things I've learned how to do throughout the game, because that would be to easy).
3. Generic, reusable items.  This is one of my pet peeves in puzzle games.  When you have a generic item like a hammer, there's a trillion and five ways that the player can think of to use this item.  Even if the game designer could think of all of those, allowing those solutions would make many of their puzzles too easy.  Anyway, this game is full of generic items that you use again and again throughout the game (but are never allowed to use when you think of it).
4. Confusing items.  I had a whole bunch of electronic gadgets and doodads that it took me a long time to figure out how they worked - a signal transmitter, a decryption device, a memory reader, etc.  All of these could be used only in very specific circumstances (i.e. as far as I can tell, the memory reader can only be used to access memories from a severed robot head - which you encounter in this game a lot more than you would think!), but this information is never explicitly told to you (I never really figured out what the rules for the decryption device were).
5. Just too much going on at once.  The game is basically divided into two parts.  During each part, you slowly unlock more areas, and then can travel freely between all areas that you have unlocked during that part, which by the end of each part results in a huge environment in which to look for a small number of remains tasks.

The end result of all of this was that I played the game with a walkthrough constantly ready.  And I do not regret it :)  Most of the things I had to get help on ("most" because I started getting lazy near the end), I think I would have felt frustrated rather than satisfied if I took the time to solve myself.

The interface is unfathomably archaic and unintuitive.  For example, the process of using an item - one of the most base necessities of a point and click game - requires (1) hovering near the top of the screen to open the tool bar, (2) selecting the inventory button to open your inventory, (3) selecting the item from the inventory, (4) clicking outside the inventory to close it, then finally (5) clicking on the thing in the world that you want to use the item on.  On all the interfaces mentioned, there are also many confusing and sometimes unnecessary/duplicate buttons.  The datachron (which automatically takes notes on things you have learned) has a horrific interface that looks something like an old school gameboy, with giant text on a tiny screen, and buttons (that you have to click with your mouse) for scolling up and down.  Similarly, the signal transmitter - on which you frequently need to set a 4-digit number to transmit - is pretty obnoxious, requiring you to click on the left and right sides of two dials (not even buttons that you can see, so it's hard to find the sweet spot to actually click on) - one to cycle through numbers, and one to cycle through DIGITS.  DIGITS.

All that being said, however, I think this game is definitely worth playing for the story alone, which like I said is fantastic.

12012483.review:
10/10

Hosszú idő óta az első point-and-click kalandjáték, ami teljesen magával ragadott. 
Története a Földön játszódik. A bolygót a folyamatos háborúk tönkretették, míg végül maguk az emberek is elpusztultak. Már csak az általuk épített robotok maradtak, akik igyekeznek túlélni, fejlődni, új robotokat építeni. Az ember, lassan már csupán egy rég letűnt kor isteneként van jelen, akihez egyes fanatikusabb robotok imádkoznak, míg mások azt is tagadják, hogy ember valaha létezett. 
Nagyon megragadott ez a különleges jövőkép, amibe a készítők a történetüket helyezték. Sok játékosnak szimpatikus, ha a főhős nem ember (nekem is) és itt ez a helyzet. Főhősünk egy magányos robot, Horatio, aki a sivatag közepén próbál életben maradni egy hajóroncsban, amit az idők során berendezett otthonának. Később épített magának társaságot, egy Crispin nevű, kis lebegő segédet... aki a játék humorforrása lesz, ugyanis valami programozási csoda folytán, rendkívül szemtelen személyiséget fejlesztett ki magának :)
Ám békés életük hirtelen veszélybe kerül, mikor egy idegen robot lyukat robbant otthonuk falán és ellopja az energia-magot, ami táplálja őket és a hajó rendszereit. Horatio és Crispin pedig kénytelen, a túléléük érdekében, a tolvaj után eredni Metropolba, az Utolsó Városba. Mire kellhet a tolvajnak az energia-mag? Miért fél Horatio a városba menni? Milyen veszély fenyegeti őket a "biztonságos menedék"-nek hirdetett Metropolban?

A történet tökéletességéről zengedezhetnék még, de innentől rátok bízom a felgöngyölítését. 
A pixeles grafika senkit ne ijesszen el! Ez csupán tisztelgés a régi nagy kalandjátékok előtt, melyek szerintem kérdés nélkül maguk közé fogadnák a Primordiát. Nem mellesleg, az összkép igenis szép, illő a lepusztult, poszt-apokaliptikus hangulathoz.

A végigjátszás során összesen egyetlen egy feladványál futottam bele a "pixelvadászat" elkerülhetetlen hibájába. Ez az egyetlen negatívum, amit felhozhatok.  

Játékidő szempontjából annyit mondanék: egy jó film hosszúságának felel meg. 

Ajánlom? Ajánlom. 
Mindenkinek, aki szeretne hallani egy különleges történetet és szereti ezt a műfajt.

11998874.review:
Overall this is a sad case of a game with brilliant elements but too many faults to make it an enjoyable experience. It has the best sense of humour of just about any game I have played. The story is good, though some of the elements don't fit together.

The problems are:  

1/ the graphics are terrible. Yes, they have a cute, arty style but they are ridiculously low resolution. 

2/ The mechanics are clunky, with slow menus and too much time watching pixellated figures crossing the screen painfully slowly. 

3/ Some of the puzzles are good, but a lot of the time I had to use a walkthrough not because a puzzle was difficult but because the game is inconsistent. Most exits are identified by mousing over, but some are only identified if you move the character to the edge of the screen. There is a system of storing info useful for solving puzzles but some of the info stored is irrelevant and some vital info is not stored. To combine items in inventory you pick up A and mouse it over B. You get a message telling you that's a dumb idea, but it turns out you need to pick up B and mouse it over A.

11946289.review:
Primordia is a point and click adventure game set in a post-apocalyptic world strewn with pieces of machinery.  You play as Horatio Nullbuild, who has a rather peaceful existence ruined when a powerful robot steals the power source of his ship.  Horatio and his companion Crispin leave their home and head for the city of glass and light - Metropol.  Here, you will uncover secrets of your past and gain a better understanding of humans who previously walked there.

Primordia does not reinvent the genre, it is a sci fi adventure game that offers a dark and meaningful story - something lost in some modern point and click games.  The game provides excellent atmosphere, a rich script, solid puzzles and an art style that is really captivating.  It is the sort of game that tries to restore the classic point and click genre and I believe it has truly nailed it.  It feels like the 90's, but shows that with careful animations, voice acting and intricate details, that 'modern' resolutions and graphics are not always necessary.

I wanted to find out more and had to see the different endings, take different paths and look for more information online.  The only fault would be that it is perhaps too short, especially if you are used to classic adventure games.  Some puzzles were pretty difficult and there were a few moments of "That doesn't make much sense", though that's something I always expect from these games.

It is not really going to interest people who don't play point and click games.  It is for people who miss games like The Dig, Beneath a Steel Sky and maybe even the classic Fallout games (in terms of atmosphere).  It has replay value, great soundtrack, top storytelling and is certainly difficult enough to stump you in a few places.  Highly recommended.

11865661.review: Possibly the best point and click adventure I've played in a decade. Certainly the best modern one. Nostalgic and yet refreshingly new. Cleverly written, and chock full of enjoyable characters. The puzzles followed a logic that was immediately understandable, but still required creativity to solve. In short, I loved it.

11572241.review:
First the good: Nice world, nice graphics, reasonable story, adequate voice acting.

Now the bad: Arbitrary puzzles, extemely linear, except for the magic points you should save to redo different "paths" for the achievements, terrible obvious boring ending, unskippable credit sequence that doesn't even respect alt-F4, and worst of all it just not fun.

Constructive advice to the devs: Don't make your hint bot refuse to give hints, especially in a snarky tone. Make your puzzles actually make sense. Tell the player when the path of a mostly linear game is going to diverge. Better yet, auto-save right before that divergence. Allow the player to be the hero at the end. Choosing "I'll never join you!" should not end with a crap series of still screens and the player losing to the big bad.

Constructive advice to people who play it: Use a walkthrough. The first part is pretty decent but the city is just silly and arbitrary. And you'll never get the achievements without a walkthrough, unless you click everything always forever in the right order (including not talking to someone when you first meet them!).

11504144.review:
Si eres de los que vivió la época dorada de las aventuras gráficas, deja de quejarte por los rincones como un viejo cascarrabias y juega a "Primordia", una aventura gráfica con píxeles como puños que te devolverá a los 90.
La historia se centra en un mundo postapocalíptico plagado de robots donde tú eres Horatio. Sí, eres un robot, no el flipado de CSI. El caso es que un robot con apariencia de caja de zapatos voladora te roba el núcleo de energía de tu nave, así que ya sabes, ¡a buscar!
Durante la aventura irás acompañado de un cacharro volador llamado Crispin, que hará las funciones del típico escudero dando pie a conversaciones graciosas o bien facilitarte pistas.
El juego no es de humor. Tiene un tono serio-decadente, pero apto para todos los públicos.
Los gráficos son calcados a los de los 90. Pixelacos de los buenos. La música también está genial. Vamos, que de poco salgo a comprarme una mano-loca al kiosko del revíval noventero que me ha dado.
El juego en sí es corto, pero como la dificultad en algunos puntos es jodidilla, pues seguro que se te hace algo más largo.
Probablemente, tal y como están las aventuras gráficas actualmente, "Primordia" no ocupe el lugar que merece. Ahora, mientras me invento un futuro utópico donde este juego ocupa un lugar especial en el mundo del videojuego, aprovechad para sacar vuestra tarjeta bancaria y comprar el juego, ¿o vais a compraros un enésimo FIFA?

[b]La historia parece demasiado simple. ¿De verdad es bueno?[/b] En ese caso, lo siento, oh gran cerebro, siento comunicarte que este juego no tiene la cantidad de millones de giros de guion como para que te guste. No lo juegues.
[b]Me refiero a que va de unos robot buscando un "núcleo de energía". ¿No es demasiado típico?[/b] No te quedes con eso. Lo bueno del juego se saborea jugando, no leyendo la crítica de un tío que no conoces de nada.

11496207.review:

I've played a lot of point'n click, and besides the fact that some others as Machinarium and Botanicula are pretty amazing, this one was for me, by far, the best one I've ever done. 11489930.review:
Primordia, a point and click adventure game that has quite good story with challenging puzzles. More or less like The Cat Lady... the good and the bad. To sum it up:

Pros:
- Great/Mature story
- Multiple endings
- Challenging puzzles... to the point I required help from walkthrough *ahem*
- Funny dialogues
- Great voice actors
- Decent price point

Bad:
- Weak graphic engine, seriously. I even had a Developer helped me to get the game up and running.
- Art isn't up to my standard.
- A bit short game (approx 5 hours), but for 2.5 USD when discounted/on sale (or bundled), well... I guess  can't be helped.

The gameplay is just another point and click adventure. You pick up one object, deliver it to one character, get another item to unlock another area... rinse and repeat. You also are required to pay attention to hints collected. Not so much new invention in this aspect.

Story, well, I can't say much without spoiling anything, but the story is interesting enough. In fact, I wouldn't have completed the game had the story been bad. It's like, again, The Cat Lady - light story in the beginning and developing slowly until the finale.

Soundtrack is so-so, not that good but not that bad. Voice actors, however, are top notch. They really portray the characters well. Oh yes, don't forget about hilarious exchanges between Horatio and Chrispin throughout the game. More often than not I laughed on many occasions thanks to that funny Chrispin. 

Overall, Wormwood Studios, I think, have a success creating a good game for us all. Moreover, they are willing to interact and listen to their playerbase as well: see  [url=http://steamcommunity.com/app/227000/discussions/0/38596748079663186/]here[/url]. I wish them luck with their future projects, too bad it won't be Primordia 2 (as has been said by the Developer himself).

Recommended game.

11459705.review: This is an absolutely fantastic point and click adventure. I am so happy to find a great little treasure such as this. Genuine storytelling is hard to find it seems like, and this has that dusty wasteland / rusty robot feeling to it that our post-modern imaginatinos crave.

11458544.review:
So first things first, i did not finish this game. I liked it, but there came a time when i said enough was enough. I gave up on the game not because it's broken, no because the stories bad, and not because it's a bad game. I stopped because i couldn't stand some design choices made by the developer. If you don't have a problem with some of the issues i have with this game, then it might be a better game then i let on.

This game is good, the stories a bit so-so (i am not a sci-fi fan, so this may not be the case for you), but there is a depth to the world that makes exploration satisfying. For an adventure game (and a sci-fi), it's not bad. Adventure games are usually sold based on their stroy, or their atmosphere and world; this one falls squarely with the interesting world brand of adventure games. It takes a serious stance to its story, so if you wanted another monkey island-ish adventure game, keep looking. The visuals are solid, and what humor there is (mainly in the form of referenceses, such as the crowbar) isn't very satisfying, but it's harmless. 

Where the game lost me is its choice on puzzle design. There comes a time when you have to do some tasks, like convince 2 robots to stop arguing. The problem i have with it is they don't give you the information for long, so you either have to write it down or memorize it. Only after writing it down can you try to solve the riddle. It's a bit backwards, where you have to work around outdated, missing, or omited mechanics to get to the puzzle before you've even had a chance to ponder it. There is a device that records important pieces of information, but what it deems as important can be hit or miss sometimes (such as the robot diologue riddles, where the riddles aren't written down). 

The game also does a very poor job of giving hints if your stuck. This problem, and a few others, are indicitive of the genre. One such problem is having puzzles where you have to guess at what the developer wanted you to use to progress. An example would be ruining soup in some adventure game, where you have mud, shoe polish, and a rat. Only one will ruin the soup, despite all of them being viable in a realist sense. 

In the end, this is an adventure game, so replayability is already low. I'd rather not waste my time reruning the same diologue trees over and over, which is what i found i had to do for the robot riddle puzzles. If I couldn't write fast enough (cus memorizing the jargen and name drops was not easy), i would have to guess and restart. There are i believe 5 riddles or so, so having to restart from the 4th on can be annoying to say the least. At this point, the game felt more like work then fun, so i gave up on it. I didn't want to put in that much effort for what i felt was not enough in return. 

You are expected to bring a lot to the table to get through the game. Good memory, write stuff down, and replay the same section over if you experiment. You will find that trying to force your way through diologue puzzles is very time consuming. If you get stuck and fall back on this, you might feel inticed to cheat (as i was). When i feel like i have to resort to a walkthrough to make progress, the game begins to feels like a chore. It's not fun when you have to use a walkthrough for an adventure game, because relying on it really takes you out of the world. Personally, i call it quits at that point, as i did here

To reiterate, this is not a bad game. It's a game with a vision that i fell outside of. If you played a lot of old-school adventure games, or you're a sci-fi fan, you might find a lot to like. If you find you didn't like older adventure games (or Daedelic's brand of adventure games, like The Dark Eye or Memoria), or you gravitate towards newer games like the Telltale brand of adventure games, this game may not be to you're liking.

If an old-school sci-fi adventure game with some of the problems of older games, as well a bit unforgiving approach to game design (in that you will solve problems for yourself, without more help then the developer deems nessassary) sound good to you, then this might be a game you will enjoy.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If anyone should wonder why the developer of the game commented on this review (i was very suprised about it, personally), it's because he questioned some of my reasons for quiting, as well as questioning why i would post a review of a game i played so little of. After being initially pissed, i thought a lot about the review and realized how many assuptions i had taken as fact. I heavily edited the review after i thought about it, namely because the initial review didn't convey what i wanted it to; this game was not for me, for the reasons listed above, but it might be the game for you depending on your tastes. 

The developer didn't harrass me (though initially i thought he had), and i am changing this review because i feel like it. Mark was a decent guy, and he responded more calmly and professionally then i thought he would. I made the changes i did because i was initially wrong, the developer earned my respect, and i had gone back over the review and found it unsatisfactory. If you think this makes my review less reliable, then so be it. You have been informed.

11458285.review: For those who grew up on the point and click adventure games of old (Monkey Island, Full Throttle, et cetera), they aren't dead - you just need to know where to look. To those who haven't, point and clicks are largely narrative-driven games based upon exploration and puzzles - and this game has all three in spades. Intriuging setting? Done. Tough, but (almost always) fair, puzzles? Done. A compelling narrative? Oh yeah. This game has all of two downsides - first, that clues are sprinkled into the dialogue, but there isn't a way to reexamine or replay it, so sometimes you're left guessing. Second, the game is short - but this is more of a nitpick than anything, because its actual length belies the completeness which the game concludes with. Ultimately, this is a great work by a talented team, and the only real reason you wouldn't like it is because you don't like point and click adventures.

11349131.review:
I'm not giving a thumbs down because I out and out dislike the game - I'm not not entirely sure if it's worth the trailer hype and full price purchase given the shortcomings. Feels like a spiritual successor of sorts to Beneath A Steel Sky, something I'm surprised more people didn't pick up on. Visually it all works and the music pleasantly chugs along - Along with some humour from Horatio and Crispin.

Here's the problem though; Just as the game allows you to get more comfortable and eager to explore the story more, it stops becoming fun. The middle section of the game has some painful 'swap this for that' puzzle sequences that become a chore, and you are only driven to continue because of the story, and trust me, you will be looking at a walkthrough at some point, some of the puzzles are too obtuse.

It also ends far too soon - overall only having 2 main environments in the whole game is not that satisfying at all, and what could have been quite atmospheric starts to feel a little brownwashed. The character development was never built up long enough for me to feel any emotional connections with the characters, and there were some uninspired and cliched plot turns. Beneath A Steel Sky never varied too much in environment either but at least it stayed enjoyable right to the end. There are multiple paths in the game to take which will lead to different endings - but it really depends on whether you enjoyed the first run to want to do this, and I'm not entirely sure if I want to play this game again for a while. Shame there's no windowed mode either, can appreciate the Lucasarts style resolution/graphics decision but couldn't easily leave the window or tweak anything.

I'm not saying it's a bad game, trust me, it isn't - I would just suggest you wait for it to go on sale, as there's a chance you could be disappointed like I was.

11344116.review:
Overall satisfying adventure game with only a few caveats.  Most of all I recommend this game.  

Pros: 
• Thought-provoking story full of moral ambiguities and juxtaposed viewpoints making you question your own judgments of the characters and their actions.
• Good interface with a minimum of unnecessary clicking and waiting.
• Varied endings dependant on choices made by the player.
• Interesting scenery, good voice acting, and excellent atmosphereic soundtrack.

Cons: 
• Completely unnecessary gender references at various points.  It's a world full of robots... Why does there need to be a "female" robot with boob-curves, or gender binary relationship references between androgynous mechanoids?
• Serious tone somewhat undermined by numerous 4th-wall jokes by  a main character.
• Lots of back-tracking and occasionally preposterous leaps in logic were needed to solve puzzles.  Several times I found myself resorting to "randomly combine junk until something happens" or having to look up walkthroughs, and being utterly baffled how someone would arrive at that solution.

As stated above, I do highly recommend this game, and I enjoyed the story.  You should check it out!

11332663.review: Definitely recommend to fans of this genre. Beautiful artwork, great sound and atmosphere with interesting characters and an engaging story in a world that made me think of the Matrix more than once. Which is a good thing.

This game surprised me. I went in expecting another tedious point-n-click, but was quickly sucked into the world that is Primoridia. You play a robot named Horatio that is on a quest for the rather simple goal of finding his home's battery. What ensues is a storyline that unveils a history and lore rooted in a mixture of "God and his creation", aiming forward with questions of freewill and the role of the State within a society. All the while, Horatio simply wants his power core. 

A brilliant, rich and enticing game. It asks more questions that it answers, while playing with your imagination and leaves you wanting more from this universe. All in all, if you're looking for a game that challenges your logic and problem-solving skills, while experiencing a well-developed world and excellent cast of characters, look no further.

7/10

Backgrounds full of rich details, as a subtle score carries you from scene to scene, each character I met was -interesting- and -entertaining-...ohh Primordia... you welcomed me kindly and at times I was deeply impressed with you. The story is very engaging but the ending left me a bit bored with it all.  The "action" scenes are almost comical and felt clumsy. 11133804.review: Primordia is quite good overall. Among its best assets are its strong sense of style and its audio.  Both the music and the voice acting are excellent. 11119789.review:
I liked it a lot. It's dark and grim. It's about "Horatio Nullbuilt", a somewhat stoic and secretive humanoid robot living alone in some long-stranded organic-looking airship in the middle of some barren brown desert. Humans are long gone, only machines remain, some worship them - or their legacy - in a secluded and lonesome manner as Horatio does. He has a self-built low-grade flying companion robot, "Crispin Horatiobuilt", who is an obvious sidekick, who keeps refering to himself as that and who is supposed to be a constant contrast to his builder for he is not as nearly withdrawn as him but more humorous, even on a meta-like level for example when he comments your futile efforts to do the same thing over and over and expecting different results.

There are more interesting characters to see. All kinds of machines who inhabit the few remaining places in the world. Be it a bomb from some long-past war that never detonated and which is worshipped for it is a creation of man, the remains of colossal titan robots buried deep within the desert or old human cities maintained by robots just enough not to collapse totally.

Primorida is a middle-scaled adventure for what I can tell. It has an interesting story, great characters, powerful voice acting (every character is voiced - and those robots who cannot talk bleep around in their own manner) and a significant amount of puzzling too. If I remember right I had to look up a walkthrough a few times, though I guess I was just blind on one eye for the solutions seemed reasonable afterwards. There are several endings, they all seem fitting and interesting in their way, and while the decision which you will see is made very lately in the game it is still somewhat relevant what you do mid-game. 

There is a significant amount of lore background. You will meet characters who share their stories and views on the world. You will learn more about them, their motivations and failures. There is a robot society that kinda imitates human society. It has it's own leadership and entities. However barely anything about is perfect. It is in demise, and Horatio is trying to find his way through. He is connected to the world around him more than he admits, and getting to know him better was done very well I think, from robots remembering him to data logs hidden within the places he visits. The art is nice, there are some great dark or soothing music tunes, everything seemed crafted together well and I thought I was satisfied with all aspects of the game even though it has been a long while since I've played it. Definitely the best adventure from Wadjet Eye Games I've played thus far.

11101742.review: Amazing game ! The atmosphere , characters and the soundtrack , everything works so damn well together , this game is addictive. I can only recommend it. Sure there were slightly annoying parts in the puzzles , but overall I think this game deserves to be played with .

A lot of things make this game brilliant. Besides being REALLY challenging and seemingly have multiple ways to solve a puzzle, it's story makes it an adventure, that is a joy to follow. Si tengo que resumir este juego en una frase sería "aventura gráfica de principios de los  90)". Sorprende que una aventura grafica así sea lanzada en 2012. En más de una ocasión me ha dado la sensacion que este juego fue un proyecto abandonado en 1992 y alguien lo pudo rescatar en el siglo XXI.

Sobre la parte artística se nota que se ha trabajado muy bien. Una gran ambientación, una comicidad que te puede recordar a las antiguas aventuras gráficas de lucas arts. 
Un apartado sonoro correcto, una musica que te sumerge. Unas voces bien elegidas. Si tengo que poner alguna pega en esta parte... Es que me habría gustado ver más primeros planos de los personajes, me ha llamado mucho su estilo artístico. Para terminar, hay ciertos finales que no han conseguido encajar con la historia ( da la sensacion que los autores querían darte a elegir un final más que la coherencia argumental, Horatio es ante todo un buen chico).

Donde flojea es en el apartado técnico. Apenas tiene opciones de configuración. No puedo ejecutar el juego en ventana, no puedo modificar la resolucion del juego. Tampoco puedes modificar la velocidad de los subtitulos. El juego es terriblemente corto. En unas 20-30 horas tendras todos los logros.

¿Merece la pena comprarlo ?
compralo si :

- Te gusta la ciencia ficcion
- Te gustan las antiguas aventuras graficas
- Esta rebajado. Actualmente, pedir 10 € por este juego me parece demasiado ( lo compre por una oferta de verano a 2,99 €)
- No te importa jugar en inglés (está subtitulado)

10649990.review: Chilling and beautiful atmosphere, gripping story, lovable characters (most of the time), and interesting puzzles. This is my fave indie game so far.

10626313.review:
This was my first point and click game, and really it made me like the genre.

The story is very interesting from start to finish.  You play as Horatio Nullbuilt version 5.  A robot sort of obsessed with fixing things, building things and correcting problems.  He lives aboard his ship with his creation Crispin Horatiobuilt version 1.  They live in the middle of a wasteland aboard the UNNIIC, a crashed ship with a long lasting power source.  That and the nearby scrap gives them all they need to survive.  A problem arises when that power source is stolen from them though and they have to find a way to get it back before they run out of juice and are shut down forever.  

The story just gets more interesting from there as you meet more and more interesting, very well written I should add, characters and solve some very interesting puzzles and problems.

None of the puzzles are overly difficult, with each having a sensible solution.  Nothing like I had always heard point and click games can be, with solutions that are so removed from reality you pretty much have to have a walkthrough to beat it unless you are supremely patient.

the fact that there is several endings as well as a way to alter the best ending slightly by how you play is quite wonderful.

All told the game shouldnt take you very long.   4-5 hours give or take allowing for some time to get stuck on what to do next I think.  Shorter if you are really fast, with some replayability in terms of endings and getting the achievements.  

If you like well written stories give it a go.

Personally this rates very high with me and I look forward to whatever this dev puts out in future.  

Well worth full price in my opinion.
