10490444.review:
UPDATE (June 2017): 
After replaying Primordia again, I have decided to keep my review as a negative one. I was simply more frustrated than I was intrigued and I found the puzzles to be exceedingly obtuse. I consider myself to be a very patient person, especially when it comes to video games and puzzles. However, I really could not get through this game. Some problems' solutions were just nonsensical and when I finally figured them out (a few took over 30 minutes of me just randomly clicking and searching), I was even more frustrated by the fact that they were supposed to be solved in that manner.

To give specific examples, [spoiler] the oil on the table that Oswald is drinking was extremely misleading. Crispin tells you that he saw oil in that area to clean the gears and that's the only oil you can actually interact with. Horatio says that Oswald won't let you take it, so it leads you to believe that you must do something to obtain it. However, you are supposed to give the gears to the shopkeeper, even though Horatio says something along the lines of, "There's no point in talking to him." It took me about half an hour to finally stumble upon the idea of giving it to the shopkeeper arm, because I had done just about everything else possible. Additionally, the floating pile of junk in the underworks that contains Oswald's chain and the Gospel of Man is hardly distinguishable from the gunk around it. It would be nice if the pile shined every few seconds or something to indicate that it's not just another collection of useless garbage in the Underworks. Or you could even have Crispin say something like "I thought I saw something shiny by the bridge where Clarity shot that husk." Also, the transmission code that you have to send to Factor "0518" was quite confusing considering you were given the code "518" and you only have a 4-digit transmitter. Of course, "0518" seems like the sensible first thing to do, but previously in the game when you were given a 3-digit code, you had to find the prefix number for it; "0XXX" would not work. My final gripe, where I stopped in this most recent playthrough, is the "Redlien" haiku in the kiosk terminal. Not only is it obscure and seemingly meaningless, Crispin's 'advice' is something similar to [i] it seemed like you could read that Redline poem in two different ways [/i], as if that helps at all. It didn't. I think I spent another 30 minutes on the "Redlien" puzzle, just rereading it and clicking on Crispin a bunch of times to no avail. [/spoiler] I eventually decided I wasn't having any fun and I should just stop. I should mention that I really enjoy the story as well as the writing. Horatio and Crispin are extremely likeable when they aren't repeating 'clues' that don't help with the puzzles. I [i] really [/i] wanted to enjoy this game; if I didn't I wouldn't have replayed it. I simply couldn't get over the confusing puzzles. Maybe I would recommend this for someone who doesn't mind reading a walkthrough every step of the way, but I just didn't have much fun playing this.

 

Original Review (June 2014):
Primordia is a point and click game that has beautiful artwork and immersive music. The story is enjoyable and I encountered zero bugs. The characters are well-developed and the occasional humor is pretty funny. Sounds awesome, right? Well, there's just one problem: I didn't have fun. As I played I felt more annoyed by the puzzles than I felt happy that I completed them. Because as soon as you fix a problem, PLOP new thing for you to fix! At first, Crispin's (your comedic companion) hints helped but when you get farther he seems to just tell you what you already know. The items you must obtain are typically in places that you wouldn't expect, and the hitboxes for them are typically small. This game just drives you to the point where you try to use every item on every object, even if it doesn't make sense, to see if that will work. I found myself sitting there trying to combine my crowbar with my memory pouch. What will that do? Nothing. But I HAD to try it because I've done everything else. And then it turns out all you had to do was something simple but there was no way you could have known about it. This game has so many amazing qualities; I wanted to like it so bad. But I just couldn't. It's just not fun. Overall, I just found this game more frustrating than satisfying. If you've got the ten bucks and you LOVE point and click puzzle adventures, go for it. You might like it. But for the average gamer, I cannot recommend this game.

10478192.review:
Muy buen juego. Es una aventura grafica al mejor estilo del Monkey Island 2, pero con varias cosas que la destaca.
Tiene varios puzzles que te hacen usar los sesos, y no son cuestion de probar todo tu inventario con todo. Ademas tiene multiples finales y, en ocaciones, se pueden seguir distintos caminos para resolver el mismo problema.
La historia me gusto mucho y los personajes en general son muy interesantes, tu compañero le da un toque humoristico aunque el tono en general es bastante serio.
Lo compre bastante barato, por lo que fue una agradable sorpresa ver que tenia dialogos totalmente hablados, lo cual es raro en aventuras de este precio. Además de los dialogos, el sonido y la ambientacion son bastante buenas.

10434250.review:
I've been playing a lot of indie point-and-clicks lately; Primordia stands out because of its writing and setting. It has a LucasArts Loom vibe to it, with the protagonist Horation NullBuilt conjuring up an idea of what Bobin Threadbare would be if he was competent and decided to use his amnesia to his advantage. Yes, both characters have amnesia, have lost their home communities, and the fabric of society quite literally rests on their creations. Elements of the story definitely seem similar. The setting of Primordia is more exciting. It's a colorful combination of dystopia, cyberpunk, and steampunk. While that mix is becoming more and more common these days, finding 'good' games in that genre is still rare.

I mentioned the writing: the story is captivating if only to explore the lore, and the main plot-arc is mediocre. The dialog writing is where the game shines; Horatio's sidekick levitating robot Crispin is a very well written NPC that integrates into the game nicely. The character is used to solve some puzzles, though not too much, and offers rather direct walkthrough-type tips if the protagonist is stuck.

With it's marvelous writing, I wanted Primordia to feature more NPCs and dialog quests. A particular stand-out quest involves a logic puzzle attempting to legally assign the surname of a pet robot. While the logic is difficult to follow without pen and paper handy, the writing and voice-acting attempts to seduce the player away from choosing the logical option and I was tempted to go down a logically-flawed path (which the game teased would result in different endings and impact late-game quests). Rarely does game-dialog inspire this anymore, and it is where indie games such as Primordia stand a cut above the rest.

The game has a relatively short playthrough and the puzzles become more difficult, sometimes to the level of ridiculousness, later in the game. This is caused by the game too early allowing me to use multiple items for different quests, and in the late game suffering through trying every permutation of item combination to solve the puzzles. Nonetheless, I would recommend this game to a casual or hardcore adventure gamer, as it is both enjoyable and tells a well-written, albeit cliche story.

I'm sorry to say that I was rather disappointed with this game. I think the trailer made me expect too much from it (what else is new). And the first half of the game itself made me expect too much from the second half. I can't really say how without spoiling, unfortunately. Let's just say that I expected some pretty grand moments that the game never even came close to delivering. But I would still recommend this game, as parts of the story are pretty interesting and some of the puzzles and conversations are cool.

I do have to talk about Crispin though. It feels like they tried to make a Wheatley-esque character who follows you everywhere, and is kind of annoying but also endearing and adorable. Unfortunately they made Crispin too much of a smartass, so he comes off as not very endearing, not even remotely adorable, but still quite annoying. His lines also get very tiresome, as they are often just lame puns and jokes, and he doesn't have a very large number of them. And aside from scripted scenes, his comedic presence didn't change in response to the increasingly minatory plot, which often ruined the tone.

Lastly, the voice-acting generally isn't very good. The villain probably has the best voice-acting. The voices themselves? Very good, well-chosen, well-suited to their characters. But the acting itself wasn't very good. It's fairly boring and I got tired of listening to everyone speak pretty quickly. Perhaps this was intentional because they were robots, but you can make someone sound robotic without sacrificing solid, emotive acting (case in point: [i]Portal[/i]).

10023725.review:
Primordia is an attempt at a weighty story that somewhat misses its mark in execution.  As in all adventure games, things start innocently (loosely applied) enough as a giant robot looking like the mobile version of HAL crossed with a lobster (I know, right?) invades your home on a derelict ship and steals your power core.  You, Horatio, from a long line of previous Horatios, must now find a way to retrieve it.  It should be mentioned that everyone in this game, including you, is a robot, and as you begin to explore the world and meet its denizens, you'll find yourself wrapped in a robot existentialist's wetware runtime environment, rolling around in what amounts to be the robotic version of a Kafka story... okay, maybe not that weighty.  There's just something about the ending (of which there are many) that just never seems satisfying, even if you take all the steps to do the 'good' one.  That being said, Primordia still manages to tell its story with care and it's delivered in perfectly-bleak dialogue for a perfectly-bleak world.

Technically, the game suffers a little bit from a few questionable design decisions.  Being (I assume) an homage to the point 'n' click (PNC) games of yesteryear, the developer insisted on a low-res, 2D game - which is great - but instead of doing what most modern games do which is make a hi-res game look low-res, this game is actually 800x600.  This isn't really that big a deal until you notice that often the character sprites don't 'belong' to the scene.  In classic adventure games, different sprites were created depending on where the character is supposed to be standing; in Primordia, the technique used instead is simply scaling down the larger sprite with the end result being a much crisper sprite on a purposely-blocky background.  Not a dealbreaker, but it can be a little bit distracting.

Other design decisions that were made are quite inexcusable in a modern PNC game.  Despite the genre being declared 'dead' for years, the truth is that the genre has thrived (loosely applied) throughout the decades and made many advances, all of which are ignored by Primordia.  For instance, in most modern PNCs, there's a hotspot-highlight button to speed along play; Primordia does not have that.  In most modern PNCs, you can usually double-click an exit to skip the slow plod of the character walking offscreen; Primordia does not have that.  To be fair, it -does- have a map system for quick travel.

Finally, there is what is known as adventure-game-logic and Primordia is rife with it.  If you're unfamiliar with the term, it is a criticism of classic adventure game puzzle solutions and how they often make little logical sense.  For example, if you needed to sharpen a pencil, logic would dictate you find a pencil sharpener, but older adventure games were known for instead making you combine a stick with a piece of glass and some tape in order to whittle the pencil... while you stand in front of a pencil sharpener.  While the puzzles in Primordia aren't quite so asinine, two extremely dense puzzles spring to mind that are just bad ideas.  Like older adventure games, you could totally sit there and work it out and feel that ego boost, but I find it hard to believe that most players won't be looking for a walkthrough when they encounter them.  That being said, most of the game is paced out well so long as you can get your head into that mindframe of the 90s and just tough it out.

All in all, Primordia is an accomplished title and a lot of love went into it, especially in the art department.  For a game entirely populated by artificial beings, there is a sort of haunting organic decay that pierces almost every piece of art in the game.  Similarly, the voice direction is quite good and despite Crispin - your sidekick floaty robot buddy - sounding a hell of a lot like Otacon from Metal Gear Solid (it doesn't fit, believe me), every one of the actors gets what the director is trying to accomplish and paints a beautiful, if desolate, piece of work.

By all accounts, I did not enjoy (but did not dislike) Primordia particularly because I found a lot of the puzzles to be purposely obtuse and the story was not one that resonated with me.  However, that does not make this a bad game and so I cannot possibly give it a thumbs down.  For some people, the story is a mindblowing, harrowing look at the nature of existence, life, its foundations, and its possible future.  It is a fascinating perspective, to be sure, but I was left unsatisfied.

Thus, if you're looking for a new PNC game, there's no reason to steer clear from this one.  What I present above are not detractions, but warnings.  PNC veterans will not bat an eye at anything that goes on in this game, but fans of modern PNC games might find a lot of things in Primordia to be frustrating.  Stick with it and it mostly rewards you - just remember that it's more about the journey than the destination in this one.

9877679.review:
A very strong adventure game in the mold of Day of the Tentacle or King's Quest. One of its features, missing from many other games of this genre, is a subtle hint mechanism to help when you are completely stuck. In the old days, this kind of "stuckness" was a death knell for a game that none of your friends had already beaten. Today, there's a different kind of problem, because you go all too easily to the internet to look up the answer. You do it begrudgingly, the first time, easier the second, and on the third time, you accidentally see how it ends.

But back to the game in specific: a nice balance of humor and seriousness. I dig the universe the story is set in, which brings some pretty serious gravity to the plot, but you have a zany sidekick who really does actually grow on you. The writers did a great job making you care about the characters... who are robots... Addtionally, in stark contrast to many of the "Press a button to select your ending" problems some games have presented us with recently, there are something like ten seperate endings which are... all pretty different.  All in all, bravo, very fun game.

Primordia is the third Wadjet Eye P&C adventure I finished. 

I liked the other two (Gemini Rue; Resonance) for their mature stories, so it is only natural that I would like Primordia as well. But what a nice surprise to say that this game is even better!

Resonance tried cool stuff with the character switching, but I found it confusing at times. I was stuck multiple times in Gemini Rue (which obviously could be me being stupid) and think that the game sometimes had no direction to push the player to.

Primordia is just a pleasant ride from start to finish. Some of the code puzzles are a bit hard, but never frustrating. The story is just great. I loved the dark and gloomy tones and the sarcastic MC. Set in a dying world the game throws all kind of grey moral choices at the player.

Preach the Gospel of Man, fellow robots!

All this helps it feel original, mature and engaging.

9506961.review:
[b][url=http://monthsbehindreviews.blogspot.com/2014/03/primordia.html]Click Here for the Full Review! [/url][/b]

Synopsis: A fantastically simple little adventure game. Explore the ruins of Earth to find the fiend that stole your power crystal, the device you need survive. In the process, find out what happened to man, and your surprising role in the end of the world. Make choices that change the final results of the game, and tackle puzzles that can be, at times, a bit too challenging. Enjoy the humorous back and forth between the main character (voiced by the narrator for Bastion) and his flying sidekick. A great game to play in short bursts if you tend to get stuck, or in a longer sitting if you have the fundamentals of combining items in you inventory together to form the key piece you need.

Multiple playthroughs, or saving at critical moments, are required in order to see all possible endings, of which, there are at least 7, but what happens after those possible ending scenarios depends on what you accomplished during the game - who  you saved, who you let die, etc. Took me about 7 hours during the first playthrough, largely because some of the puzzles are a bit tricky (oh, wait, I can use the Signal Transmitter on that blue light to solve this puzzle...huh.). A second playthrough took about a third of that time. I found the environment and story the game told, as well as the solidness of the gameplay, well worth my $2.50 investment, but it wouldn't be a bad deal to get it for a bit more than that, because I've rated this one 9/10.

9500893.review:
I’m a sucker for graphical adventure games, though they don’t always pan out. All the same, Wadjet Eye hasn’t let me down yet. This one’s a bit of a different take. Basically, the human race is gone and all we’re left with is machines just trying to get by and survive. Unfortunately, there’s not a whole hell of a lot else I can say because I haven’t played this one much.  So why recommend it, then? First and foremost, everything is dripping in ambience.

The artwork, animation, sounds, music…all of it is perfect and fitting. In a way, it almost reminds me of New Vegas in that you are nomadic and are forced into going into “the city” at an eventual point that only serves to further the plot with all kinds of twists.  Nevermind that there are returning voice actors from other Wadjet Eye titles that do an outstanding job and the puzzles are no joke…though not necessarily heavy-handed either. Again, I haven’t played too much into it, but the game is cheap and a definite throwback to earlier graphical adventure titles. I highly recommend it.

9442248.review: Unlike a lot of other adventure games, the puzzles in this one are literal logic puzzles. You play as a robot named Horatio who lives a hermit-ish existance in a post-human world with his little buddy Crispin. All is grand till a mean robot busts up your place and steals your home power supply. So now it's a quest of revenge and such. Great little game. No major issues bug-wise since they've been patched out as far as I can see. I believe it's a total of 6 endings or so. It's not completely linear but there are parts that have to be completed in certain ways if you want the achievements. Late-ish in the game there is an achievement everyone hates that requires you to enter all key words into the kiosk. If you don't have the monocle, don't worry about it yet. I recommend 2 videos on youtube by Tomoch. Write the words he uses down then type them in, don't save half way through. Do exactly what he does. Click the mores on the screen, don't type more. If you do both of those videos by the letter you should get the achievement which many people still cannot get. Achievements aside, this is a golden adventure point & click game with challenging logic puzzles with a dash of humour.

9435328.review: My favorite iteration to date of the classic adventure game. 9252706.review:
Note: I have been informed that the puzzles have been improved since I played.

Primordia is a game about robots.  Unlike Machinarium, it is a very dark and gritty setting.  While that fits the game very well, it makes the artwork quite dull and dreary, amplified by the very low resolution the game runs at.  The story, however, makes good use of the setting and is well-written and even includes multiple endings, but that unfortunately is the extent of the the game that I enjoyed.

Primordia is the best example I have run into of a modern adventure game succumbing to the classic adventure game failing of very confusing and obtuse puzzles.  If you don't already need a guide to complete the story, and you probably will, trying to complete the optional achievements is even worse, essentially necessitating the use of a guide.

It's hard for me to recommend Primordia when there's so many better adventure games to choose from.

9137668.review:
Bottom line: I can recommend this game to fans of the genre, however it is not without it's flaws. It will probably be a rewarding experience if you are willing to approach it charitably. However, there are better games of this kind to play first (Gemini Rue, the Blackwell series and so on).

Pros: A very well crafted and engaging universe, with it's own history and mythology. Some excellent puzzle design in parts. A haunting atmosphere facilitated by a decent soundtrack (probably inspired by Vangelis' Blade Runner music). Fans of Beneath a Steel Sky will find much to like here.

Cons: Impossible to enjoy without a walkthrough on hand to get over the occasional obtuse puzzle solution. Could have done with more blind testing to deal with this, or a more robust hint system. Some of the voice acting feels a little innappropriate in tone - the sidekick character in particular.

8806587.review:
A beautifully pixel-rendered adventure game with a surprisingly deep and almost haunting plot that leaves you pondering well after completion. Players will experience nostalgia as they are transported back to the glory days of point and click adventure games with Primordia's art style, environments, atmosphere, script, voice acting, music, and puzzles. Additionally, the ingenious inclusion of multiple endings and Steam achievements create replay value (seldom seen in this genre) and the main character (Horatio) is wonderfully voiced by none other than Bastion's Logan Cunningham. 

I highly recommend this game to any and all adventure game fans.

8749590.review: This game is amazing. One of the most unique SciFi stories i have ever heard. The world is fantastic and the character are unforgetable. The humor is a geeks dream. Computer nerds will have a ball. If you have any free cash and time Primordia is worth a look. Though i was never into the point and click adventures, Primordia's Imaginative plot and enchanting style pulled my attention every step of the way. The game's puzzles and tech based solutions will challenge your curiosity and cleaver problem solving skills. Though what i have seen so far are single solutions to problems, the non-linear flow of the main chapters of the game are in there own write part of the puzzle, "Where the hell am i going to find and LED Display?", trust me, Primordia will challenge and enchant you. Have a look and Bsod those that pass it up.

8738519.review: Отличный арт, которому мешает слишком щедрая пикселизация. Да, благодаря ей игра выглядит как гость из 90-ых, вызывает чувство ностальгии, но я бы предпочел либо не такие детальные картины, либо пиксели не размером с яблоко. Музыка по большей части незаметная, некоторые треки довольно неплохие, но главное - она ненавязчивая. Озвучка персонажей отличная, хотя порой перебарщивают с обработкой голоса и приходится полагаться исключительно на субтитры. Сами персонажи довольно запоминающиеся, как и мир - сценаристу и правда удалось создать впечатление, что не всё в игре служит исключительно ради геймплея и ГГ. Хотя это порой мешает решать загадки - я нередко зацикливался на объекте, с которым нельзя взаимодействовать и это задерживало решение задач. Да и вообще я двигался по игре рывками - то начинал понимать логику игры, а то бесцельно бродил по локациям по полчаса, пока не натыкался мышкой на объект в пару пикселей или напарник не давал подсказку.

8722014.review:
I recommend this game. However I have to point it isn't going to be the best adventure you have ever played. I really liked how decisions mattered and it's nice to see an adventure willing to take risks and giving more than one solution for most puzzles. It has its faults, but it was still very enjoyable and I would recommend to anyone looking for an adventure to take your time. 

Getting every achievement may take you some time, though playing it more than once is cool for listening to the authors commentaries. So if you're into the games "meta," I extra recommend this to you. The writer namedrops loads of great novels and other games and stories as inspirations that helped shape this game, which only makes it the more sad that this game is only "not bad." Not bad is still recommended in my book.

8611899.review:
A dark but not excessively dramatic game with a slight Planescape: Torment vibe to its atmosphere and side characters. The music is beautiful and well-chosen for the scenes that are meant to get to you (and they really do), and the voices feel spot on for most characters you meet. Some puzzles can get frustrating due to the combination of 'I don't need this right now' for interactable objects that you might or might not use in the future and objects that only become interactable when something else happens in a different area. However, dialogue usually contains hints on where you need to go, and your humorous floating [strike]skull[/strike] sidekick might have something useful to say as well, so pay attention. There's a variety of endings, and you're not restricted to the path of the good guy, though, by that time you'll be questioning your definition of a 'good guy' and how good your actions actually were. This game will definitely make you think and not just about solving puzzles. 

tl;dr Buy it. It's great.

8610205.review:
Primordia is a great example of what "point and click" game should be. I liked it from the beginning and to the end - it didn`t dissapoint me. I enjoyed it`s plot - the postapocalyptic world ravaged from past war. The mankind vanished and robots are only survivors. The game is about a fate of one of those robots - Horatio and his loyal sidekick Crispin. 
It all begins when an unknown robot steals UNIIC`s power core. Without it, it is a matter of time before our heroes will ran out of energy in the middle of the desert. And so it`s do or die. The journey to the Metropol "City of glass and light" begins.
While playing this game player will meet both new friends and enemies, uncover mysteries of Metropol`s city and Horatio`s past, listen to funny and well made actor dialogues, solve many puzzles. If you like "point and click" games or just good games then you will definetely like Primordia.

8503745.review:
Primordia is a sci-fi, futuristic, post-apocalyptic story where you play as a robot named Horatio. In the world of Primordia robots run the planet; "Man" is but long forgotten and a thing only of legend. The puzzles are decently hard but not overbearing. Some puzzles actually have multiple solutions and the game has multiple endings. There is a built in hint system that you have the option of using. The hints gently nudge you in the correct direction but do not give obvious answers. I liked how the story pokes fun/satirizes modern day society and its views on religion without making it overly obvious. It was done subtley and in good taste. The story is just really well done; it is one of my favorites and certainly memorable. Primordia isn't just a well designed game; it is also beautiful, sad, and poetic. Overall, definitely another great title from Wadjet Eye. 

Side note - There is an option to turn on commentary from the writers. I highly recommend turning on the commentary if you are enjoying the game - it provides a ton of context and for me made the experience even more so enjoyable.

9.5/10

Please upvote this review if you found it useful :)

8485881.review:
Another great game by Wadjet Eye. I first discovered the studio with Gemini Rue and this is what i believe make their trademark: Point n' Click adventure games written with talent, involving dark/noire universes, with great dialogues and cynical humor. The characters are great with superb voiceacting. The graphics take it back to old school 2D art, which i am very fond of. It gives a very classic look, but remain very serious on the plot, twists or endings. This one has many, by the way. I had fun discovering them all.

Some of the criticisms i could think of is, for exemple, a couple of particular scenes or plot resolutions going too fast or being technically rushed (but they are very rare, though) and also the game being very short. Still, at the end, i enjoyed a great story with very original characters. I really wish for the sequel "Fallen" they might produce later on. I hope so!

8484995.review:
Primordia is a beautifully crafted science fiction adventure game in the spirit of Lucas Arts' The Dig. The melancholic mystery of the lovingly rendered post-apocalyptic setting is off-set by often light-hearted dialogue and cleverly ironic story elements (Freud's ego, id and superego populate an enormous defunct robot's skull at one point). The gameplay is deceptively simple, but my actions and choices had consequences, as I learned on my second play-through, which surprised and thrilled me. Like The Dig, Primordia's adventure game format ultimately serves as a vehicle to tell a subtle and poignant sci-fi fable. I highly recommend this game.

7.5 / 10

8352860.review:
This game is so amazing it actually pains me to delete it from my computer. It was an amazing experience and I URGE any and all of you to try it out. I am thus writing a review to leave my mark.

Gameplay : the puzzles are sometimes a bit contrived, but satisfying overall. It's all a matter of investigating the area and DON'T FORGET YOU CAN USE CRISPIN. He's essential to many puzzles and I got stumped because I didn't know I could use him as an item! Otherwise, despite being occasionnaly frustrating, the mechanics are very well implemented and its a joy to interact with the game's world. 

Graphics : All the graphics in this game are simply GORGEOUS. You can tell the makers put their heart into the art (pun intended), despite there being not all that much since the game is a bit short. But you can tell from the screenshots that this game really shines visually.

Audio : The real beauty of this game : the voice-over. The voice actor for Bastion's Narrator is the main character here, and he doesn't disappoint! And neither do the other characters! Each and every robot has a unique personality, and I loved just examining every little detail just for more of the voice talent. There's even a robot that only speaks in rhyming riddles! And the music, simply entrancing. When you play this, be sure to put up the volume!

Story : As usual, you are an amnesiac and you live with your faithful companion Crispin. While short, the adventure is really gripping, and charming- despite the post-apocalyptic setting. Similar to Machinarium, the world is only populated by robots, and they live in a big city of lights! There's two main sections to the story : exploring the desert, discovering various different areas, and exploring the city, which sadly wasn't that big. Unlike the desert, which had a map with a few area markers you could jump to, the city was only a few connected screens, which blocked you with puzzles. Despite the city being a bit small and the story short, it ends (according to the good ending) on a good note and offers the possibility of a sequel. 

At least... I hope...

I give this game a 9/10, with frustrating puzzles as the only negative point. Try it out! Don't worry, there's plenty of comic relief thanks to Crispin :)

8076789.review:
Let me just say, I adore this game. As someone who enjoys point-and-click adventure games as well as cyberpunk themes, this was a match made in heaven.

The story revolves around Horatio and Crispin, two robots who live in a wrecked ship. Horatio is a believer in Humanism, that humans are the creators, which is a frowned upon idea in the world the live in. They live far away from the city, isolated, until their power supply is stolen and they are forced to go to Metropol. As they search they discover the corrupt system that the city is operating under and Horatio's past. 


The characters themselves were enough to keep me playing. I enjoyed each one's own personality, their dialog, their story, it was all well done. The art style very well sets the tone for Primordia and was pleasing to look at while playing. The story was actually surprisingly well done and with multiple endings it just increases the replay value as well as my interests. It was challenging enough to where I felt incredibly accomplished once I finished it, but easy enough to where I didn't rage quite and ignore it for days. I was easily absorbed into Primordia's world and it's certainly a game I will replay more than once (and already have).

Overall, worth the money and the time if you enjoy this genre. A must have.

Primordia does 2 things well: dialogue and environment. Despite the less than crisp resolution of the game, the backgrounds and landscapes are imaginative and beautiful. The dystopian world is set post-human inhabitation, and robots--having gained self-sufficiency--are the survivors. Interactions are varied, and the clash of philosophies keeps you interested. It is an alien world, one that I was happy I visited.

I needed a guide to get through this game. Solving puzzles requires assistance or large amounts of time. Direct question puzzles were difficult. Seriously difficult. I was able to figure them out because I have enough probability knowledge to know how to crunch the numbers. Otherwise, I got stuck, alot. The technical jargon naming of items, though justifiable, made some item combo puzzles vexing. I did not even know what some words meant, and few times I would simply not even try.

It lasts about 6-8 hours, and is a fun ride. It harkens back to Monkey Island and other wonderful point-and-click adventures, but it also brings the same frustrations. Regardless, it is worth the asking price for a weekend game.

7814330.review:
Primordia is, at it's core, a nostalgic trip to the old days of the Point-and-Click Adventure genre of gaming that at this day and age has almost been completely forgotten and lost.  And what a welcome blast from the past it is indeed.  Following the travels and trials of Horatio and Crispin, this game tells an amazing story with all the conventions of the P&C genre.  But it's not QUITE to same as the games of old, such as King's Quest, or Broken Sword.

For starters, the game tells you outright that you cannot die, or can you take an action that renders the game "unwinnable", a flaw that made many of the classic staples of point-and-click, like King's Quest 5, atrocities of game design.  The locales don't require meticulous pixel hunts to find that one item you need in order to progress.  Travelling the maps is expidited by a fast-travel system that easily lets you jump from place to place.  Combining items is no longer a nonsensical MacGuyver mish-mash of parts, it's all explained and makes perfect sense.  No longer do you need a notebook to take down vital information, a handy item in-game records all the most relevant information for you, and your helper will at times offer a light nudge towards the next possible objective.

And that's just the mechanics.  The game's art and sound, two of the major foundations of point-and-click, which lives and thrives (or fails and dies) off it's atmosphere, are in full force.  The discoloration of the game's settings isn't just to be "realistic", it's a compliment to the setting and aesthetic.  And the music is highly atmospheric.  From the haunting melody of the game's menu theme "Primordia" to the tune of "The City of Glass and Light", the music compliments the setting as much as the color palette.  The characters are all fully voiced, and the voice work is clean and quality, with voices befitting each character and role.

Of course, Primordia isn't perfect.  For starters, the biggest and possibly most glaring flaw, is just how SHORT the game is.  Even if the puzzles make you spend extra time (and at first, they will), you'll likely only wind up spending 5-7 hours on this game.  It's basically over before it seems to really begin.  While it follows the classic story-telling formula, the climax of the story seems to be on you before you know it.  A point in the game that feels like the 50% is more like the 75% mark instead.  And before you know it, you're already at the final scene.  Even with multiple endings (which can be achieved by just reloading and making a different choice) the game feels painfully short-lived.  You'll be left wanting to hear and see more.

The music, while perfectly fitting the mood, never seems to stick with the player much.  I couldn't tell you a moment in the game and point out the music for it, besides the music at the main menu.  Which isn't to say the music is bad, because it's not.  But it's not catchy much.  Or very present.  The music mostly serves as a background to the game, ambience.  And it does it's part amazingly well.  I just wish that perhaps the music felt a bit more powerful at certain scenes.  Speaking of sound, the voice-acting and sound effects are a bit off as well.  Some scenes would have effects, like gunshots, with NO sound accompanying them, which removed something important to the scene.  And the voice actors themselves, while very good, still felt a bit rough.  Horatio's voice actor in particular, either does a stellar job, or seems a bit too stoic when you'd think a situation would call for a more forceful, emotional or venomous delivery.

Overall though, Primordia definitely feels like it was a game that SHOULD have existed back in the Golden Age of the adventure genre of PC gaming.  It feels like a game that I missed from my childhood and I'm just getting to sit down and enjoy it now for the first time in years, and it's not even that old!  But it takes me back to that time in gaming that I've almost forgotten and reminded me of what games I use to partake of, and that's a feeling I can't being to say how much I enjoy.  If you are a person who enjoys the point-and-click genre, grew up in that era, or want a relaxing, easy-paced game that can still deliver a great story, Primordia is worth every possible virtual cent you pay for it.

7784237.review:
This game is a point and click adventure set in a post-apocalpytic world where all humans are (presumably) dead.  Although I haven't really read books or played other games on this topic, I think it does a pretty good take on the setting, enough so to spark some creative interest of my own.  The characters and full-game voicework are for the most part fairly well done but dialogue kind of falls flat in a few places, mostly because of the script writing and not because of the voice actors.  The story is fairly cohesive and events therein are weighty and interesting, but in a few places I feel like the scenes were not given -enough- weight.  This is especially true of all the alternate endings and post-game cinematics, which although included to give the player some logical options, needed a bit more fleshing out.  It is also interesting to point out, it is impossible to game over although some decisions can change your endings.

The visual aesthetic of the game is quite nice, as is the music.  While pleasant to listen to and not annoying in any way, none of the tunes were especially catchy or easily memorable, and in a few of the dramatic scenes a stronger musical touch would have gone a long way.  Sound effects are unfortunately fairly weak, lacking thematic when operating devices and having little oomph when explosions occur, and in some places the game seems bugged and plays no sound effect at all.  The voice work has a nice robotic emulation added, although some characters seem to exhibit multiple variances in recording quality or style that doesn't seem to be a character quirk.

Performance-wise the game runs fine.  Although it resizes itself and forces fullscreen (thus making dual-monitor setups a little wonky), the resolution is not a complaint.  I never had pathing issues or pixel-hunts (just me being blind).  The game interface is functional and unobtrusive, as well as autosaving.  There are some included commentaries as well in the options menu.

All in all, I really did enjoy the game despite some of its flaws.  Its not very expensive, and it's about 7 hours of gameplay for one playthrough, with low replayability.  The setting is done very nicely and the story is good, what's there to complain about is mostly some rough edges and needed spitshining.  It doesn't ruin the game at all.  I'd say pick it up.

7765061.review:
Primordia is a game set in a world where ‘Man’ has mysteriously disappeared from the world. Man, also known as ‘The perfect machine’ were the builders from which sentient robots sprang into ‘life’. You play Horatio, a humanoid robot searching for his power core which was stolen by a ‘big robot with claws that shoots lasers’. You have a companion along the way, Crispin. He’s a cocky little robot, full of witty banter and useful advice (although, that advice can be hard to coax out of the little guy at times).

But I digress, back to the story. All I can say is, ‘Wow’. Ok, so it starts a little slow, but once you start learning about you character and his past the game really opens up. Playing as ‘Horatio Nullbuilt V.5’, your character has four versions of prior history of which the data has become fragmented and corrupted. You’ll meet robots along the way that seem to know you, but you haven’t much recollection of them! On top of the world that you are set exploring, this story mechanic really draws you in and makes you hungry for more. I remember thinking that if this game was a book, I’d read the hell out of it! It’d be one of those books that you can’t put down despite having to work early the next day! And in truth, I couldn’t put this game down. Thanks Wormwood Studios, my daughter finally gets to sleep, and instead of capitalising on this moment of rest that I could be having, I decide to turn on my PC and play a little more Primordia!

The music and sounds effects really help to bring this game to life. The background music can be haunting at times, and other times it can be so subtle to lift the mood of a scene that you hardly notice it has changed. The voices of the many robots that populate the world have a slight tinny, and sometimes electronic sound to them, each different from the last. Being how it’s set in a world of robots, Wormwood Studios could have simply hired the same vocal artist and applied filters to his/her voice, but they haven’t gone this route thankfully. Every robot you meet oozes personality, and the voice acting is top notch, adding real character and a human touch to these robots that were, at least in the past, touched by humanity.

Despite all the things that make Primordia such a wonderful game, there are a couple of things that bugged me whilst playing through it. The first thing is the heads up display, or HUD for short. The HUD is located at the top of the screen, and when you drag your mouse up to the top it will pop down, allowing access to the various menu’s and inventory. Sometimes it can get in the way though, as it’s not located at the upper most pixel, and sometimes when you are on the lookout for that next pick-up, or you want to exit to another area, the HUD can slide down, thus breaking the immersion ever so slightly. It’s not a deal breaker by any means, but it can be a slight annoyance at times.

The second thing that got to me the whole time was the graphics. Don’t get me wrong here, I absolutely adore the art style. This game looks great, my problem is that it could have looked amazing. This game isn’t HD, you can set the resolution higher, but you then have to apply a filter to smooth out the jaggies as the game wasn’t designed to run at high resolutions! This results in the image being a little washed out when you play full screen. This wouldn’t be as noticeable on a smaller monitor, but on my 22” screen it was a slight issue.

Gripes aside, Primordia is a polished and lively world with a great story that compels you to finish the game. Clocking in at around 4-5 hours, it’s a journey so full of history and lore that you can’t help but be fascinated by it, the world they have created is really captivating. The central character and his companion guide you through this gritty world, and even though Crispin can be a little on the sarcastic side, you become attached to all you companions, and enemies.

7744575.review:
Primordia is a well done point and click adventure game, but those new to the genre may find it frustrating and inconsistent. 

Point and click adventure games depend on their characters and setting, and Primordia delivers in both. The NPC robots who inhabit the world are all distinctive and have personality, but the real centrepieces are the two main characters. Horatio, the playable protagonist, plays the straight man to Crispin, his robot sidekick who I personally found kind of annoying. However, Crispin's sarcasm and jokes do a lot to lighten the mood established by the setting. Primordia takes place in a post-apocalyptic world inhabited entirely by robots. As a crucial and interesting element of this world, some of the robots worship humanity, who they view as their creators and the originators of the world. The world itself is interesting to look at and there are some really striking setpieces in several of the stages. I won't really discuss the story, but I will say that the "good" ending resolves much more than any of the other ones. Though you have to be careful as there are a couple decisions in the game that can lock you out of getting what seems to be the only ending that gives you some sense of closure. 

The graphics are done in a retro, psuedo-16 bit style that can occasionally make it difficult to determine which objects are in the background and which are interactive objects. Furthermore, my biggest problem with the game comes when you try to use these objects. Several times in the game you have to use Crispin to retrieve objects that are out of reach but the things he can do and the types of objects he can get aren't consistent. Sometimes he can bump things off ledges but other times he can't, sometimes he can use a keypad and other times he can't, sometimes he can fly into a pipe and get something and other times he can't. What it boils down to is trying everything you can and relying on trial and error to solve several puzzles as things that worked last time don't now for mainly arbitrary reasons.

Overall, Primordia is an interesting, well-fleshed out point and click adventure game that occasionally doesn't follow it's own rules. But if you can get past hearing "I don't think that will work" several dozen times you'll find a fascinating world filled with a host of unique characters.

7743312.review:
Primordia is fantastic. 

This game is a must play for anyone who enjoyed the point and click adventure games of the past. If you have never tried a point and click, this is the best example of one you could ever hope to encounter.

The story was extremely well written, and the progression was perfect. You really feel like you are developing the story and game as you play, as well as learning about yourself in the process.

This game had me both happy and sad at the end of the game. I was elated to have played such a game, and devastated that it was over.

Horatio and Crispin have a life of their own, and you really couldn't ask for better leads.

If you were ever a fan of the point and click adventure games from Sierra, this game is dead on.

7734655.review: Based only on Primordia and Resonance, I'm on board with Wadjet Eye games being the new king of the old school point and click adventure.  Their games have felt the most like the Sierra and Lucasarts adventures I grew up on - strong puzzles, interesting characters, and a goofy sense of humor.  Primordia is shorter than I expected, but it has a surprisingly deep and engrossing story - and I love the art style.  The puzzles are actually pretty tough, but if you pay attention to the dialogue there are always hints.  So, be prepared to try every dialogue option and every combination of inventory items, and keep a pen and paper handy.  Also, save often.  There are multiple ways to solve puzzles and some of those lock you out of endings/achievements.  I have a habit of reading walkthroughs for areas after I have completed them because I like to make sure I got everything.  So I had to replay a few areas to get everything in "one" playthrough.

Certainly one of the best point and click Adventures I've played since the nineties!* Both immersive and humerous. The story is Great and told extremely well. the art style is very appealing combining art nouveau and cyberpunk proves a valid design concept, the resolution ould be a tad bit higher tho and animations are a bit of a let down but that's a flaw of many games in the genre.
Gameplay is fluid, controlls and leveldesign are sensible, avoiding frustration. Riddles range from realtively easy tasks to complex and hard enigmas, without lowering to the level of odd/alien/generic minigames or resulting in daylong meditations on what to do. Unlike most P&Cs with inventory, Primordias items are neither randomly taken from the environment(aka taking the banana instead of the wench) nor require absurd combinations, most "crating" tasks are sensible. 
The Help function is a bit wonky, it's hints range from being very specific to being nomore than a slight nudge in the right direction and there are no "advice levels" or "search functions". there is no hotspot highlighter, which may be seen both ways. You will have to think a bit to get this game done but it's very well solvable without any outside help** or random clicking.
It's also fully*** voiced, and quite good if I may add.

Ps: Unniic, Genius!

*Probably THE best if you dismiss myst 4 as not a point and click game
**I required it once, when I was standing infront of the hotspot. The hotspot was even named "crystal"   -.-
***The is one spot(info booth) where I would have liked an additional voiceover, something Myst 4 did: voice all written text.

7579512.review:
I haven't been this happy since Grim Fandango. It's a 16-bit point-and-click adventure (in the play style of Curse of Monkey Island) in sepia tones. The game is fully voice acted, and it's the least annoying voice acting ever. The lead is voiced by Logan Cunningham, the guy who narrated Bastion, and the other characters and voices thus far have been FANTASTIC. 

At one point, I had to set the mouse aside to get pencil and paper out because a pair of indignant robots wanted me to settle a legal dispute, but not until after proving my worthiness by solving a logical story problem. 

Basically I have spent six times as much money on games that were one tenth as engaging and wonderful. I don't know why this game isn't blowing up my friends list already, but hey, now you know.

7422443.review:
Un autre jeu de Wadjet Eye, du même calibre que Resonance ou Gemini Rue. Celui-ci se déroule dans un monde où les humains n'existent plus et seuls les robots survivent, à défaut de vivre. Nous incarnons l'androide Horiato accompagné du petit robot volant Crispin (créé par Horiato) et tout commence quand un vilain gros robot vient nous voler notre source d'énergie.

Comme les autres jeux de Wadjet Eye, Primordia propose plusieurs fins. Il parait même qu'il y a plusieurs manières de résoudre les énigmes (ne l'ayant fait qu'une fois, je n'ai pas pu le constater par moi-même).

Le background se découvre au fur et à mesure et est très très riche. Le ton est plutôt sérieux, mais Crispin vient rajouter de bonnes notes d'humour (vraiment marrant, ce robot).

Les voix sont de très bonnes facture et comme d'habitude, le générique de fin est accompagné d'une très belle musique.

Je le recommande aux amateurs de point'n click non rebutés par des graphismes old school (pixelisés).

'Primordia' had a story so good, I had to come back and play it again to see some of the other endings. Many of the most thought-provoking events make references to issues that have kept me awake before. It's interesting to experience a game that has me thinking about it for a time after the ending credits.

There are some audio issues after using Steam's overlay UI, but the game's pretty polished aside from that glitch. The puzzles are good, but the world is a little empty. However, the animated characters are entertaining and keep things interesting. The artwork and voiceover work is also amazing.

If you want a good story that's told with a classic style point-and-click adventure game, then this is it.

1958570.review:
I've never been an extremely huge fan of point-and-click puzzle games, but Primordia caught my attention, initially due to the attractive art style and the story teaser. So I gave it a try, and was blown away by how much I absolutely enjoyed it. It's your standard point-and-click; you collect items, open your inventory, and can combine items or use them on characters or objects in the world to progress. So there's little to mess up when it comes to controls, and Primordia succeeds there. 
The game is set some ambiguous number of years in the future. The world is inhabited by robots, no sign of organic life anywhere. You play as Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot designed to build and repair. While aboard your ship, the Uniic, you are attacked by a strange robot and stripped of your ship's power core. Left without transportation and limited power keeping you running, you are left with no other option but to wander out into the world, trying to track down a power source, or as a last resort, enter the city of Metropol, "the city of glass and light." Not much is known about Metropol, other than there is supposedly unlimited power for everyone. Still, Horatio has his reserves about entering the city; despite his logic-driven robot nature, he doesn't trust the place.
As I mentioned, the art style was much of what first intrigued me, and it's prevalent throughout the game. It's designed to look very old-school and pixelated, but the amount of detail that can be projected by so few pixels is astounding, not to mention the general apocalyptic dystopian feel it gives off, which as a fan of Fallout, I enjoyed all too much. 
Overall this was one of those games that gave me that feel of reading a really good book; I'd sit down and play and not want to put it down until I found out what happened next. The only problems I had were a few vague or confusing puzzles, in which I had to resort to the old "try everything with everything on everything" play method common to point-and-click games. Aside from that, the game offers multiple endings, some far more underwhelming than others, which left me feeling a tad unsatisfied. Still, the game was extremely enjoyable, and one of the few games that I'd almost like to forget playing so I could enjoy it all over again.

Set in a post-apocalyptic world strewn with cast-off machines, Primordia tells the story of Horatio Nullbuilt, a stoic robot who values his solitude and independence. 958985.review: Primordia è prima di tutto un grande omaggio alla storia del genere punta e clicca. Fin dalla scelta di utilizzare l'interfaccia a scomparsa nella parte alta dello schermo, tipica di alcune vecchie glorie (ne cito una su tutte, Gabriel Knight - SIns of the Fathers) fino a scegliere una risoluzione "vintage" di 640x480. Ma Primordia è anche una bellissima avventura, ambientata in un mondo cyberpunk dove l'uomo è ormai solo storia da raccontare. Un gioco con una trama interessante, uno stile grafico forse non davvero originale ma efficace, dialoghi sempre intelligenti, voice acting di altissimo livello, bellissime musiche, enigmi che forse non sono mai davvero difficili, però logici e coerenti con l'ambiente e le varie situazioni. Ancora non vi basta ? Allora vi dico possibilità di risolvere alcuni enigmi in più di un modo, finali multipli, achievements e cloud saving. Che state aspettando ? Se vi piace il genere sarà un piacere giocarlo, come lo è stato per me.

2648314.review: I think this game is awesome; a really well made Indie Adventure title. Reminiscent of 90's PC adventure games, Primordia is a 'point and click' game in which you must use skills of logical deduction, puzzle solving, listening and recall to complete all tasks and find all usable objects. I really like the tone created by the graphics, artwork/scenery, soundtrack and dialogue; I quite liked Horatio and Crispin as protagonists, too. The game has backstory that ties into the plot nicely, and I didn't find it overly expansive or tedious. The world in the game is quite small, but its an appropriate fit for the length of the story and the style of gameplay. I highly recommend this, its a beautiful little game. *****

875587.review:
Words cannot express the deep and thoughtful world that Primordia is. Unless for some reason, you hate – and I mean, truly, with burning fire, HATE – point and click adventure games, you owe it to yourself to play this game.

As dark as the world can seem, humor abounds in this game. The simple graphics are still beautifully rendered, and the characters you meet are ones who will climb inside your head, and stay for the long haul. With a cast of incredibly well realized and acted robots, the world doesn't just invite you in; it sucks you down, and makes you a part of it. Things in this game will be thought about days, weeks later. Enough cannot be said for how immersive this game is.

As unfortunate and bleak as the world of Primordia may seem, it has many things I wish to see again. Perhaps, if enough people play Primordia, some day we can all go back together.

2017 Update: Still thinking about this game. Still both horrified by and in love with it. Miss ya Horatio.

Что бы человек для них был богом?
Что бы был религией?
Horatio Nullbuilt, version 5 - он верит в человека, он полностью изучил Gospel of Man.
Он довольно таки необычный робот.
У него есть друг, которого он же и построил - Crispin Horatiobuilt, version one.
В двоём они живут в постапокалиптичном мире на корабле UNNIC, застрявшем в пустоше и который обеспечен энергией благодаря Power Core.

Остался лишь резервный генератор, которого надолго не хватит.
Пора отправляться на поиски...
-----------------
Такова сюжетная завязка игры Primordia.
Primordia - великолепный пиксельный квест, сделанный знатоками таковых из студии Wadjet Eye Games.
Эти ребята создали такие прекрасные вещи, как The Blackwell Series, Resonance и Geminy Rue.
О дааа, эти ребята знают в квестах толк.
Я люблю все квесты их студии - они того заслуживают.
И Primordia я люблю больше всех.
Почему?
Сейчас поясню.
------------------
Дамы и господа, взгляните пожалуйста на сюжет.
Он прекрасен.
Превосходен.
Да, завязка проста, но вот дальнейшее...
Сюжет очень проработан и глубок, мрачен и безысходен.
Он бесподобен.
И это - важно.
Ведь это квест, в квесте главное - сюжет и головоломки.
Кстати о таковых.
Ну, решать местные задачки не так уж ипросто.
Порой сломать голову просто.
Потому что не додумаешься до очевидного.
И это - хорошо.
Хоть и бесит порой, но хорошо.
Да и пиксельхантинга тут мало - это тоже хорошо.
Вообщем, замечательно.
Но куда замечательнее атмосфера.
Атмосфера, состоящее из двух превосходных факторов - графона и звука.
Графон - превосходный пиксельный рай. Всё настолько хорошо прорисованно, настолько красиво, мрачно, детально, что мои глаза просто получают удовольствие от увиденного.
Этот прекрасный постапокалиптичный мир...
Пустоши, груды желеезного ржавого мусора.
Безысходность...
А звук здесь ахренителен.
Эмбиэнт, музыка, звуки окружения - всё на высшем уровне.
В особенности я хочу сказать это про озвучку.
Она бесподобна.

3647003.review:
Primordia is a must for anyone who is a fan of old-school point & click adventures. 

The tale follows robot Horatio and his floating companion Crispin as they try to retrieve a power core stolen from them by a boxy robot with lasers in a post-apocalyptic style world - however, the story is much more than this basic premise. One of the central questions the player wants answered is what exactly happened to the humans who presumably once inhabited this Earth and created the robots left behind. Added to this is a tapestry of moral and philosopical themes such as the meaning and existence of free will, individuality, progress, and what constitutes the 'greater good'. These sometimes rather heavy themes are pulled off through excellent writing, and are offset by a quirky humour that runs through the whole game. This off-beat humour and occasional breaking of the fourth wall are reminiscent of some of my favourite, genuinely old-school games such as Simon the Sorcerer, and I think anyone who was playing this kind of thing in the early 90's will appreciate it. The worldbuilding and background detail is fantastic - my one gripe is that the game just doesn't go far enough. There are hints of exciting other locations that we don't get to visit, and the larger philosophical themes are never fully explored. 

As this is a game and not just a visual novel, I should probably mention a bit about the gameplay - it's pretty much standard of point & click games, and uses the traditional inventory system. Nothing stood out as unique, but equally nothing was inconvenient or jarring. The puzzles are not particularly challenging, and there's plenty of hints on hand from Crispin if one chooses to press him for them (it's also pretty fun to hear him getting annoyed and snarky when you try and use him too many times). I prefer simpler puzzles so the flow of the story doesn't stall, but others might find this game too easy. 

In terms of visuals, the pixel art is gorgeous, and the colour palette of browns, rusts and muted golds perfectly realizes the dusty, disued world. The audio content is also great, from the music to the voice acting. Even minor characters are voiced, and the robot voice effects are pretty cool.

Overall an 9/10 for this game. The presentation is beautiful both visually and aurally, and beneath this is a solid story rooted in a world that feels like it really could be our future. Horatio and Crispin are likeable and memorable characters to journey through this tale with, and their easy banter creates the emotional anchor to this crumbling planet. Points are lost for the sense that the game could have been bigger both in terms of the number of locations, and the philosophical ideas that never seem to be explored quite as far as you hope. Regardless, 'Primordia' is highly recommended!

1091198.review: The flaws:  It's very short, lasting around 6 hours if you don't linger too much on the puzzles, which are sometimes (later on in the game) reliant on numbers and math to an extent that there was no way I wouldn't be pulling out a guide.  Worse, when I found the numbers needed to solve a puzzle, I wondered how the writers even arrived at that solution.  Evidently, I cannot math.  (Thankfully, though, plenty of other puzzles are subtle yet logical, and a pleasure to work out.)  Some of the dialogue here is pretty cornball, clashing with the dreary dystopian setting, but then again I suppose that fits with the tradition of this style of game.  Beyond these issues, Primordia enjoys an aesthetic drawing from Giger, Moebius, Dune, and probably a bit of Machinarium and/or Beneath a Steel Sky, with music that recalls Blade Runner and Kaiba.  The scope of the story and its setting suggests far more than the ground you actually cover, but just that it seems so sprawling is wonderful.  Primordia feels like a labor of love.

There was an era of adventure gaming that I really loved: the 90s LucasArts-style era.  These were games that ran in 256-color MCGA mode and had MIDI soundtracks.  If you were fortunate enough to own, rather than download, these games, you might even have gotten the voice tracks.

This game is a lot like those.  It has some puzzles that make little sense and some arbitrary hurdles, but on the whole, it holds up very well.  The surplus of endings is interesting, as well.  Primordia doesn't have a very long playthrough, which is nice.  It's like a novella and it just hits the spot.

Only problems I encounter are some glitches with the game. Some of the spirits from inventory gone missing. Steam overlay bothers with the game making it skip dialogs. Also sometimes the game crashes but it was due to configuration issues. 
9/10

If you encounter any issue with the game then configure it as shown below and it should fix the crash issues.

1. In Steam, right-click "Properties" on Primordia
2. Go to the "Local Files" tab
3. Select the "Browse Local Files" button
4. A file explorer window will open. Double-click "winsetup.exe" (or just "winsetup")
5. Look at the bottom of that window, there is an "Advanced >>" button: click on it
6. In the new area that appeared, there is a "Maximum Size" drop-down that shows "20MB". Change the value to 100.
7. "Save" (or "Save and run") and it should work :)

39170380.review:
[quote]"Together, we can build a Primordia; every day a moment of creation".[/quote]

[h1]General Impressions[/h1]
There is a certain wistfulness that permeates an existence without affection. In [i]Primordia[/i], building a robot is the equivalent of birthing one. To oil cogs into a machine's first breath is a labor of love. However, just as much as human birth can blossom from a seed of spite, machines too can click and clank about as the result of nothing short of duty and necessity. 

Playing as Horatio Nullbuilt (built by [i]null[/i]), wistfulness is your paragon; humanity, your faith. 

With that premise, [i]Primordia[/i] may prove not be a game for everyone – even if such thing did exist. On the other hand, its infinite amount of excellently delivered wisdom make the game quickly and universally take root within every heart brave enough to play it. 

In that sense, I believe there has never been a point and click game quite like [i]Primordia[/i]. Although it stands atop of a hill with the classics – the [i]Monkey Island[/i] series, The [i]Broken Sword[/i] series, [i]The Longest Journey[/i], etc. – it holds something that few of its older peers have: it has the vision, the eloquence and the language of modern day games. It takes the best if its genre and holds it close to its heart, while tossing away the majority of what so many people have always disliked about it – like not knowing when or in what order to combine items or being stuck in convoluted puzzles – and from that, it draws its strength and appeal. 

However, [i]Primordia[/i]'s strongest trait lies elsewhere: in its story. The universe it weaves is one that begs you to belong to it. Which is quite the accomplishment, considering how the vast majority of said universe is tarnished by decay and, upon a first glance, seems wholeheartedly uninviting and cold. 

And yet, as my last decision of the game dawned to an epic close, I didn't want to leave. That scrap of the Earth deemed as its most crude and barren shell felt like home, and Horatio Nullbuilt and Crispin Horatiobuilt felt like family.

There are, out there, creative births that make us wonder how far we can stretch the definition of 'art'. In [i]Primordia[/i], it is just as endless as a robot's love.

39057624.review:
Now [b]this[/b] was an experience. And a b'sodding good one at that. I don't have an all too extensive history with point-and-click games, but I felt that Primordia was unique (UNNIIC?).
 
The story of Primordia takes place in what seems like a distant future, where humanity is but a bleak and redundant memory in the most ancient of machines. Biological life has been eradicated and solely machines roam the surface of the dying planet. We, the player, follow Horatio Nullbuilt V.5 and his companion - Crispin Horatiobuilt V.1 - in a quest to retrieve the power core of their ship that has been stolen. The duo search the dunes in the first arc, but soon arrive at Metropol. The Last City. The City of Glass and Light. Though they soon discover that their expectations were wildy inaccurate...

In my opinion, the plot of Primordia is quite intriguing. Morality [spoiler] and the preservation of mankind and machines [/spoiler] is discussed [spoiler] in an excerpt from the files of Horus and conversations with MetroMind [/spoiler] and we encounter myriads of wacky characters all with their own personalities, motives and backgrounds. There are several endings, although most can be achieved by [spoiler] going back to a save from the last scene in the Tower [/spoiler].

Overall, the game covers the adventure of a machine suffering from partial amnesia (not a medical term) who is dragged into intrigues and conspirations and who is forced to realize his identity in a abysmal post-singularity world. Will you save your friends? Will you save Metropol from descending into chaos and ruin? Will you fulfill your [spoiler] ancient mission or your [/spoiler] dream? Is there even hope for the Last of the Four Cities?

Art: What can one say but simply [i]astounding[/i]?

Music/Soundtrack and SFX: Really quite atmospheric. Fully voice acted.

Story: Solid 

Gameplay: There isn't too much 'gameplay', but it runs smoothly. Minor graphic glitches and movement errors. 
I suggest that fullscreen mode should be added for increased immersion, but sadly, the game likely won't be getting any updates. 

Some issues I had included text being shown at a ridiculously rapid pace [spoiler] and my inability to steal Oswald's oil before Clarity started accompanying Horatio and Crispin [/spoiler].  

Primordia isn't all too replayable, but the first playthrough will be fascinating for the player. Remember: almost EVERYTHING interactable has a use, so when you obtain a new item always try to combine it with all other items in your inventory, and most objects and structures out in the map. (Always click everything with everything you have.) If you're stuck, try consulting (clicking on) Crispin. 

I genuinely love Primordia and of course recommend it.

39022610.review:
Greetings Steamers! As an old graphic adventure's player and a experienced gamer in many genres i must say im impressed with every single part of this game since i buyed and completed it. 

The music ambient songs fit with every enviroment of the game and this last ones make the player get involved in the actions of the game. I liked the puzzles and map exploration of the game as well as Horatio and Crispin comments and jokes in the decissions and findings.

Also i've seen Crispin's comments and advices make the game easier, wich is not a bad thing for unexperienced graphic adventures players who want help, because you can choose not to ask Crispin for advice, so the game maintains its dificulty and makes you think.

The art is fantastic, a perfect example of decayed futurist world with an own and original style that i believe every graphic adventure fan and game art fan will love.

By the way I've read some negative comments about this game complaining about the ease or difficulty of the puzzles and also the "pixel hunter" expresion refering to the map exploration and its secrets and i can't less than ask myself: isn't that part of the game genre? why whould it have to be that easy? aren't the graphic adventures about thinking the different puzzles and ways to get the final satisfaction of completing the story? I understand the "i'm stuck" problem, i've lived it many times in this genre, but it's not an excuse to make developers responsible for "not making the game as easy as i want to". I think the game is perfectly complete and does not need facilities but mindful players who must apreciate the details and think more when doing the puzzles, wich are created to think and resolve them.

At last i must say the only thing i dont like about the game just to help devs: the Metropol city robots. The robots make a constant walk along the maps you can explore into the city, and i liked the way how diferent robots appear and leave when you change of map and in the different parts of the game, but the ones moving constantly into the maps just go nowhere turning at the end of the roads and coming back the same way. That gives you a kick in the city involve sense(if you know what i mean).

To end this reviwew I definitely recommend this game... no... this piece of digital art to every single person who's searching for an adventure with a great story, many ends depending on decissions and a impressive way to get involved on it.
Thanks to Primordia developers for this story, i wont lie, i want more and me like others in this community would like to see more games like this soon.

First part is for people considering to buy the game. Second part is my actual review on the game. They're separated by lines, so use that to skip ahead if you just want to know more about the game itself. Forwarning: I'm not an avid point and click adventure player so I can't compare this to other games in the same genre - If that's what you're looking for my review probably won't be helpful to you.



If you're not a fan of point and click adventures, and stories aren't drawing factors for you for whether a not a game is worth playing (despite gameplay that may or may not suit your tastes) then this game isn't blowing anything out of the waters with its gameplay enough for me to consider you buying it.

HOWEVER, if your into stories at all and the point and click formula is even slightly tolerable (or curious to you) this is a must buy.

________________________________________________________________________________


I was hooked on the art style before I was hooked onto the description. You generally shouldn't judge a book by it's cover but I'm an absolute SUCKER for pixelated games of any nature.

I'm also a sucker for sentient robots and post apocalyptic scenarios that don't involve zombies.

This game was gorgeous enough just from the screen shots that despite it being a point and click I considered it. The deciding factor was the rating of the reviews and the fact that it was on sale so I said "even if I end up not liking it it's 2 bucks I can't be mad".

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Again coming from someone who doesn't like the genre, gameplay was better then I was expecting it to be. Beginning lead you through a lot more easily then I would have thought a point and click would have put into a "tutorial" section of the game and (at least for the early areas) I only had one real nag point and it was the one section of your ship home that I didn't realize you could walk out onto by walking through a wall that didn't seem at all (to me, anyway) to be a door.

And the point and click puzzles towards the end are generally me being frustrated from not seeing clues that are kinda slapped into your face once you realize what they were (which is it's own kind of annoying but I digress). Dialogue can't be repeated, and EVERY bit of dialogue needs to be listened to. You're given very few hints from your companion Crispin and in some sections they aren't even helpful. "Do this thing you already know you need to be doing" Yes, Crispin, but [i]how[/i]. 

I won't lie the amount of times I skimmed or had an NPCs comment fly over my head to be stuck for an hour wondering what I was doing wrong only made everything harder. There are brief but unreliable auto saves -- it's better if you save before talking to people so if you need to you can listen to their dialogue again.

If you like thinking there are a lot of challenging puzzles that put your mind to work though. Not too much, but just enough to make you feel smart for getting it. The only hard part is figuring out what pieces you need to solve things, if you're missing anything at all.

As a side note this game is not friendly to pick back up after a couple of days or a week. You might as well restart from the beginning - you don't really get a feel for what you were doing previously at all unless if you have a good memory.


[h1]Story Story Story (and art)[/h1]

Before I actually start this out, can I just point out that this game has voice acting? Yeah, [i]voice acting.[/i] I was taken by surprise but pleasantly so - it was great work and generally fit the game well.


When I say this game has the background story building of games like Horizon Zero Dawn I'm not kidding. You're given a world and a small objective to begin with, before being given an area that might as well have jumped out of the past. That past area at a superficial glance is nothing much but then it becomes SO much more after just a little delving. The art, meanwhile, draws your curiosity in and really settles you down into the games atmosphere and how the world really does seem to be crumbling into nothing but rust.

As you keep exploring the story goes from your first objective to a much more intense objective and then all the pieces of the old world slowly come together. Getting clues from ones left behind in the age of man, figuring out what exactly happened who your character actually was (or IS) was intense and the multiple different endings that can spur from it being a point and click adventure game where your mind is the only limiting factor in what ending you go for HONESTLY has given the genre some pointers in that regard for story alone. It wont be as easy for me to pass over them in the future, and it's definitely earned this game a spot among my favorite games (including but not limited to Aragami, Breath Of The Wild, Horizon Zero Dawn, Ori and the Blind Forest, etc).

The only thing I found extremely disappointing about this game was that there wasn't more. I'll definitely be chewing on this story for weeks to come.

________________________________________________________________________________

TLDR: Story's amazing enough that even if you're not a fan of the game genre I'd recommend it, even at base price.
