40758144.review:
The best P&C game I've played yet, [i]Primordia[/i] thrilled me with excellent world design, an engaging plot, memorable characters, and fun puzzles. At such a low price, I can't imagine why you wouldn't pick this up. If you're still on the fence, allow this review to push you to (hopefully) the buy-it-now side.

[h1]PLOT (8/10)[/h1]
You are Horatio Nullbuilt, a robot hermit living in the wasteland with his floating lamp sidekick Crispin. Life is quiet, until a large robot breaks into your house and steals your power core. Energy is a precious resource, so you aim to get that core back before you black out.

The story unfolds into a grand adventure with many memorable characters, good pacing (though slow to start), clever writing, and some strong philosophy. The only drawback I would say is how short it was, though equally sweet. I would estimate it took me around 10 hours to complete. The review says less hours because I play a lot in Steam offline mode.

Finished [i]Primordia[/i] and want more story? Check out [i]Fallen[/i], a spin-off extension of the story post-game!

[h1]GRAPHICS (10/10)[/h1]
Goodness gracious, the art is masterful. Every scene had my eyes glued to it like candy, and most areas of the game were a picture I would use as my computer desktop. The environments are so beautifully detailed, you just can't help but admire the effort it must've taken. Mind you, the setting takes place far beyond apocalypse and the world is in a state of decay and ruin, so expect mostly Earth tones. Great for a colorblind guy like me.

[h1]SOUNDTRACK (6/10)[/h1]
Haunting melodies that match the melancholy atmosphere of the game very well. They're not distracting in any way, however I was paying more attention to puzzles or dialogue throughout the game.

[h1]PUZZLES (8/10)[/h1]
As you'd expect with a P&C game, there are a lot of them. These generally revolve around logical reasoning, or memory of past locations and dialogue. The puzzles were great fun, and while a couple had me scratching my head, they all were reasonable enough that I didn't get frustrated. My favorite puzzle of the game was getting [spoiler]Memorious's code![/spoiler]

[h1]VERDICT (9/10)[/h1]
I haven't played a P&C game in a while, so I'm glad [i]Primordia[/i] was the first to welcome me back to this genre! A big thanks to the devs who made such a great adventure!

40747458.review:
Some random thoughts:
-Crispin's quirky personality and humor work so well next to Horatio's colder approach. What a great duo!

-It only took, like, two or three screens to set the mood of absolute loneliness in a vast, unwelcoming city. they just put some residents that will refuse to talk to you, a waiting line for a questionable service, and a lot of distant lights in the background that imply thousands of buildings. That, to me, is smart storytelling.
Oh! And that one line that is delivered when you try to talk to someone: "[i]Strange robot... Go away...[/i]". 

-The dialogues and descriptions are intelligent and written with economy. Primordia's universe is bleak and its colour palette is that of rust, dust and decay. Yet, while it shouldn't feel intimate at all, it sucked me in.

-What begins as a simple, personal quest to redeem a stolen energy crystal, progresses into a collective dream of building a better world.

-Logan Cunningham was once again fantastic. Nothing new here.

-I got some fleeting notions here and there that SOME of the themes that the game exlplores, are present in R.Scott's Blade Runner: [i]who is your maker[/i], [i]what did he built you for[/i], [i]what makes one human[/i] and, of course, [i]dignity[/i]. This became even more apparent, because of the ending that I opted for ("Stay true to the end"). And then The song that we listen to at the ending credits is called "Dreams of Green". This MUST be a "Memories of Green" reference!

[i][...]As days go by, I long to sleep
And so to dream, and soon it seems,
I'll wake no more.

And in the dark, the endless dark,
Will be my heart
With dreams of green.[/i]

Oh, I didn't cry at all, BTW. It was the fucking Dunes all along.
And now, excuse me, I have to play it from beginning to end again while listening to the creator's commentary.

Thank you Carmela, for introducing this gem to me.
Thank you George, for gifting this for my birthday! 

I owe you a good one!

39975751.review:
TL;DR: The story really had me hooked, but Primordia's gameplay is far from today's standards. I am torn between whether recommend it for the story alone or don't recommend for the gameplay. I guess the latter is more important for a videogame.

Primordia has a great story and cool post-apocalyptic setting, but gameplay wise it's just like a point and click adventure from the 95'. Pixel graphics, pixel hunting (mostly due to the low resolution and everything blending into one brown mess), some puzzles have nothing to do with logic and even when you know a solution you think "wtf?". Furthermore, the main hero is followed by a really obnoxious sidekick (he calls himself that) who tries to be witty, but instead produces boring monologues written by a 10 year old.

Moreover, the game also has a bug when all dialogues are instantly skipped without a single button press.

I have no idea why it has so many positive reviews: the only good thing about this game is story with multiple endings. And even then, you get to choose the ending in the very last scene: your actions during the game have zero impact on how it ends.

39974937.review: Absolutely fantastic. Great puzzles with multiple ways to solve them, awesome backstories and a whole robot universe that feels like it's living and breathing on its own. 11 out of 10.

39928846.review:
A puzzle adventure where the only enemy is your own problem-solving ability. If you're not up to puzzles, guides work just fine without ruining the narrative aspect, which is truly the gem of the game. (If you avoid spoilers of course.)

The atmosphere is excellent, being a post-apocalyptic setting that does not feel as used and abused as the label. The reds and browns feel fresh despite their lifelessness, the barren, blasted landscape seems alien rather than cliche, and the ruins impart a sense of history, the sensation of a world frozen in its last moment as the sands and rust slowly consume it. 

The inverted parallels with our own society I found interesting. The way revelations wove disparate elements together was also great. The story was touching, with the opportunity of a best ending but also *choices!* and *consequences!* that allow one to explore other paths. It won't completely change everything, but enough to not feel arbitrary. 

I did not feel it was too short. The pacing was right, it was a complete story, and everything was grounded in the overall narrative. If absolute length is a concern consider it a novella, short yet satisfying. 

There is a short story, "Fallen" on their website, that follows but is otherwise unrelated to events in the game, that adds to the world and I would recommend as well.

What a gem of a game. 

I have a soft spot in my heart for dystopian/post-apocalyptic/cyberpunk/steampunk settings and stories so this game quickly became a favorite of mine. Great writing with quirky humor, fun characters, and a memorable world all made the experience thought provoking and enjoyable.

I appreciate that the puzzles, while challenging at times, weren't overly difficult so they didn't bring the game to a screeching halt or distract from the story. 

There are a few choices to be made in the game as well as a variety of endings depending on aforementioned choices so this game does have replay value. Not that I needed another excuse to complete various playthroughs, but it was interesting to see the various endings and where certain characters could end up. 

Crispin is too awesome to be my sidekick, but hey, I'm not complaining. 

That's all folks. Another great point and click adventure game well worth your time.
